Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Utah Code of Criminal Procedure
================================================================

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 1 - Preliminary Provisions
*******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-1 Short title.
-----------------------------------------
This act shall be known and may be cited as the "Utah Code of Criminal Procedure."

Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-2 Criminal procedure prescribed.
-----------------------------------------------------------
The procedure in criminal cases shall be as prescribed in this title, the Rules of Criminal Procedure, and such further rules as may be adopted by the Supreme Court of Utah.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-3 Definitions.
-----------------------------------------
For the purpose of this act:Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-3(1): "Criminal action" means the proceedings by which a person is charged, accused, and brought to trial for a public offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-3(2): "Indictment" means an accusation in writing presented by a grand jury to the district court charging a person with a public offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-3(3): 77-2-2.2 "Information" means an accusation, in writing, charging a person with a public offense which is presented, signed, and filed in the office of the clerk where the prosecution is commenced in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-3(4): 78A-5-107 "Magistrate" means a justice or judge of a court of record or not of record or a commissioner of such a court appointed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-3(5): "Risk and needs assessment" means an actuarial tool validated on offenders that determines:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-3(5)(a): an individual's risk of reoffending; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-3(5)(b): the criminal risk factors that, when addressed, reduce the individual's risk of reoffending.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-4 Conviction to precede punishment.
--------------------------------------------------------------
No person shall be punished for a public offense until convicted in a court having jurisdiction.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-5 Prosecuting party.
-----------------------------------------------
A criminal action for any violation of a state statute shall be prosecuted in the name of the state of Utah. A criminal action for violation of any county or municipal ordinance shall be prosecuted in the name of the governmental entity involved.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6 Rights of defendant.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(1): In criminal prosecutions the defendant is entitled:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(1)(a): To appear in person and defend in person or by counsel;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(1)(b): To receive a copy of the accusation filed against him;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(1)(c): To testify in his own behalf;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(1)(d): To be confronted by the witnesses against him;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(1)(e): To have compulsory process to insure the attendance of witnesses in his behalf;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(1)(f): To a speedy public trial by an impartial jury of the county or district where the offense is alleged to have been committed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(1)(g): To the right of appeal in all cases; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(1)(h): To be admitted to bail in accordance with provisions of law, or be entitled to a trial within 30 days after arraignment if unable to post bail and if the business of the court permits.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(2): In addition:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(2)(a): No person shall be put twice in jeopardy for the same offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(2)(b): No accused person shall, before final judgment, be compelled to advance money or fees to secure rights guaranteed by the Constitution or the laws of Utah, or to pay the costs of those rights when received;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(2)(c): No person shall be compelled to give evidence against himself;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(2)(d): A wife shall not be compelled to testify against her husband nor a husband against his wife; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-6(2)(e): No person shall be convicted unless by verdict of a jury, or upon a plea of guilty or no contest, or upon a judgment of a court when trial by jury has been waived or, in case of an infraction, upon a judgment by a magistrate.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-7 Dismissal without trial -- Custody or discharge of defendant.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-7(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-7(1)(a): Further prosecution for an offense is not barred if the court dismisses an information or indictment based on the ground:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-7(1)(a)(i): there was unreasonable delay;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-7(1)(a)(ii): the court is without jurisdiction;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-7(1)(a)(iii): the offense was not properly alleged in the information or indictment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-7(1)(a)(iv): there was a defect in the impaneling or the proceedings relating to the grand jury.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-7(1)(b): The court may make orders regarding custody of the defendant pending the filing of new charges as the interest of justice may require.   Otherwise, the defendant shall be discharged and bail exonerated.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-1-7(2): An order of dismissal based upon unconstitutional delay in bringing the defendant to trial or upon the statute of limitations is a bar to any other prosecution for the offense charged.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 2 - Prosecution, Screening, and Diversion
**********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2 Definitions.
-----------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2(1): "Commencement of prosecution" means the filing of an information or an indictment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2(2): "Diversion" means suspending criminal proceedings before conviction on the condition that a defendant agree to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2(2)(a): participate in a rehabilitation program;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2(2)(b): pay restitution to a victim; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2(2)(c): fulfill some other condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2(3): 77-38b-102 "Restitution" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2(4): "Screening" means the process used by a prosecuting attorney to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2(4)(a): terminate an investigative action;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2(4)(b): proceed with prosecution;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2(4)(c): move to dismiss a prosecution that has been commenced; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2(4)(d): cause a prosecution to be diverted.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.1 Authorization to file information.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Except as otherwise provided by law, no information may be filed charging the commission of any felony or class A misdemeanor unless authorized by a prosecuting attorney.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.2 Signing and filing of information.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.2(1): The prosecuting attorney shall sign all informations.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.2(2): The prosecuting attorney may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.2(2)(a): sign the information in the presence of a magistrate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.2(2)(b): present and file the information in the office of the clerk where the prosecution is commenced upon the signature of the prosecuting attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.2(3): When reasonably available, the prosecuting attorney shall ensure that the information includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.2(3)(a): the defendant's state identification number issued by the Bureau of Criminal Identification;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.2(3)(b): the citation number associated with the case; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.2(3)(c): the offense tracking number associated with the case.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.3 Reducing the level of an offense.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.3(1): 76-3-103; 76-3-103; 76-3-104; 76-3-103; 76-3-103; 76-3-104 Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a prosecuting attorney may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.3(1)(a): 76-3-103; 76-3-103; 76-3-104 present and file an information charging an individual for an offense under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.3(1)(b): 76-3-103; 76-3-103; 76-3-104 subject to the approval of the court, amend an information, as part of a plea agreement, to charge an individual for an offense under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.3(2): A court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.3(2)(a): enter a judgment of conviction for an offense filed under Subsection (1) at one degree lower than classified in statute; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.3(2)(b): impose a sentence for the offense filed under Subsection (1) at one degree lower than classified in statute.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.3(3): 77-41-102 A conviction of an offense at one degree lower than classified in statute under Subsection (2) does not affect the requirements for registration of the offense under Title 77, Chapter 41, Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry, if the elements of the offense for which the defendant is convicted are the same as the elements of an offense described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-2.3(4): This section does not preclude an individual from obtaining and being granted an expungement for the individual's record in accordance with Title 77, Chapter 40a, Expungement of Criminal Records.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-3 Termination of investigative action.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Prior to the commencement of prosecution, the prosecutor may, without approval of a magistrate, authorize a termination of investigative action when it appears that further investigative action is not in the public interest.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-4 Dismissal of prosecution.
------------------------------------------------------
After commencement of a prosecution the prosecutor may, upon reasonable grounds, move the magistrate before whom the prosecution is pending to dismiss the prosecution. If, in the judgment of the magistrate, the prosecution should not continue, he may dismiss the prosecution and enter an order of dismissal stating the reasons for the dismissal in the order.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-4.3 Compromise of boating violations -- Limitations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-4.3(4)(a): the Uniform Bail Schedule amount;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-4.3(4)(b): the amount of any surcharges being assessed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-4.3(4)(c): the amount of the plea in abeyance fee.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-4.5 Dismissal by compromise -- Limitations.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-4.5(1): (2) In misdemeanor cases the court may dismiss the case upon motion of the prosecutor if it is compromised by the defendant and the injured party, except under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-4.5(2): A dismissal by compromise may not be granted when the misdemeanor is committed by or upon a peace officer while in the performance of his duties, or riotously, or with intent to commit a felony.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5 Diversion agreement -- Negotiation -- Contents.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(1): At any time after the commencement of prosecution and before conviction, the prosecuting attorney may, by written agreement with the defendant, filed with the court, and upon approval of the court, divert a defendant to a non-criminal diversion program.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(2): A defendant shall be represented by counsel during negotiations for diversion and at the time of execution of any diversion agreement unless the defendant has knowingly and intelligently waived the defendant's right to counsel.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(3): The defendant has the right to be represented by counsel at any court hearing relating to a diversion program.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(4)(a): A diversion agreement, entered into between the prosecuting attorney and the defendant and approved by a court, shall contain a full, detailed statement of the requirements agreed to by the defendant and the reasons for diversion.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(4)(b): The diversion agreement described in Subsection (4)(a) shall include an agreement, by the parties, for a specific amount of restitution that the defendant will pay, unless the prosecuting attorney certifies that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(4)(b)(i): the prosecuting attorney has consulted with all victims, including the Utah Office for Victims of Crime; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(4)(b)(ii): the defendant does not owe any restitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(5)(a): If the court approves a diversion agreement that includes an agreement by the parties for the amount of restitution that the defendant will pay, the court shall order the defendant to pay restitution in accordance with the terms of the diversion agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(5)(b): The court shall collect, receive, process, and distribute payments for restitution to the victim, unless otherwise provided by law or by the diversion agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(6): A decision by a prosecuting attorney not to divert a defendant is not subject to judicial review.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(7): 78A-5-110; 78A-7-120 A diversion agreement entered into between the prosecution and the defense and approved by a magistrate may contain an order that the defendant pay a nonrefundable diversion fee that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(7)(a): 78A-5-110; 78A-7-120 shall be allocated in the same manner as if paid as a fine for a criminal conviction under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(7)(b): may not exceed the suggested fine listed in the Uniform Fine Schedule adopted by the Judicial Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(8): A diversion agreement may not be approved unless the defendant knowingly and intelligently waives the defendant's constitutional right to a speedy trial before a magistrate and in the diversion agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(9)(a): The court shall, on the defendant's request, consider the defendant's ability to pay a diversion fee before ordering the defendant to pay a diversion fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(9)(b): The court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(9)(b)(i): consider any relevant evidence in determining the defendant's ability to pay a diversion fee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(9)(b)(ii): lower or waive the diversion fee based on that evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(10): A diversion program longer than two years is not permitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-5(11): The court may not rely solely on an algorithm or a risk assessment tool score in determining whether the court should approve the defendant's diversion to a non-criminal diversion program.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-6 Dismissal after compliance with diversion agreement.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The court shall dismiss the information or indictment filed against the defendant who has complied with the requirements of his diversion agreement and the defendant shall not thereafter be subject to further prosecution for the offense involved or for any lesser included offense.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-7 Diversion not a conviction.
--------------------------------------------------------
Diversion is not a conviction and if the case is dismissed the matter shall be treated as if the charge had never been filed.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-8 Violation of diversion agreement -- Hearing -- Prosecution resumed.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If, during the course of the diversion of a defendant, information is brought to the attention of a magistrate or the prosecuting attorney that the defendant has violated his diversion agreement and it appears in the best interests of the community to reinstate and proceed with the prosecution, the prosecuting attorney, upon court approval, or the magistrate, on his own motion, shall cause to be served upon the defendant an order to show cause specifying the facts relied upon by the prosecuting attorney or magistrate to terminate diversion and shall set a time and place for a hearing to determine whether or not the defendant has violated his diversion agreement. If, at the hearing, the magistrate finds the defendant has failed to comply with any terms or conditions of the diversion agreement, he may authorize the prosecuting attorney to proceed with prosecution.  The prosecution of a diverted offense shall not bar any independent prosecution arising from any offense that constituted a violation of any term or condition of the diversion agreement by which the original prosecution was diverted.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9 Offenses ineligible for diversion.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(1): 76-5-205; 76-5-206; 77-36-1 A magistrate may not grant a diversion for:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(1)(a): a capital felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(1)(b): a felony in the first degree;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(1)(c): any case involving a sexual offense against a victim who is under 14 years old;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(1)(d): any motor vehicle related offense involving alcohol or drugs;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(1)(e): any case involving using a motor vehicle in the commission of a felony;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(1)(f): driving a motor vehicle or commercial motor vehicle on a revoked or suspended license;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(1)(g): 76-5-205; 76-5-206 any case involving operating a commercial motor vehicle in a negligent manner causing the death of another including the offenses of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(1)(g)(i): 76-5-205 manslaughter under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(1)(g)(ii): 76-5-206 negligent homicide under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(1)(h): 77-36-1 a crime of domestic violence as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(2): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses; 80-6-502; 80-6-504 When an individual is alleged to have committed any violation of
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(2)(a): 80-6-502; 80-6-504 the offenses could have been adjudicated in juvenile court but for the delayed reporting or delayed filing of the information in the district court, unless the offenses are before the court in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(2)(b): the individual did not use coercion or force;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(2)(c): there is no more than three years' difference between the ages of the participants; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2-9(2)(d): it would be in the best interest of the person to grant diversion.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 2a - Pleas in Abeyance
***************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-1 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-1(1): 77-38b-102 "Criminal conduct" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-1(2): 77-38b-102 "Pecuniary damages" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-1(3): "Plea in abeyance" means an order by a court, upon motion of the prosecuting attorney and the defendant, accepting a plea of guilty or of no contest from the defendant but not, at that time, entering judgment of conviction against the defendant nor imposing sentence upon the defendant on condition that the defendant comply with specific conditions as set forth in a plea in abeyance agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-1(4): "Plea in abeyance agreement" means an agreement entered into between the prosecuting attorney and the defendant setting forth the specific terms and conditions upon which, following acceptance of the agreement by the court, a plea may be held in abeyance.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-1(5): 77-38b-102 "Restitution" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-1(6): 77-38b-102 "Victim" means the same as that term is defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2 Plea in abeyance agreement -- Negotiation -- Contents -- Terms of agreement -- Waiver of time for sentencing.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(1): At any time after acceptance of a plea of guilty or no contest but before entry of judgment of conviction and imposition of sentence, the court may, upon motion of both the prosecuting attorney and the defendant, hold the plea in abeyance and not enter judgment of conviction against the defendant nor impose sentence upon the defendant within the time periods contained in Rule 22(a), Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(2): A defendant shall be represented by counsel during negotiations for a plea in abeyance and at the time of acknowledgment and affirmation of any plea in abeyance agreement unless the defendant knowingly and intelligently waives the defendant's right to counsel.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(3): A defendant has the right to be represented by counsel at any court hearing relating to a plea in abeyance agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(4)(a): Any plea in abeyance agreement entered into between the prosecution and the defendant and approved by the court shall include a full, detailed recitation of the requirements and conditions agreed to by the defendant and the reason for requesting the court to hold the plea in abeyance.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(4)(b): If the plea is to a felony or any combination of misdemeanors and felonies, the agreement shall be in writing and shall, before acceptance by the court, be executed by the prosecuting attorney, the defendant, and the defendant's counsel in the presence of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(5): 63M-7-401.1
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(5)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (5)(b), a plea may not be held in abeyance for a period longer than 18 months if the plea is to any class of misdemeanor or longer than three years if the plea is to any degree of felony or to any combination of misdemeanors and felonies.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(5)(b): 63M-7-401.1
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(5)(b)(i): 63M-7-401.1 For a plea in abeyance agreement that the Department of Corrections supervises, the plea may not be held in abeyance for a period longer than the initial term of probation required under the adult sentencing and supervision length guidelines, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(5)(b)(ii): Subsection (5)(b)(i) does not:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(5)(b)(ii)(A): apply to a plea that is held in abeyance in a drug court created under Title 78A, Chapter 5, Part 2, Drug Court, or a problem solving court approved by the Judicial Council; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(5)(b)(ii)(B): prohibit court supervision of a plea in abeyance agreement after the day on which the Department of Corrections supervision described in Subsection (5)(b)(i) ends and before the day on which the plea in abeyance agreement ends.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(6): Notwithstanding Subsection (5), a plea may be held in abeyance for up to two years if the plea is to any class of misdemeanor and the plea in abeyance agreement includes a condition that the defendant participate in a problem solving court approved by the Judicial Council.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-2(7): A plea in abeyance agreement may not be approved unless the defendant, before the court, and any written agreement, knowingly and intelligently waives time for sentencing as designated in Rule 22(a), Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3 Manner of entry of plea -- Powers of court -- Expungement.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(1)(a): Acceptance of any plea in anticipation of a plea in abeyance agreement shall be done in full compliance with the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure, Rule 11.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(1)(b): In cases charging offenses for which bail may be forfeited, a plea in abeyance agreement may be entered into without a personal appearance before a magistrate.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(2): A plea in abeyance agreement may provide that the court may, upon finding that the defendant has successfully completed the terms of the agreement:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(2)(a): reduce the degree of the offense, enter a judgment of conviction for the lower degree of the offense, and impose a sentence for the lower degree of the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(2)(b): allow withdrawal of the defendant's plea and order the dismissal of the case; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(2)(c): issue an order of expungement for all records of the offense if:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(2)(c)(ii): the court allows the withdrawal of the defendant's plea and orders the dismissal of the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(3): 76-3-402

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(3)(a)(ii): allow withdrawal of the defendant's plea and order the dismissal of the case; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(3)(a)(iii): issue an order of expungement for all records of the offense if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(3)(a)(iii)(A): the defendant successfully completes a problem solving court program that is certified by the Judicial Council; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(3)(a)(iii)(B): the court allows the withdrawal of the defendant's plea and orders the dismissal of the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(3)(b): 76-3-402 Upon sentencing a defendant for any lesser offense in accordance with a plea in abeyance agreement, the court may not invoke Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(5)(c): an order that the defendant comply with any other conditions that could have been imposed as conditions of probation upon conviction and sentencing for the same offense.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(6)(a)(i): a specific amount of restitution that the defendant will pay, as agreed to by the defendant and the prosecuting attorney;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(6)(a)(ii): a certification from the prosecuting attorney that:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(6)(a)(ii)(B): all victims, including the Utah Office for Victims of Crime, are not seeking restitution; or

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(6)(b): At a subsequent hearing described in Subsection (6)(a)(iii), the court shall order the defendant, as a modified term of the plea in abeyance, to pay restitution to all victims for the entire amount of pecuniary damages that are proximately caused by the criminal conduct of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(6)(c): The court shall collect, receive, process, and distribute payments for restitution to the victim, unless otherwise provided by law or by the plea in abeyance agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-3(6)(d): If the defendant does not successfully complete the terms of the plea in abeyance, the court shall enter an order for restitution, in accordance with Chapter 38b, Crime Victims Restitution Act, upon entering a sentence for the defendant.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-4 Violation of plea in abeyance agreement -- Hearing -- Entry of judgment and imposition of sentence -- Subsequent prosecutions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-4(1): If, at any time during the term of the plea in abeyance agreement, information comes to the attention of the prosecuting attorney or the court that the defendant has violated any condition of the agreement, the court, at the request of the prosecuting attorney, made by appropriate motion and affidavit, or upon its own motion, may issue an order requiring the defendant to appear before the court at a designated time and place to show cause why the court should not find the terms of the agreement to have been violated and why the agreement should not be terminated.  If, following an evidentiary hearing, the court finds that the defendant has failed to substantially comply with any term or condition of the plea in abeyance agreement, it may terminate the agreement and enter judgment of conviction and impose sentence against the defendant for the offense to which the original plea was entered. Upon entry of judgment of conviction and imposition of sentence, any amounts paid by the defendant as a plea in abeyance fee prior to termination of the agreement shall be credited against any fine imposed by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-2a-4(2): The termination of a plea in abeyance agreement and subsequent entry of judgment of conviction and imposition of sentence shall not bar any independent prosecution arising from any offense that constituted a violation of any term or condition of an agreement whereby the original plea was placed in abeyance.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 3 - Security to Keep the Peace
***********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-1 Threatened offense -- Complaint.
-------------------------------------------------------------
A complaint that a person has threatened to commit an offense against the person or property of another, except in the case of stalking, may be made before any magistrate.  Petitions alleging the commission of stalking shall be handled pursuant to

Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-2 Examination of complainant and witnesses.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
The magistrate shall examine, on oath, the complainant and any witnesses he may produce and may take their testimony in writing.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-3 "Complaint" defined.
-------------------------------------------------
A complaint, within the meaning of this chapter, is a statement in writing setting forth the jurisdictional facts, specifying the threatened offense, and subscribed and sworn to by the complainant before the magistrate.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-4 Warrant of arrest -- Temporary restraining order.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the magistrate believes there is reasonable ground to fear the commission of the offense threatened, he may:Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-4(1): Issue a warrant directed generally to any peace officer, reciting the substance of the complaint and commanding the officer to immediately arrest the person complained of and bring him before the magistrate or in the case of his absence or inability to act before the nearest and most accessible magistrate of the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-4(2): Issue a temporary restraining order against the commission of the offense and order the person complained of to immediately appear before the magistrate for a hearing.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-5 Defendant taken before different magistrate -- Procedure.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When the person arrested is taken before a magistrate other than the one who issued the warrant, the peace officer who executed the warrant shall deliver it to the issuing magistrate with his endorsed return. The complaint and written testimony, if any, on which the warrant was issued shall be sent to the magistrate before whom the person arrested is taken.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-6 Change of venue.
---------------------------------------------
When the person complained of is brought before the magistrate, a change of venue may be had for good cause shown.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-7 Hearing -- Evidence -- Record.
-----------------------------------------------------------
At the time set for hearing, the magistrate shall take evidence. The hearing may be recorded or reduced to writing.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-8 Findings and orders -- Discharge -- Undertaking -- Commitment.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-8(1): If it appears there is no reasonable ground to fear the commission of the offense alleged to have been threatened, the person complained of shall be discharged. The complainant may be ordered to pay the costs of the proceedings if the magistrate believes the complaint was unfounded and frivolous.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-8(2): If there is reasonable ground to fear the commission of an offense, the court may, in addition or as an alternative to other relief, enter an order permanently restraining the person from engaging in illegal conduct or acting in any manner that could result in illegal conduct or the person complained of may be required to enter into an undertaking in a sum not to exceed $3,000, with one or more sufficient sureties, to keep the peace toward the people of this state and particularly toward the persons endangered. The conditions of the undertaking shall be in writing and shall be for a period of six months. It may be extended on good cause shown for a longer period or enlarged and a new undertaking may be required.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-8(2)(a): If the undertaking is given, the party complained of shall be discharged.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-8(2)(b): If the undertaking is not given, the magistrate shall commit the defendant to jail specifying in the warrant of commitment the requirement to give security, the amount thereof, and the effective period of time.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-8(2)(c): A person committed for not giving the required undertaking may be discharged by any magistrate when he provides the undertaking.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-9 Filing undertaking with district court clerk.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
An undertaking shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the district court.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-10 Assault in presence of magistrate or court.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person who, in the presence of the court or magistrate, assaults or threatens to assault another or to commit an offense against person or property, or who contends with another with threatening words, may be ordered by the court or magistrate to give security and if he refuses to do so, may be committed as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-11 Undertaking, when broken -- Prosecution.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-11(1): The undertaking is broken if the person posting the bond violates the conditions set by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-11(2): If the undertaking is broken and the county attorney produces evidence of the violation to the district court where the undertaking was filed, the court shall order an action on the undertaking to be commenced, and the county attorney shall commence an action in the name of the state against the principal sureties on the undertaking.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-12 Record of conviction conclusive evidence -- Judgment on undertaking.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In an action filed by the county attorney to recover on an undertaking:Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-12(1): The offense shall be alleged as a breach of the undertaking stated in a record of conviction and a record of conviction is conclusive evidence thereof.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-3-12(2): If the court finds the offense constitutes a breach of the undertaking, judgment for the amount of the undertaking shall be entered against the parties liable.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 4 - Pleadings and Proceedings Before Trial
***********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-101 Force by officer -- Arrest.
----------------------------------------------------------
A public officer authorized to execute process issued by any court may use such force as is reasonable and necessary to execute service of process. If necessary, he may seize, arrest, and confine persons resisting or aiding and abetting resistance to his service of process.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201 Reproduction of child sexual abuse material -- Prohibition.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(1): 76-5b-103; 53-1-102; 77-37-2 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(1)(a): 76-5b-103 "Child sexual abuse material" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(1)(b): 53-1-102 "Law enforcement agency" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(1)(c): 77-37-2 "Victim" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(2): In a proceeding involving child sexual abuse material, the child sexual abuse material shall remain in the care, custody, and control of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(2)(a): a law enforcement agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(2)(b): a court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(3)(a): In a proceeding involving child sexual abuse material, a court shall deny a request by a defendant to copy, photograph, duplicate, or otherwise reproduce the child sexual abuse material if the court or a law enforcement agency provides the defendant's attorney or an individual the defendant may seek to qualify as an expert an adequate opportunity to view and examine the child sexual abuse material.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(3)(b): (3)(a) An individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(3)(c): A defendant who is self represented:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(3)(c)(i): may not inspect the child sexual abuse material; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(3)(c)(ii): may request that the court appoint counsel for the purpose of inspecting the child sexual abuse material on behalf of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(4): (4)(a); (4)(a); (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(4)(a): In a proceeding involving child sexual abuse material, a victim, the victim's attorney, or an individual the victim may, upon a showing of good cause, seek to qualify as an expert, may view and examine the child sexual abuse material that depicts the victim upon a showing of good cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(4)(b): (4)(a) An individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(4)(c): (4)(a) An individual described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-4-201(4)(d): (4) The court or law enforcement agency may redact the child sexual abuse material described in this Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 5 - Impeachments
*********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-1 Officers liable to impeachment.
------------------------------------------------------------
The governor and other state and judicial officers shall be liable to impeachment for high crimes and misdemeanors or malfeasance in office.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-2 Chief justice to preside, when.
------------------------------------------------------------
When the governor is on trial, the chief justice of the Supreme Court shall preside, and, in case he is disqualified or unable to act, the Senate shall select some other justice of the Supreme Court to preside.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-3 Two-thirds vote of House required.
---------------------------------------------------------------
The House of Representatives shall have the sole power of impeachment, but in order to impeach, two-thirds of all the members elected shall vote therefor. Impeachments shall be by resolution. The resolution shall originate in and be adopted by the House of Representatives.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-4 Trial by Senate.
---------------------------------------------
All impeachments shall be tried by the Senate sitting for that purpose.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-5 Hearing, notice of -- Defendant served with articles.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The Senate shall assign a day for the hearing of the impeachment and inform the House of Representatives. The president of the Senate shall cause a copy of the articles of impeachment, with a notice to appear and answer the same at the time and place appointed, to be served on the officer being impeached not less than 10 days before the day fixed for the hearing.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-6 Suspension on filing articles -- Vacancy, how filled.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When articles of impeachment are presented to the Senate, and the officer has been served with a copy of the articles, the officer shall be temporarily suspended from office and may not exercise the duties of the office until the officer is acquitted.  Upon the suspension of any officer, other than the governor, or a justice or judge of a court of record, the office shall be temporarily filled by an appointment made by the governor, with the advice and consent of the Senate, until the acquittal of the party impeached, or, in the case of the officer's removal, until the vacancy is filled at the next election as provided by law.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-7 Senators to be sworn -- Two-thirds required for proceedings.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
At the time and place appointed, and before the Senate proceeds to act on the impeachment, the secretary shall administer to the president of the Senate, and the president of the Senate shall administer to each of the members of the Senate then present, an oath or affirmation to do justice according to law and the evidence and no member of the Senate shall act or vote on the impeachment, or any question arising on it without taking the oath or affirmation and being present during the proceedings. No proceedings shall be conducted unless at least two-thirds of the senators elected and entitled to vote are present.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-8 Two-thirds vote necessary for conviction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
The officer shall not be convicted on impeachment without the concurrence of two-thirds of the senators elected, voting by ayes and nays, and if two-thirds of the senators elected do not concur in a conviction, he shall be acquitted.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-9 Nature of judgment.
------------------------------------------------
The judgment may be that the officer be suspended, or removed from office and disqualified to hold any office of honor, trust, or profit in the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-10 Effect of judgment.
-------------------------------------------------
If judgment of suspension is given, the officer, during the continuance thereof, is disqualified from receiving the salary, fees, or emoluments of the office.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-11 Impeachment not a bar to prosecution.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The officer, whether convicted or acquitted, shall nevertheless be liable to prosecution, trial, and punishment according to law for any offense committed that constituted a basis for the impeachment proceedings.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-5-12 Rules of procedure.
-------------------------------------------------
The procedure for impeachment proceedings shall be adopted by rule in each house and such rules shall govern.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 6 - Removal by Judicial Proceedings
****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-1 Officers subject to removal.
---------------------------------------------------------
All officers of any city, county, or other political subdivision of this state not liable to impeachment shall be subject to removal as provided in this chapter for high crimes and misdemeanors or malfeasance in office.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-2 Commencement of action for removal.
----------------------------------------------------------------
An action for the removal of a justice court judge or officer of a city, county, or other political subdivision of this state shall be commenced by presenting a sworn, written accusation to the district court.  The accusation may be initiated by any taxpayer, grand jury, county attorney, or district attorney for the county in which the officer was elected or appointed, or by the attorney general.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-3 Form of accusation.
------------------------------------------------
The accusation shall state the grounds for removal in ordinary and concise language.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-4 Presentation of accusation -- Service on defendant.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-4(1): When the accusation is initiated by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-4(1)(a): a grand jury, the foreperson shall present the accusation to the court in the presence of the grand jurors which shall be filed with the clerk; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-4(1)(b): a taxpayer, the county attorney, district attorney, or the attorney general, any of these persons shall present the accusation to the presiding judge of the district court for filing with the clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-4(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-4(2)(a): Except when the accusation is initiated by the county attorney or district attorney, the court shall furnish a copy of the accusation to the county attorney or, if within a prosecution district, the district attorney who shall investigate and may prosecute the accusation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-4(2)(b): If the accusation is against the county or district attorney, the court shall furnish a copy of the accusation to the Office of the Attorney General, who shall investigate and may prosecute the accusation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-4(2)(c): If prosecution is pursued, the county attorney, district attorney, or attorney general shall serve a copy of the accusation on the defendant with a summons which requires the defendant to appear before the district court of the county in which the county attorney or district attorney serves and to answer the accusation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-4(3): The time fixed for appearance may not be less than 10 days from the date of service of summons.  The service of the accusation, summons, and the return of service shall be made in the manner provided by law for service of civil process.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-5 Appearance -- Procedure on default.
----------------------------------------------------------------
The defendant shall appear at the time appointed and answer the accusation, unless for some sufficient cause the court assigns another time for that purpose. If he does not appear, the court may proceed to hear and determine the accusation in his absence.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-6 Answer -- Objections for insufficiency.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The defendant may orally answer the accusation either by admitting or denying it in open court, or he may, in writing, object to the legal sufficiency of the accusation. If the objection to the sufficiency of the accusation is sustained, the accusation shall be dismissed. If the objection is overruled, the defendant shall immediately admit or deny the accusation.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-7 Trial on denial or refusal to answer -- Procedure.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the defendant denies the accusation or refuses to answer or appear, the court shall proceed to try the accusation. The rights of the parties and procedures used shall be the same as in any civil proceeding.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-8 Judgment of removal -- Service on defendant.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the defendant admits the accusation or is convicted, the court shall enter judgment against him directing the defendant be removed from office and setting forth the causes of removal. The judgment of removal shall immediately be served upon the defendant.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-6-9 Appeal -- Suspension from office.
--------------------------------------------------------------
From a judgment of removal an appeal may be taken to the Supreme Court in the same manner as from a judgment in a civil action; but from entry of judgment and until the judgment is reversed, the defendant shall be suspended from his office. Pending the appeal, the office shall be filled as in the case of a vacancy.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 7 - Arrest, by Whom, and How Made
**************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-1 "Arrest" defined -- Restraint allowed.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
An arrest is an actual restraint of the person arrested or submission to custody. The person shall not be subjected to any more restraint than is necessary for his arrest and detention.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2 Arrest by peace officers.
------------------------------------------------------
A peace officer may make an arrest under authority of a warrant or may, without warrant, arrest a person:Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(1): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(1)(a): for any public offense committed or attempted in the presence of any peace officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(1)(b): (1) as used in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(2): when the peace officer has reasonable cause to believe a felony or a class A misdemeanor has been committed and has reasonable cause to believe that the person arrested has committed it;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(3): when the peace officer has reasonable cause to believe the person has committed a public offense, and there is reasonable cause for believing the person may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(3)(a): flee or conceal himself to avoid arrest;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(3)(b): destroy or conceal evidence of the commission of the offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(3)(c): injure another person or damage property belonging to another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(4): 76-8-301.5 when the peace officer has reasonable cause to believe the person has committed the offense of failure to disclose identity under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(5): when the peace officer has reasonable cause to believe that the person is an alien:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(5)(a): subject to a civil removal order issued by an immigration judge;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(5)(b): regarding whom a civil detainer warrant has been issued by the federal Department of Homeland Security; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-2(5)(c): who has been charged or convicted in another state with one or more aggravated felonies as defined by 8 U.S.C. Sec. 1101(a)(43).


Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-3 By private persons.
------------------------------------------------
A private person may arrest another:Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-3(1): For a public offense committed or attempted in his presence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-3(2): When a felony has been committed and he has reasonable cause to believe the person arrested has committed it.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-4 Magistrate may orally order arrest.
----------------------------------------------------------------
A magistrate may orally require a peace officer to arrest anyone committing or attempting to commit a public offense in the presence of the magistrate, and, in the case of an emergency, when probable cause exists, a magistrate may orally authorize a peace officer to arrest a person for a public offense, and thereafter, as soon as practical, an information shall be filed against the person arrested.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5 Issuance of summons or warrant -- Time and place arrests may be made -- Contents of warrant or summons -- Responsibility for transporting prisoners.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(1)(a): "Daytime hours" means the hours after 6 a.m. and before 10 p.m.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(1)(b): "Nighttime hours" means the hours after 10 p.m. and before 6 a.m.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(2): A magistrate may issue a warrant for arrest in lieu of a summons for the appearance of the accused only upon finding:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(2)(a): probable cause to believe that the person to be arrested has committed a public offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(2)(b): under the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure, and this section that a warrant is necessary to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(2)(b)(i): prevent risk of injury to a person or property;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(2)(b)(ii): secure the appearance of the accused; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(2)(b)(iii): protect the public safety and welfare of the community or an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(3): If the offense charged is:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(3)(a): a felony, the arrest upon a warrant may be made at any time of the day or night; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(3)(b): a misdemeanor, the arrest upon a warrant may be made during nighttime hours only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(3)(b)(i): the magistrate has endorsed authorization to do so on the warrant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(3)(b)(ii): the person to be arrested is upon a public highway, in a public place, or in a place open to or accessible to the public; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(3)(b)(iii): the person to be arrested is encountered by a peace officer in the regular course of that peace officer's investigation of a criminal offense unrelated to the misdemeanor warrant for arrest.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(4): (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(4)(a): If the magistrate determines that the accused must appear in court, the magistrate shall include in the arrest warrant the name of the law enforcement agency in the county or municipality with jurisdiction over the offense charged.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(4)(b): (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(4)(b)(i): (4)(a) The law enforcement agency identified by the magistrate under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(4)(b)(ii): The law enforcement agency named on the warrant may contract with another law enforcement agency to have a defendant transported.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(5): (4)(a) The law enforcement agency identified by the magistrate under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-5(6): (4)(a) The law enforcement agency identified by the magistrate under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-6 Manner of making arrest.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-6(1): The person making the arrest shall inform the person being arrested of his intention, cause, and authority to arrest him.  Such notice shall not be required when:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-6(1)(a): there is reason to believe the notice will endanger the life or safety of the officer or another person or will likely enable the party being arrested to escape;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-6(1)(b): the person being arrested is actually engaged in the commission of, or an attempt to commit, an offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-6(1)(c): the person being arrested is pursued immediately after the commission of an offense or an escape.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-6(2): 78B-1-201(2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-6(2)(a): 78B-1-201(2) If a deaf or hard of hearing person, as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-6(2)(b): (2) Compliance with this Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-7 Force in making arrest.
----------------------------------------------------
If a person is being arrested and flees or forcibly resists after being informed of the intention to make the arrest, the person arresting may use reasonable force to effect the arrest. Deadly force may be used only as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8 Forcible entry to conduct search or make arrest -- Conditions requiring a warrant.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(1): 77-7-5; 77-7-5; 53-1-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(1)(a): 77-7-5 "Daytime hours" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(1)(b): "Forcibly enter" means entering any premises by force.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(1)(c): "Knock" means to knock with reasonably strong force in a quick succession of three or more contacts with a door or other point of entry into a building that would allow the occupant to reasonably hear the peace officer's demand for entry.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(1)(d): "Knock and announce warrant" means a lawful search warrant that authorizes entry into a building after knocking and demanding entry onto a premises described in Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(1)(e): 77-7-5 "Nighttime hours" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(1)(f): 53-1-102 "Peace officer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(1)(g): "Premises" means any building, room, conveyance, compartment, or other enclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(1)(h): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(1)(h)(i): "Supervisory official" means a command-level officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(1)(h)(ii): "Supervisory official" includes a sheriff, a head of a law enforcement agency, and a supervisory enforcement officer equivalent to a sergeant rank or higher.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(2)(a): Subject to the provisions of this Subsection (2), a peace officer when making a lawful arrest, or serving a knock and announce warrant, may forcibly enter a premises:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(2)(a)(i): if the individual to be arrested is located within the premises; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(2)(a)(ii): if there is probable cause to believe that the individual is located within the premises.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(2)(b)(i): Subject to Subsection (3), before forcibly entering a premises as described in Subsection (2)(a), a peace officer shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(2)(b)(i)(A): wear readily identifiable markings, including a badge and vest or clothing with a distinguishing label or other writing that identifies the individual as a law enforcement officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(2)(b)(i)(B): audibly identify himself or herself as a law enforcement officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(2)(b)(i)(C): knock and demand admission more than once;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(2)(b)(i)(D): wait a reasonable period of time for an occupant to admit access after knocking and demanding admission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(2)(b)(i)(E): explain the purpose for which admission is desired.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(3): 77-7-6; 77-7-8.1
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(3)(a): 77-7-6; 77-7-8.1 A peace officer does not need to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(3)(a)(i): 77-7-6; 77-7-8.1 comply with the requirements of Subsection (2)(b)(i)(B), (2)(b)(i)(C), (2)(b)(i)(D), and (2)(b)(i)(E) before forcibly entering a premises:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(3)(a)(i)(A): 77-7-6; 77-7-8.1 under the exceptions in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(3)(a)(i)(B): where there is probable cause to believe exigent circumstances exist due to the destruction of evidence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(3)(a)(i)(C): where there is reasonable suspicion to believe exigent circumstances exist due to the physical safety of a peace officer or individual inside or in near proximity to the premises; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(3)(a)(ii): comply with the requirements described in Subsections (2)(b)(i)(C) and (2)(b)(i)(D) before forcibly entering a premises if the officer, or another peace officer:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(3)(a)(ii)(A): has been near the premises for an extended amount of time and a reasonable person would conclude that an individual on the premises knows or should know that a peace officer is present;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(3)(a)(ii)(B): has demanded admission and announced an intent to enter the premises more than once; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(3)(a)(ii)(C): has complied with Subsections (2)(b)(i)(A), (2)(b)(i)(B), and (2)(b)(i)(E).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(3)(b): If a peace officer forcibly enters a premises under Subsection (3)(a)(i), the peace officer shall identify himself or herself and state the purpose for entering the premises as soon as practicable after entering the premises.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(4): The peace officer may use only that force that is reasonable and necessary to forcibly enter a premises under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(5): Subject to Subsection (6), if the premises to be entered under Subsection (2)(a) appears to be a private residence or the peace officer knows the premises is a private residence, and if there is no consent to enter or there are no exigent circumstances, the peace officer shall, before entering the premises:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(5)(a): obtain an arrest or search warrant if the premises is the residence of the individual to be arrested; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(5)(b): obtain a search warrant if the building is a private residence, but not the residence of the individual whose arrest is sought.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(6): Before seeking a warrant from a judge or magistrate under Subsection (2)(a), a supervisory official shall, using the peace officer's affidavit:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(6)(a): independently perform an assessment to evaluate the totality of the circumstances;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(6)(b): ensure reasonable intelligence gathering efforts have been made;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(6)(c): ensure a threat assessment was completed on the individual or premises to be searched; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(6)(d): determine either that there is a sufficient basis to support seeking a warrant or require that the peace officer continue evidence gathering efforts.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(7): 58-37-8; 58-37a-3 Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, a peace officer may not forcibly enter a premises based solely on:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(7)(a): 58-37-8 the alleged possession or use of a controlled substance under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8(7)(b): 58-37a-3 the alleged possession of drug paraphernalia as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1 Forcible entry to conduct a search -- Conditions requiring a warrant -- No-knock warrants.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(1): 77-7-5; 77-7-8; 77-7-5; 77-7-8; 53-1-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(1)(a): 77-7-5 "Daytime hours" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(1)(b): 77-7-8 "Forcibly enter" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(1)(c): 77-7-5 "Nighttime hours" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(1)(d): "No-knock warrant" means a lawful search warrant that authorizes entry onto a premises without notice to any occupant on the premises at the time of service.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(1)(e): 77-7-8 "Supervisory official" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(1)(f): 53-1-102 "Peace officer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(1)(g): "Premises" means any property, building, room, conveyance, compartment, or other enclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(2): Subject to the provisions of this section, a peace officer serving a lawful no-knock warrant may forcibly enter a premises to be searched without notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(3): Before seeking a no-knock warrant from a judge or magistrate under Subsection (2), a supervisory official shall, using the peace officer's affidavit:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(3)(a): independently perform an assessment to evaluate the totality of the circumstances;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(3)(b): ensure reasonable intelligence gathering efforts have been made;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(3)(c): ensure a threat assessment was completed on the individual or premises to be searched; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(3)(d): determine either that there is a sufficient basis to support seeking a warrant or require that the peace officer continue evidence gathering efforts.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(4)(a): The affidavit for a no-knock warrant shall describe:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(4)(a)(i): why the peace officer believes the suspect is unable to be detained or the residence searched using less invasive or less confrontational methods;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(4)(a)(ii): investigative activities that have been undertaken to ensure that the correct premises is identified and that potential harm to innocent third parties, the premises, and officers may be minimized; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(4)(a)(iii): the present or imminent threat of serious bodily injury or death to an individual inside, outside, or in near proximity to the premises.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(4)(b): A peace officer shall serve a no-knock warrant during daytime hours unless a peace officer's affidavit states sufficient grounds to believe a search is necessary during nighttime hours.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(5): An officer shall wear readily identifiable markings when serving a no-knock warrant, including a badge and vest or clothing with a distinguishing label or other writing that shows that the individual is a peace officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-8.1(6): Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, a peace officer may not request a no-knock warrant if the warrant is solely for a misdemeanor investigation.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-9 Weapons may be taken from prisoner.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Any person making an arrest may seize from the person arrested all weapons which he may have on or about his person.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-10 Telegraph or telephone authorization of execution of arrest warrant.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any magistrate may, by an endorsement on a warrant of arrest, authorize by telegraph, telephone or other reasonable means, its execution. A copy of the warrant or notice of its issuance and terms may be sent to one or more peace officers. The copy or notice communicated authorizes the officer to proceed in the same manner under it as if he had an original warrant.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-11 Possession of warrant by arresting officer not required.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any peace officer who has knowledge of an outstanding warrant of arrest may arrest a person he reasonably believes to be the person described in the warrant, without the peace officer having physical possession of the warrant.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-12 Detaining persons suspected of shoplifting or library theft -- Persons authorized.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-12(1): A peace officer, merchant, or merchant's employee, servant, or agent who has reasonable grounds to believe that goods held or displayed for sale by the merchant have been taken by a person with intent to steal may, for the purpose of investigating the unlawful act and attempting to effect a recovery of the goods, detain the person in a reasonable manner for a reasonable length of time.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-12(2): (1); Title 76, Chapter 6, Part 8, Library Theft A peace officer or employee of a library may detain a person for the purposes and under the limits of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-15 Authority of peace officer to stop and question suspect -- Grounds.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A peace officer may stop any individual in a public place when the officer has a reasonable suspicion to believe the individual has committed or is in the act of committing or is attempting to commit a public offense and may demand the individual's name, address, date of birth, and an explanation of the individual's actions.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-16 Authority of peace officer to frisk suspect for dangerous weapon -- Grounds.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A peace officer who has stopped a person temporarily for questioning may frisk the person for a dangerous weapon if he reasonably believes he or any other person is in danger.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17 Authority of peace officer to take possession of weapons.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A peace officer who finds a dangerous weapon pursuant to a frisk may take and keep it until the completion of the questioning, at which time he shall either return it if lawfully possessed, or arrest such person.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5 Physical body cavity search policy -- Requirements.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(1)(a): "Arrestee" means an individual who is in the custody of law enforcement for an offense for which the individual has not been convicted.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(1)(b)(i): "Body cavity" includes the anus, rectum, vagina, esophagus, or stomach.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(1)(b)(ii): "Body cavity" does not include the mouth, ear canal, or nasal passages.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(1)(c)(i): "Physical body cavity search" means a search of a body cavity of an individual that involves touching the individual with:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(1)(c)(i)(A): any part of another individual's body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(1)(c)(i)(B): an instrument or other item.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(1)(c)(ii): "Physical body cavity search" does not include a clothed, pat down search.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(2): Each county jail shall adopt and implement a policy that meets the minimum standards contained in a model policy established by the Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3): The model policy shall specify the minimum standards and procedures to be followed by the county jail when a body cavity search is performed on an arrestee within the county jail's jurisdiction, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(a): stating with specificity the circumstances under which a body cavity search may be performed on an arrestee;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(b): designating who may authorize the performance of a body cavity search;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(c): designating specific jail staff or medical personnel who may perform a body cavity search;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(d): requiring any nonmedically trained jail staff who may perform a body cavity search to be trained on safe practices for conducting a body cavity search;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(e): requiring documentation of each body cavity search performed at the correctional facility, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(e)(i): the identity of the arrestee searched;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(e)(ii): the date, time, and location of the search;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(e)(iii): the identity of the individual performing the search;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(e)(iv): the identity of the individual authorizing the search;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(e)(v): a description of the body areas searched and the procedures followed in performing the search; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(e)(vi): the circumstances necessitating the body cavity search; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(f): designating rules and procedures to be followed, by authorized staff, when performing a body cavity search that account for the health and privacy interests of the arrestee, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(f)(i): the location where a body cavity search must be performed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(f)(ii): the gender requirements of the individuals who perform or observe the search in relation to the gender of the arrestee being searched; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(3)(f)(iii): methods to ensure the body cavity search is conducted with the minimal amount of touching necessary to effectuate the purposes of the search.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-7-17.5(4): A county jail's body cavity search policy is a public record.
