Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-302 Return of seized property to claimant by surety bond or cash.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-302(1): Except as provided in Subsection (2), a claimant may obtain the return of seized property by posting a surety bond or cash with the court that is in an amount equal to the current fair market value of the property as determined by the court or a stipulation by the parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-302(2): 77-11b-102 A court may refuse to order the return of property under Subsection (1) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-302(2)(a): the bond tendered for the property is inadequate;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-302(2)(b): the property is subject to the retention or preservation requirements under Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-302(2)(c): 77-11b-102 the property is particularly altered or designed for use in the commission of the offense subjecting the property to forfeiture under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-302(2)(d): the property is contraband.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-302(3): If a surety bond or cash is posted and the court later determines that the property is forfeited, the court shall order the forfeiture of the surety bond or cash in lieu of the property.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303 Return of seized property subject to forfeiture to claimant for hardship.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1): 77-11b-201 A claimant is entitled to the immediate return of seized property for which the agency has filed a notice of intent to forfeit under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1)(a): the claimant had a possessory interest in the property at the time of seizure;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1)(b): continued possession by the agency pending a forfeiture proceeding will cause substantial hardship to the claimant, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1)(b)(i): preventing the functioning of a legitimate business;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1)(b)(ii): preventing any individual from working;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1)(b)(iii): preventing any child from attending elementary or secondary school;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1)(b)(iv): preventing or hindering an individual from receiving necessary medical care;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1)(b)(v): preventing the care of a dependent child or adult who is elderly or disabled;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1)(b)(vi): leaving an individual homeless; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1)(b)(vii): any other condition that the court determines causes a substantial hardship;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1)(c): the hardship from the continued possession of the property by the agency outweighs the risk that the property will be destroyed, damaged, lost, concealed, or transferred if the property is returned to the claimant during the pendency of the proceeding; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(1)(d): the determination of substantial hardship under this Subsection (1) is based upon the property's use before the seizure.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(2): 77-11a-102 A claimant may file a motion or petition for hardship release under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(2)(a): in the court in which forfeiture proceedings have commenced; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(2)(b): 77-11a-102 in a district court where there is venue under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(3): The motion or petition for hardship release shall be served upon the agency with custody of the property within five days after the day on which the motion or petition is filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(4): The court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(4)(a): schedule a hearing on the motion or petition within 14 days after the day on which the motion or petition is filed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(4)(b): render a decision on a motion or petition for hardship filed under this section no later than 20 days after the day of the hearing, unless this period is extended by the agreement of both parties or by the court for good cause shown.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(5): If the claimant demonstrates substantial hardship under Subsection (1), the court shall order the agency to immediately return the property to the claimant pending completion of any forfeiture proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(6): The court may place conditions on the return of the property as the court finds necessary and appropriate to preserve the availability of the property or the property's equivalent for forfeiture.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(7): The hardship release under this section does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(7)(a): contraband;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(7)(b): property that is subject to the retention or preservation requirements under Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-303(7)(c): property that is likely to be used to commit additional offenses if returned to the claimant.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-304 Release of seized property to innocent owner or interest holder.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-304(1): Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence; 77-11b-302; (1)(a); (1)(b); (1)(a)(ii); (1)(a)(ii); 77-11b-302; (1)(a)(ii); (1)(d)(i); (1)(d)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-304(1)(a): Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence; 77-11b-302 Except for property required to be retained or preserved under
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-304(1)(a)(i): 77-11b-302 submitting a written request with the seizing agency before the later of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-304(1)(a)(i)(A): 77-11b-302 the commencement of a civil forfeiture proceeding under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-304(1)(a)(i)(B): 30 days after the day on which the property was seized; and

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305 Release of seized property to claimant when seized property is retained as evidence.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(1): 77-11a-102

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(1)(b): 77-11a-102 The claimant may file the petition in:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(1)(b)(i): the court in which criminal proceedings have commenced regarding the offense for which the property is being retained as evidence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(1)(b)(ii): 77-11a-102 the district court with venue under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(1)(c): A claimant shall serve a copy of the petition on the prosecuting attorney or federal prosecutor and the agency with custody of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(2)(a): The court shall provide an opportunity for an expedited hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(2)(b): After the opportunity for an expedited hearing, the court may order that the property is:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(2)(b)(i): returned to the claimant if the claimant is the owner as determined by the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(2)(b)(ii): if the offense subjecting the property to seizure results in a conviction, applied directly or by proceeds of the sale of the property toward restitution, fines, or fees owed by the claimant in an amount set by the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(2)(b)(iii): converted to a public interest use;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(2)(b)(iv): held for further legal action;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(2)(b)(v): sold at public auction and the proceeds of the sale applied to a public interest use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(2)(b)(vi): destroyed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(3): Before the court can order property be returned to a claimant, the claimant shall establish, by clear and convincing evidence, that the claimant:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(3)(a): is the owner of the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(3)(b): may lawfully possess the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11a-305(4): If the court orders the property to be returned to the claimant, the agency with custody of the property shall return the property to the claimant as expeditiously as possible.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-103 Trial by jury.
-----------------------------------------------
The right to trial by jury applies to forfeiture proceedings under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-302(11): 77-11b-102(1) A civil forfeiture action under this section may be converted to a criminal forfeiture action at any time after a prosecuting attorney files a criminal complaint, information, or indictment for the offense subjecting the property to forfeiture under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303 Proportionality of forfeiture.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(1)(a): A claimant's interest in property that is used to facilitate an offense may not be forfeited under any provision of state law if the forfeiture is substantially disproportionate to the use of the property in committing or facilitating an offense that is a violation of state law and the value of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(1)(b): If property is used solely in a manner that is merely incidental and not instrumental to the commission or facilitation of an offense, a forfeiture of the property is not proportional.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(2): 77-11b-102(1)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(2)(a): 77-11b-102(1) In determining proportionality, the court shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(2)(a)(i): 77-11b-102(1) the offense subjecting the property to forfeiture under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(2)(a)(ii): what portion of the forfeiture, if any, is remedial in nature;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(2)(a)(iii): the gravity of the conduct for which the claimant is responsible in light of the offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(2)(a)(iv): the value of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(2)(b): If the court finds that the forfeiture is substantially disproportional to an offense for which the claimant is responsible, the court shall reduce or eliminate the forfeiture as the court finds appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(3): 77-11b-102(1) A prosecuting attorney has the burden of demonstrating that a forfeiture is proportional to the offense subjecting the property to forfeiture under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(4): In all cases, the court shall decide questions of proportionality.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-303(5): A forfeiture of any proceeds used to facilitate the commission of an offense that is a violation of federal or state law is proportional.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-304 Postjudgment interest to prevailing party in forfeiture proceeding.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In a proceeding to forfeit currency or other negotiable instruments under this chapter, the court shall award postjudgment interest to a prevailing party on the currency or negotiable instruments at the interest rate established under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-305 Attorney fees and costs for forfeiture proceeding.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-305(1): In a forfeiture proceeding under this chapter, a court shall award reasonable legal costs and attorney fees to a prevailing claimant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-305(2): (1) If a court awards legal costs and attorney fees to a prevailing claimant under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-305(3): A  claimant who prevails only in part is entitled to recover reasonable legal costs and attorney fees only on an issue on which the party prevailed.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-306 Limitation on fees for holding seized property subject to forfeiture.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In any civil or criminal proceeding under this part in which a judgment is entered in favor of a claimant, or where a forfeiture proceeding against a claimant is voluntarily dismissed by the prosecuting attorney, an agency may not charge a claimant any fee or cost for holding seized property.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-401(1): If a court finds that property is forfeited under this chapter, the court shall order the property forfeited to the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-401(2)(a): If the property is not currency, the agency shall authorize a public or otherwise commercially reasonable sale of that property if the property is not required by law to be destroyed and is not harmful to the public.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-401(2)(b)(i)(B): otherwise in saleable condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-401(2)(b)(ii): an alcoholic product and the alcoholic product's package shall be destroyed if the alcoholic product is impure, adulterated, or otherwise unfit for sale.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-401(2)(d): The proceeds of the sale of forfeited property shall remain segregated from other property, equipment, or assets of the agency until transferred in accordance with this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403 State Asset Forfeiture Grant Program.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(1): There is created the State Asset Forfeiture Grant Program.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(2): 63M-7-502; Title 63M, Chapter 7, Part 5, Utah Office for Victims of Crime The program shall fund crime prevention, crime victim reparations, and law enforcement activities that have the purpose of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(2)(a): deterring crime by depriving criminals of the profits and proceeds of their illegal activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(2)(b): weakening criminal enterprises by removing the instrumentalities of crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(2)(c): reducing crimes involving substance abuse by supporting the creation, administration, or operation of drug court programs throughout the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(2)(d): encouraging cooperation between agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(2)(e): allowing the costs and expenses of law enforcement to be defrayed by the forfeited proceeds of crime;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(2)(f): increasing the equitability and accountability of the use of forfeited property used to assist agencies in reducing and preventing crime; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(2)(g): 63M-7-502; Title 63M, Chapter 7, Part 5, Utah Office for Victims of Crime providing aid to victims of criminally injurious conduct, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(3): 77-11b-105(2); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(3)(a): 77-11b-105(2); (2) Upon appropriation of funds from the Criminal Forfeiture Restricted Account, the commission shall allocate and administer grants to an agency or political subdivision of the state in compliance with this section and Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(3)(b): The commission may retain up to 3% of the annual appropriation from the Criminal Forfeiture Restricted Account to pay for administrative costs incurred by the commission, including salary and benefits, equipment, supplies, or travel costs that are directly related to the administration of the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(4): An agency or political subdivision shall apply for an award from the program by completing and submitting forms specified by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(5): In granting the awards, the commission shall ensure that the amount of each award takes into consideration the:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(5)(a): demonstrated needs of the agency or political subdivision;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(5)(b): demonstrated ability of the agency or political subdivision to appropriately use the award;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(5)(c): degree to which the agency's or political subdivision's need is offset through the agency's or political subdivision's participation in federal equitable sharing or through other federal and state grant programs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(5)(d): agency's or political subdivision's cooperation with other state and local agencies and task forces.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(6): (2) The commission may award a grant to any agency or political subdivision engaged in activities associated with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(7): Title 63M, Chapter 7, Criminal Justice and Substance Abuse An applying agency or political subdivision shall demonstrate compliance with all reporting and policy requirements applicable under this chapter and under
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(8)(a): A recipient agency may only use award money after approval by the agency's legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(8)(b): The award money is nonlapsing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(9): (2)(g) A recipient agency or political subdivision shall use an award:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(9)(a): (2)(g) only for law enforcement purposes described in this section, or for victim reparations as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(9)(b): for the purposes specified by the agency or political subdivision in the agency's or political subdivision's application for the award.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(10): A permissible law enforcement purpose for which award money may be used includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(10)(a): controlled substance interdiction and enforcement activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(10)(b): drug court programs;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(10)(c): activities calculated to enhance future law enforcement investigations;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(11): A law enforcement purpose for which award money may not be granted or used includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(11)(a): payment of salaries, retirement benefits, or bonuses to any individual;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11b-403(11)(f): uses, payments, or expenses that are not within the scope of the agency's functions.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(1): 77-11b-101 "Acquitted" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(2): 80-6-701 "Adjudicated" means that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(2)(a)(i): a judgment of conviction by plea or verdict of an offense has been entered by a court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(2)(a)(ii): a sentence has been imposed by the court; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(2)(b): 80-6-701 a judgment has been entered for an adjudication of an offense by a juvenile court under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(3): 80-6-701 "Adjudication" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(3)(a): a judgment of conviction by plea or verdict of an offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(3)(b): 80-6-701 an adjudication for an offense by a juvenile court under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(4): 77-11a-101 "Agency" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(5): "Appellate court" means the Utah Court of Appeals, the Utah Supreme Court, or the United States Supreme Court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(6)(a): "Biological evidence" means an item that contains blood, semen, hair, saliva, epithelial cells, latent fingerprint evidence that may contain biological material suitable for DNA testing, or other identifiable human biological material that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(6)(a)(i): is collected as part of an investigation or prosecution of a violent felony offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(6)(a)(ii): may reasonably be used to incriminate or exculpate a person for the violent felony offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(6)(b): "Biological evidence" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(6)(b)(i): material that is catalogued separately, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(6)(b)(i)(A): on a slide or swab; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(6)(b)(i)(B): inside a test tube, if the evidentiary sample that previously was inside the test tube has been consumed by testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(6)(b)(ii): material that is present on other evidence, including clothing, a ligature, bedding, a drinking cup, a cigarette, or a weapon, from which a DNA profile may be obtained;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(6)(b)(iii): the contents of a sexual assault  kit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(6)(b)(iv): for a violent felony offense, material described in this Subsection (6) that is in the custody of an evidence collecting or retaining entity on May 4, 2022.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(7): 77-11a-101 "Claimant" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(8): 77-11a-101 "Computer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(9): "Continuous chain of custody" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(9)(a): for a law enforcement agency or a court, that legal standards regarding a continuous chain of custody are maintained; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(9)(b): for an entity that is not a law enforcement agency or a court, that the entity maintains a record in accordance with legal standards required of the entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(10): 77-11a-101 "Contraband" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(11): 58-37-2 "Controlled substance" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(12): "Court" means a municipal, county, or state court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(13): "DNA" means deoxyribonucleic acid.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(14): "DNA profile" means a unique identifier of an individual derived from DNA.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(15): 58-37a-3 "Drug paraphernalia" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(16): "Evidence" means property, contraband, or an item or substance that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(16)(a): is seized or collected as part of an investigation or prosecution of an offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(16)(b): may reasonably be used to incriminate or exculpate an individual for an offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(17): 53-10-902
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(17)(a): "Evidence collecting or retaining entity" means an entity within the state that collects, stores, or retrieves biological evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(17)(b): 53-10-902 "Evidence collecting or retaining entity" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(17)(b)(i): a medical or forensic entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(17)(b)(ii): a law enforcement agency;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(17)(b)(v): 53-10-902 "Evidence collecting or retaining entity" does not include a collecting facility defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(18): "Exhibit" means property, contraband, or an item or substance that is admitted into evidence for a court proceeding.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(20): 77-11a-101 "Law enforcement agency" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(21): "Medical or forensic entity" means a private or public hospital, medical facility, or other entity that secures biological evidence or conducts forensic examinations related to criminal investigations.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(25): 53-10-902 "Sexual assault kit" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(26): 53-10-902 "Victim" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(27): 76-3-203.5 "Violent felony offense" means the same as the term "violent felony" is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-101(28): 23A-1-101 "Wildlife" means the same as that term is defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-102 Retention of evidence as an exhibit.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-102(1): If evidence is admitted as an exhibit for a court proceeding, the clerk of the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-102(1)(a): retain the evidence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-102(1)(b): return the evidence to the custody of the agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-102(2): Rule 4-206 of the Utah Code of Judicial Administration applies to evidence that is admitted as an exhibit in a court proceeding.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-103 Disposal or return of evidence.
----------------------------------------------------------------
When evidence is no longer subject to retention under this chapter, the agency shall:Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-103(1): return evidence that is property to a claimant under Chapter 11a, Part 3, Return of Seized Property to Claimant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-103(2): dispose of evidence that is property or contraband in accordance with Chapter 11a, Part 4, Disposal of Seized Property and Contraband.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201 Retention of evidence of misdemeanor offenses.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1): An agency shall retain evidence of a misdemeanor offense for the longer of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(a): the length of the statute of limitations for the offense if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(a)(i): no charges are filed for the offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(a)(ii): the offense remains unsolved;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(b): 60 days after the day on which any individual charged with the offense is acquitted if each individual charged with the offense is acquitted;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(c): 90 days after the day on which any individual is adjudicated for the offense if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(c)(i): each individual charged with the offense has been adjudicated;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(c)(ii): there is no appeal pending in:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(c)(ii)(A): an appellate court for any individual adjudicated for the offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(c)(ii)(B): the district court for a trial de novo for any individual adjudicated by a justice court for the offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(c)(iii): there is no post-trial motion pending in the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(c)(iii)(A): for a new trial under Rule 24 of the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(c)(iii)(B): to amend or make additional findings of fact under Rule 52(b) of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(c)(iii)(C): for relief under Rule 60(b) of the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(d): 30 days after the day on which any individual is adjudicated by a district court for the offense on a trial de novo from the justice court if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(d)(i): each individual charged with the offense has been adjudicated by a justice court or a district court on a trial de novo from the justice court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(d)(ii): there is no appeal pending in:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(d)(ii)(A): an appellate court for any individual adjudicated for the offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(d)(ii)(B): the district court for a trial de novo for any individual adjudicated by a justice court for the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(e): 30 days after the day on which an appellate court issues a remittitur for an appeal of any individual adjudicated for the offense if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(e)(i): the appellate court's final decision upholds the individual's adjudication;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(e)(ii): each individual charged with the offense has been adjudicated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(e)(iii): there is no appeal pending in:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(e)(iii)(A): an appellate court for any individual adjudicated for the offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(e)(iii)(B): the district court for a trial de novo for any individual adjudicated by a justice court for the offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(1)(f): 20 years from the day on which the evidence is collected if the evidence is a sexual assault kit.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(2): Subsection (1) does not require an agency to return or dispose of evidence of a misdemeanor offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-201(3): An agency shall ensure that evidence of a misdemeanor offense is subject to a continuous chain of custody.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202 Requirements for not retaining evidence of a misdemeanor offense -- Preservation of sufficient evidence.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(1): 77-11c-201; 77-11c-203; 77-11c-203; 77-11a-305 An agency is not required to retain evidence of a misdemeanor offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(1)(a): 77-11c-203; 77-11c-203
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(1)(a)(i): the agency determines that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(1)(a)(i)(A): the size, bulk, or physical character of the evidence renders retention impracticable; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(1)(a)(i)(B): the evidence poses a security or safety problem for the agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(1)(a)(ii): the agency preserves sufficient evidence of the property, contraband, item, or substance for use as evidence in a prosecution of the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(1)(a)(iii): 77-11c-203 the agency sends a written request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(1)(a)(iv): 77-11c-203 the prosecuting attorney grants the agency's written request in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(1)(b): 77-11a-305 a court orders the agency to return evidence that is property to a claimant under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(1)(c): the evidence is wildlife or parts of wildlife.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(2): 77-11c-201; 53-10-905; 53-10-905 Notwithstanding Subsection (1), the agency may not dispose of evidence of a misdemeanor offense that is a sexual assault kit before the day on which the time period described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(2)(a): 53-10-905 the agency sends a notice to the victim as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(2)(b): 53-10-905 the victim submits a written request for retention of the evidence within the 180-day period described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(3)(a): Subsection (1) does not require an agency to return or dispose of evidence of a misdemeanor offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(3)(b): Subsection (1)(a) does not apply when the return or disposal of evidence of a misdemeanor offense is in compliance with a memorandum of understanding between the agency and the prosecuting attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(4): If the evidence described in Subsection (1) is a controlled substance, an agency shall preserve sufficient evidence under Subsection (1)(a)(ii) of the controlled substance by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(4)(a): collecting and preserving a sample of the controlled substance for independent testing and use as evidence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(4)(b): taking a photographic or video record of the controlled substance with identifying case numbers;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(4)(c): maintaining a written report of a chemical analysis of the controlled substance if a chemical analysis was performed by the agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(4)(d): if the controlled substance exceeds 10 pounds, retain at least one pound of the controlled substance that is randomly selected from the controlled substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(5): If the evidence described in Subsection (1) is drug paraphernalia, an agency shall preserve sufficient evidence under Subsection (1)(a)(ii) of the drug paraphernalia by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(5)(a): collecting and preserving a sample of the controlled substance from the drug paraphernalia for independent testing and use as evidence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(5)(b): maintaining a written report of a chemical analysis of the drug paraphernalia if a chemical analysis was performed by the agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(5)(c): taking a photographic or video record of the drug paraphernalia with identifying case numbers.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(6): If the evidence described in Subsection (1) is a computer, the agency shall preserve sufficient evidence under Subsection (1)(a)(ii) of the computer by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(6)(a): extracting all data from the computer that would be evidence in a prosecution of an individual for the offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(6)(b): taking a photographic or video record of the computer with identifying case numbers.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-202(7): For any other type of evidence, the agency shall preserve sufficient evidence under Subsection (1)(a)(ii) of the property, contraband, item, or substance bytaking a photographic or video record of the property, contraband, item, or substance with identifying case numbers.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203 Request to prosecuting attorney by agency -- Notification to defendant.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(1): 77-11c-202; 77-11c-202 If an agency determines that the agency is not required to retain evidence of a misdemeanor offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(1)(a): identifies the evidence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(1)(b): 77-11c-202 explains the reason for which the agency is not required to retain the evidence under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(1)(c): explains the steps that the agency will take, or has taken, to preserve sufficient evidence of the property, contraband, item, or substance for use as evidence in a prosecution of the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(2): If the prosecuting attorney receives a written request under Subsection (1) and determines that the agency needs to retain the evidence for a prosecution of the misdemeanor offense, the prosecuting attorney shall send a written notification to the agency that explains the reason for which the prosecuting attorney is denying the agency's request.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(3): If the prosecuting attorney receives a written request under Subsection (1) and determines that the agency does not need to retain the evidence for a prosecution of the misdemeanor offense, the prosecuting attorney shall provide written notice of the intent to not retain the evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(3)(a): is sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, or a delivery service that provides proof of delivery, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(3)(a)(i): any individual charged with or adjudicated for the offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(3)(a)(ii): the individual's most recent attorney of record; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(3)(b): explains that the individual receiving the notice may submit a written objection to the prosecuting attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(4)(a): An individual, who is charged with or adjudicated for the offense, may submit a written objection to the return or disposal of the evidence by the agency no later than 30 days after the day on which the prosecuting attorney receives proof of delivery under Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(4)(b): If an individual submits a written objection under Subsection (4)(a), the prosecuting attorney shall send a written notification to the agency that explains the reason for which the prosecuting attorney is denying the agency's request.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(4)(c): If the prosecuting attorney does not receive a written objection within the time period described in Subsection (4)(a), the prosecuting attorney shall send a written notification to the agency that grants the agency's request to return or dispose of the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(5)(a): If a prosecuting attorney receives a written request from an agency seeking to return or dispose of evidence, the prosecuting attorney shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(5)(a)(i): provide a notice of receipt to the agency within 15 days after the day on which the prosecuting attorney receives the written request; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(5)(a)(ii): send a written notification to the agency of the prosecuting attorney's decision to deny or grant an agency's written request within 60 days after the day on which the prosecuting attorney receives the agency's written request.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(5)(b): If an agency does not receive a notice of receipt under Subsection (5)(a)(i) or a written notification under Subsection (5)(a)(ii), the agency may send the written request to the district attorney, county attorney, attorney general, or other prosecuting attorney who directly oversees and supervises the prosecuting attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(6): 77-11c-201 If a prosecuting attorney denies an agency's written request to return or dispose of evidence under this section, the agency shall retain the evidence in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-203(7): The requirements of this section do not apply when the return or disposal of evidence of a misdemeanor offense is in compliance with a memorandum of understanding between the agency and the prosecuting attorney.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301 Retention of evidence for felony offenses.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(1): (1)(a)(iii) Except as provided in Subsection (4), an agency shall retain evidence of a felony offense:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(1)(a): (1)(a)(iii) for the longer of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(1)(a)(i): the length of the statute of limitations for the felony offense if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(1)(a)(i)(A): charges are not filed for the felony offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(1)(a)(i)(B): the felony offense remains unsolved;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(1)(a)(ii): the length of time that any individual convicted of the felony offense, or a lesser included offense, remains in custody;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(1)(a)(iii): one year after the day on which all direct appeals of the final judgment for any individual convicted of the felony offense, or a lesser included offense, are exhausted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(1)(a)(iv): (1)(a)(iii) the length of time that a petition for postconviction relief, and any appeal of the petition, is pending if an individual convicted of the felony offense files the petition within the one-year time period described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(1)(a)(v): 20 years from the day on which the evidence is collected if the evidence is the contents of a sexual assault kit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(1)(b): at the discretion of the prosecuting attorney or federal prosecutor if the prosecution of the felony offense resulted in an acquittal or dismissal.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(2): An agency shall ensure that evidence of a felony offense is subject to a continuous chain of custody.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(3): Subsection (1) does not require an agency to return or dispose of evidence of a felony offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-301(4): An agency shall retain and preserve biological evidence of a violent felony offense in accordance with Part 4, Preservation of Biological Evidence for Violent Felony Offenses.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302 Requirements for not retaining evidence of felony offense -- Preservation of sufficient evidence.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302(1): 77-11c-301; 77-11c-303; 77-11a-305 An agency is not required to retain evidence of a felony offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302(1)(a): 77-11c-303
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302(1)(a)(i): the agency determines that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302(1)(a)(i)(A): the size, bulk, or physical character of the evidence renders retention impracticable or the evidence poses a security or safety problem for the agency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302(1)(a)(i)(B): the evidence no longer has any significant evidentiary value;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302(1)(a)(ii): the agency preserves sufficient evidence from the property, contraband, item, or substance for use as evidence in a prosecution of the offense; and

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302(6)(b): maintaining a written report of a chemical analysis of the drug paraphernalia if a chemical analysis was performed by the agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302(6)(c): taking a photographic or video record of the drug paraphernalia with identifying case numbers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302(6)(d): 77-11c-401 for a violent felony offense, collecting and preserving biological evidence from the drug paraphernalia as described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302(7)(a): extracting all data from the computer that would be evidence in a prosecution of an individual for the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-302(7)(b): taking a photographic or video record of the computer with identifying case numbers; and

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303 Procedure for authorizing the return or disposal of evidence of a felony offense.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(1): 77-11c-302; 77-11c-302 If an agency determines that the agency is not required to retain evidence of a felony offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(1)(a): identifies the evidence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(1)(b): 77-11c-302 explains the reason that the agency is not required to retain the evidence under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(1)(c): explains the steps that the agency will take, or has taken, to preserve sufficient evidence from the property, contraband, item, or substance for use as evidence in a prosecution of the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(2): If a prosecuting attorney receives a written request described in Subsection (1), the prosecuting attorney shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(2)(a): provide a notice of receipt to the agency within 15 days after the day on which the prosecuting attorney receives the written request; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(2)(b): send a written notification to the agency of the prosecuting attorney's decision to deny or grant an agency's written request within 60 days after the day on which the prosecuting attorney receives the agency's written request.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(3): If an agency sends a written request described in Subsection (1) to the prosecuting attorney, the agency shall also send the written request by certified mail, return receipt requested, or a delivery service that provides proof of delivery, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(3)(a): any individual who remains in custody based on a conviction related to the evidence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(3)(b): the private attorney or public defender of record for each individual described in Subsection (3)(a);
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(3)(c): the entity that employed the private attorney or public defender described in Subsection (3)(b) at the time of the criminal conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(3)(d): if applicable, the prosecuting agency responsible for the prosecution of each individual described in Subsection (3)(a); and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(3)(e): the Utah attorney general.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(4)(a): If a person described in Subsection (3) receives a written request from an agency seeking to return or dispose of evidence of the felony offense, the person may object to the agency's written request to return or dispose of evidence of the felony offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(4)(b): To object to an agency's request under Subsection (4)(a), the person must send a written objection to the agency and prosecuting attorney within 60 days after the day on which the person receives the agency's written request.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(5): If the prosecuting attorney receives a written request under Subsection (2) and determines that the agency needs to retain the evidence for a prosecution of the felony offense, the prosecuting attorney shall send a written notification to the agency that explains the reason for which the prosecuting attorney is denying the agency's request.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(6): The agency may petition the court for an order granting the agency's request to return or dispose of the evidence of a felony offense if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(6)(a): the prosecuting attorney denies the agency's written request or does not respond to an agency's written request within the time periods described in Subsection (2); or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(6)(b): a person described in Subsection (3) objects to the agency's written request.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(7): The court shall hold a hearing on the agency's petition to determine whether an agency's request to return or dispose of evidence should be granted.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(8): After a hearing on the agency's petition, the court shall grant an agency's request to return or dispose of evidence of a felony offense if the court determines, by a preponderance of the evidence, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(8)(a): the size, bulk, or physical character of the evidence renders retention impracticable or the evidence poses a security or safety problem for the agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(8)(b): the evidence no longer has any significant evidentiary value; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(8)(c): the agency will take, or has taken, steps to preserve sufficient evidence from the property, contraband, item, or substance for use as evidence in a prosecution of the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(9): If the court determines that a prosecuting attorney, or a person described in Subsection (3), objects to an agency's request to dispose or return of physical evidence of a felony offense because the physical evidence contains biological evidence that would be evidence in a prosecution of the offense, the court may require the agency to collect and preserve biological evidence from the physical evidence before the agency returns or disposes of the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(10): 77-11c-301; 77-11c-301 If a prosecuting attorney denies the agency's written request or a person described in Subsection (3) objects to the agency's written request, the agency shall retain the evidence of a felony offense as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(10)(a): the agency obtains a court order granting the agency's request to return or dispose of the evidence as described in Subsection (8); or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-303(10)(b): 77-11c-301 the time periods described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-401 Preservation of biological evidence -- Procedures -- Inventory request.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-401(1): 77-11c-402 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-401(2): (2)(a)(iii) An evidence collecting or retaining entity shall preserve biological evidence of a violent felony offense:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-401(2)(a)(i): the length of the statute of limitations for the violent felony offense if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-401(2)(a)(i)(A): no charges are filed for the violent felony offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-401(2)(a)(i)(B): the violent felony offense remains unsolved;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11c-401(3): An evidence collecting or retaining entity shall ensure that biological evidence under Subsection (2) is:

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 11d - Lost or Mislaid Property
***********************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(1): 77-11a-101 "Interest holder" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(2): 76-10-529
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(2)(a): "Lost or mislaid property":
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(2)(a)(i): means any property that comes into the possession of a peace officer or law enforcement agency:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(2)(a)(i)(A): that is not claimed by anyone who is identified as the owner of the property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(2)(a)(i)(B): for which no owner or interest holder can be found after a reasonable and diligent search;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(2)(a)(ii): includes any property received by a peace officer or law enforcement agency from a person claiming to have found the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(2)(a)(iii): does not include property seized by a peace officer in accordance with Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(2)(b): 76-10-529 "Lost or mislaid property" includes a firearm or other dangerous weapon received by a law enforcement agency at an airport under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(3): 77-11a-101 "Owner" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(4): "Public interest use" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(4)(a): use by a governmental agency as determined by the agency's legislative body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-101(4)(b): donation to a nonprofit charity registered with the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-102 Disposition by police agency.
--------------------------------------------------------------
All lost or mislaid property coming into the possession of a peace officer or law enforcement agency shall be turned over to, held, and disposed of only by the local law enforcement agency whose authority extends to the area where the item was found.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-103 Statement of finder of property.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-103(1): A person who finds lost or mislaid property and delivers it to a local law enforcement agency shall sign a statement included in a form provided by the agency, stating:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-103(1)(a): the manner in which the property came into the person's possession, including the time, date, and place;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-103(1)(b): that the person does not know who owns the property;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-103(1)(c): that, to the person's knowledge, the property was not stolen;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-103(1)(d): that the person's possession of the property is not unlawful; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-103(1)(e): any information the person is aware of which could lead to a determination of the owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-103(2): Additional information may be requested by the agency receiving the property, as necessary.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-104 Locating owner of property.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-104(1): The local law enforcement agency shall take reasonable steps to determine the identity and location of the owner, and notify the owner that the property is in custody.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-104(2): The owner may obtain the property only by providing personal identification, identifying the property, and paying any costs incurred by the agency, including costs for advertising or storage.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-105 Disposition of unclaimed property.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-11d-105(1): 45-1-101

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 13 - Pleas
***************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-1 Kinds of pleas.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-1(1): There are five kinds of pleas to an indictment or information:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-1(1)(a): not guilty;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-1(1)(b): guilty;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-1(1)(c): no contest;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-1(1)(d): not guilty by reason of insanity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-1(1)(e): guilty with a mental condition at the time of the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-1(2): An alternative plea of not guilty or not guilty by reason of insanity may be entered.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-2 Record of plea -- Effect of each kind of plea.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every plea shall be entered upon the record of the court and shall have the following effect:Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-2(1): A plea of not guilty is a denial of the guilt of the accused and puts in issue every material allegation of the information or indictment;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-2(2): A plea of guilty is an acknowledgment that the accused is guilty of the offense charged; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-2(3): A plea of no contest indicates the accused does not challenge the charges in the information or indictment and if accepted by the court shall have the same effect as a plea of guilty and imposition of sentence may be rendered in the same manner as if a plea of guilty had been entered.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-3 Court approval of no contest plea required.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
A plea of no contest may be entered by the accused only upon approval of the court and only after due consideration of the views of the parties and the interest of the public in the effective administration of justice.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-4 Felonies -- Entry in open court.
--------------------------------------------------------------
All pleas in felony cases shall be entered by the defendant in open court and the proceedings recorded.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-5 Failure to plead -- Not guilty entered.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
When a defendant does not enter a plea, the court shall enter a plea of not guilty for him.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-6 Withdrawal of plea.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-6(1): A plea of not guilty may be withdrawn at any time prior to conviction.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-6(2): (2)(b); Title 78B, Chapter 9, Postconviction Remedies Act
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-6(2)(a): A plea of guilty or no contest may be withdrawn only upon leave of the court and a showing that it was not knowingly and voluntarily made.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-6(2)(b): A request to withdraw a plea of guilty or no contest, except for a plea held in abeyance, shall be made by motion before sentence is announced.  Sentence may not be announced unless the motion is denied.  For a plea held in abeyance, a motion to withdraw the plea shall be made within 30 days of pleading guilty or no contest.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-13-6(2)(c): (2)(b); Title 78B, Chapter 9, Postconviction Remedies Act Any challenge to a guilty plea not made within the time period specified in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 14 - Defenses
******************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-1 Time and place of alleged offense -- Specification.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The prosecuting attorney, on timely written demand of the defendant, shall within 10 days, or such other time as the court may allow, specify in writing as particularly as is known to him the place, date and time of the commission of the offense charged.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-2 Alibi -- Notice requirements -- Witness lists.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-2(1): A defendant, whether or not written demand has been made, who intends to offer evidence of an alibi shall, not less than 10 days before trial or at such other time as the court may allow, file and serve on the prosecuting attorney a notice, in writing, of his intention to claim alibi. The notice shall contain specific information as to the place where the defendant claims to have been at the time of the alleged offense and, as particularly as is known to the defendant or his attorney, the names and addresses of the witnesses by whom he proposes to establish alibi. The prosecuting attorney, not more than five days after receipt of the list provided herein or at such other time as the court may direct, shall file and serve the defendant with the addresses, as particularly as are known to him, of the witnesses the state proposes to offer to contradict or impeach the defendant's alibi evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-2(2): The defendant and prosecuting attorney shall be under a continuing duty to disclose the names and addresses of additional witnesses which come to the attention of either party after filing their alibi witness lists.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-2(3): If a defendant or prosecuting attorney fails to comply with the requirements of this section, the court may exclude evidence offered to establish or rebut alibi. However, the defendant may always testify on his own behalf concerning alibi.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-2(4): The court may, for good cause shown, waive the requirements of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-3 Testimony regarding mental state of defendant or another -- Notice requirements -- Right to examination.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-3(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-3(1)(a): If the prosecution or the defense intends to call any expert to testify at trial or at any hearing regarding the mental state of the defendant or another, the party intending to call the expert shall give notice to the opposing party as soon as practicable but not less than 30 days before trial or 10 days before any hearing at which the testimony is offered.  Notice shall include the name and address of the expert, the expert's curriculum vitae, and a copy of the expert's report.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-3(1)(b): The expert shall prepare a written report relating to the proposed testimony.  If the expert has not prepared a report or the report does not adequately inform concerning the substance of the expert's proposed testimony including any opinion and the bases and reasons of that opinion, the party intending to call the expert shall provide a written explanation of the expert's anticipated testimony sufficient to give the opposing party adequate notice to prepare to meet the testimony, followed by a copy of any report prepared by the expert when available.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-3(2): As soon as practicable after receipt of the expert's report, the party receiving notice shall provide notice to the other party of witnesses whom the party anticipates calling to rebut the expert's testimony, including the name and address of any expert witness and the expert's curriculum vitae.  If available, a report of any rebuttal expert shall be provided.  If the rebuttal expert has not prepared a report or the report does not adequately inform concerning the substance of the expert's proposed rebuttal testimony, or in the event the witness is not an expert, the party intending to call the rebuttal witness shall provide a written explanation of the witness's anticipated rebuttal testimony sufficient to give the opposing party adequate notice to prepare to meet the testimony, followed by a copy of any report prepared by any rebuttal expert when available.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-3(3): If the prosecution or the defense proposes to introduce testimony of an expert which is based upon personal contact, interview, observation, or psychological testing of the defendant, testimony of an expert involving a mental diagnosis of the defendant, or testimony of an expert that the defendant does or does not fit a psychological or sociological profile, the opposing party shall have a corresponding right to have its own expert examine and evaluate the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-3(4): This section applies to any trial, sentencing hearing, and other hearing, excluding a preliminary hearing, whether or not the defendant proposes to offer evidence of the defense of insanity or diminished mental capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-3(5): If the defendant or the prosecution fails to meet the requirements of this section, the opposing party shall be entitled to a continuance of the trial or hearing sufficient to allow preparation to meet the testimony.  If the court finds that the failure to comply with this section is the result of bad faith on the part of any party or attorney, the court shall impose appropriate sanctions.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-3(6): This section may not require the admission of evidence not otherwise admissible.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-4 Insanity or diminished mental capacity -- Notice requirement.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-4(1): 76-5-205.5(2)(a) If a defendant intends to offer evidence that the defendant is not guilty as a result of insanity or that the defendant had diminished mental capacity, or intends to offer evidence in mitigation of a criminal homicide or attempted criminal homicide offense under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-4(2): 77-16a-301 If the court receives notice that a defendant intends to claim that the defendant is not guilty by reason of insanity or that the defendant had diminished mental capacity, the court shall proceed in accordance with the requirements described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-14-6 Entrapment -- Notice of claim required.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Notice of a claim of entrapment shall be given by the defendant in accord with Section

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 15 - Inquiry into Sanity of Defendant
******************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-1 Incompetent individual not to be tried for public offense.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An individual who is incompetent to proceed may not be tried for a public offense.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(1): "Competency evaluation" means an evaluation conducted by a forensic evaluator to determine if an individual is competent to stand trial.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(2): "Competent to stand trial" means that a defendant has:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(2)(a): a rational and factual understanding of the criminal proceedings against the defendant and of the punishment specified for the offense charged; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(2)(b): the ability to consult with the defendant's legal counsel with a reasonable degree of rational understanding in order to assist in the defense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(3): "Department" means the Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(4): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act "Forensic evaluator" means a licensed mental health professional who:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(4)(a): is not involved in the defendant's treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(4)(b): is trained and qualified by the department to conduct a competency evaluation, a restoration screening, and a progress toward competency evaluation, based on knowledge, experience, or education relating to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(4)(b)(i): intellectual functioning or psychopathology; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(4)(b)(ii): the legal system and the rights of a defendant in a criminal trial; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(4)(c): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act if under contract with the department, demonstrates ongoing education and training relating to forensic mental health in accordance with rules established by the department in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(5): "Incompetent to proceed" means that a defendant is not competent to stand trial as a result of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(5)(a): mental illness; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(5)(b): intellectual disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(6): "Intellectual disability" means an intellectual disability as defined in the current edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders published by the American Psychiatric Association.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(7): 26B-5-301 "Mental illness" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(8): "Petition" means a petition to request a court to determine whether a defendant is competent to stand trial.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(9): "Progress toward competency evaluation" means an evaluation to determine whether an individual who is receiving restoration treatment is:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(9)(a): competent to stand trial;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(9)(b): incompetent to proceed but has a substantial probability of becoming competent to stand trial in the foreseeable future; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(9)(c): incompetent to proceed and does not have a substantial probability of becoming competent to stand trial in the foreseeable future.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(10): "Restoration treatment" means training and treatment that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(10)(a): provided to an individual who is incompetent to proceed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(10)(b): tailored to the individual's particular impairment to competency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-2(10)(c): limited to the purpose of restoring the individual to competency.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3 Petition for inquiry regarding defendant  -- Filing -- Contents.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3(1): When a defendant charged with a public offense is incompetent to proceed, an individual described in Subsection (2)(b) may file a petition in the district court of the county where the charge is pending or where the defendant is confined.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3(2)(a)(i): The petition shall contain a certificate that it is filed in good faith and on reasonable grounds to believe the defendant is incompetent to proceed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3(2)(a)(ii): The petition shall contain a recital of the facts, observations, and conversations with the defendant that have formed the basis for the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3(2)(a)(iii): If filed by defense counsel, the petition may not disclose information in violation of the attorney-client privilege.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3(2)(b): The petition may be based upon knowledge or information and belief and may be filed by the defendant, any person acting on behalf of the defendant, the prosecuting attorney, or any person having custody or supervision over the defendant.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3.5 Incompetent to proceed in misdemeanor cases.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3.5(1): 77-15-3 When a defendant charged with a misdemeanor may be incompetent to proceed, any petition shall be filed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3.5(2): If the most severe charge against a defendant is a misdemeanor and the defendant is adjudicated by a court as incompetent to proceed:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3.5(2)(a): the department shall provide restoration treatment to the defendant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3.5(2)(b): the court may refer the defendant to pretrial diversion services, upon agreement of the prosecution and defense counsel.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3.5(3): 77-15-6(5)(c) Unless the prosecutor or another individual indicates that civil commitment proceedings will be initiated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3.5(3)(a): the most severe charge against the defendant is a class B misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3.5(3)(b): more than 60 days have passed after the day on which the court adjudicated the defendant incompetent to proceed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3.5(3)(c): the defendant is not restored to competency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3.5(4): (3)(b) The department shall provide restoration treatment to the defendant within the timeframe described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-3.5(5): (3) The court may, but is not required to, dismiss the charges against a defendant who was released under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-4 Court may raise issue of competency at any time.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The court in which a charge is pending may raise the issue of a defendant's competency at any time.  If raised by the court,  the court shall permit counsel for each party to address the issue of competency.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5 Order for hearing -- Stay of other proceedings -- Examinations of defendant -- Scope of examination and report.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(1): 77-15-3; 77-15-3.5; 77-15-4 A court in which criminal proceedings are pending shall stay all criminal proceedings, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(1)(a): 77-15-3; 77-15-3.5 a petition is filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(1)(b): 77-15-4 the court raises the issue of the defendant's competency under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6): (6)(a) In the conduct of a competency evaluation and in a report to the court, a forensic evaluator shall consider and address, in addition to any other factors determined to be relevant by the forensic evaluator:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(a)(i): the impact of the defendant's mental illness or intellectual disability on the defendant's present ability to:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(a)(i)(B): consult with the defendant's legal counsel with a reasonable degree of rational understanding in order to assist in the defense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(b): (6)(a) in making the determinations described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(b)(i): the defendant's present ability to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(b)(i)(A): understand the charges or allegations against the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(b)(i)(B): communicate facts, events, and states of mind;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(b)(i)(C): understand the range of possible penalties associated with the charges or allegations against the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(b)(i)(D): engage in reasoned choice of legal strategies and options;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(b)(i)(E): understand the adversarial nature of the proceedings against the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(b)(i)(F): manifest behavior sufficient to allow the court to proceed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(b)(i)(G): testify relevantly, if applicable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(6)(c): whether the defendant is exhibiting false or exaggerated physical or psychological symptoms relevant to the defendant's capacity to stand trial.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(7): (7)(b)(i); (7)(c) Upon a determination that the defendant is incompetent to proceed, the forensic evaluator shall indicate in the report to the court:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(7)(c): whether the defendant would benefit from restoration treatment; and

Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(10): (10)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(10)(a): Any statement made by the defendant in the course of any competency examination, whether the examination is with or without the consent of the defendant, any testimony by a forensic evaluator based upon the statement, and any other fruits of the statement may not be admitted in evidence against the defendant in any criminal proceeding except on an issue respecting mental condition on which the defendant has introduced evidence, unless the evidence is relevant to a determination of the defendant's competency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(10)(b): (10)(a) Before examining the defendant, the forensic evaluator shall specifically advise the defendant of the limits of confidentiality as provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(11)(a): Upon receipt of the forensic evaluators' reports, the court shall set a date for a competency hearing. The hearing shall be held not less than five and not more than 15 days after the day on which the court received the forensic evaluators' reports, unless for good cause the court sets a later date.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(11)(b): Any person directed by the department to conduct the competency evaluation may be subpoenaed to testify at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(11)(c): The court may call any forensic evaluator to testify at the hearing who is not called by the parties.  If the court calls a forensic evaluator, counsel for the parties may cross-examine the forensic evaluator.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(11)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(11)(d)(i): If the forensic evaluators are in conflict as to the competency of the defendant, all forensic evaluators should be called to testify at the hearing if reasonably available.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(11)(d)(ii): A conflict in the opinions of the forensic evaluators does not require the appointment of an additional forensic evaluator unless the court finds good cause for the appointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(12): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(12)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(12)(a)(i): A defendant shall be presumed competent to stand trial unless the court, by a preponderance of the evidence, finds the defendant incompetent to proceed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(12)(a)(ii): The burden of proof is upon the proponent of incompetency at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(12)(b): An adjudication of incompetent to proceed does not operate as an adjudication of incompetency to give informed consent for medical treatment or for any other purpose, unless specifically set forth in the court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(13): (15) In determining the defendant's competency to stand trial, the court shall consider the totality of the circumstances, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(13)(a): the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(13)(b): the defendant's criminal and arrest history;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(13)(c): prior mental health evaluations and treatments provided to the court by the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(13)(d): (15) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(13)(e): the testimony of lay witnesses, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(13)(f): the forensic evaluator's testimony and report;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(13)(g): the materials on which the forensic evaluator's report is based; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(13)(h): any other relevant evidence or consideration bearing on the competency of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(14): 77-15-6(1); (6)(a) If the court finds the defendant incompetent to proceed:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(14)(a): 77-15-6(1); (6)(a) the court shall issue the order described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-5(14)(a)(iv): be sent by the court to the department; and
