Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6 Commitment on finding of incompetency to stand trial -- Subsequent hearings -- Notice to prosecuting attorneys.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (5), if after a hearing a court finds a defendant to be incompetent to proceed, the court shall order the defendant committed to the department for restoration treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1)(b)(i): Except as provided in Subsection (1)(b)(ii), the court may recommend but may not order placement of a defendant who is found incompetent to proceed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1)(b)(ii): The court may order that the defendant be placed in a secure setting rather than a nonsecure setting.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1)(c): Following restoration screening, the department's designee shall designate and inform the court of the specific placement and restoration treatment program for the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1)(d): Restoration treatment shall be of sufficient scope and duration to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1)(d)(i): restore the defendant to competency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1)(d)(ii): determine whether the defendant can be restored to competency in the foreseeable future.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1)(e): A defendant who a court determines is incompetent to proceed may not be held for restoration treatment longer than:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1)(e)(i): the time reasonably necessary to determine that the defendant cannot become competent to stand trial in the foreseeable future; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(1)(e)(ii): the maximum period of incarceration that the defendant could receive if the defendant were convicted of the most severe offense of the offenses charged.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(a): A defendant who is receiving restoration treatment shall receive a progress toward competency evaluation, by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(a)(i): a forensic evaluator, designated by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(a)(ii): an additional forensic evaluator, if requested by a party and paid for by the requesting party.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(b): A forensic evaluator shall complete a progress toward competency evaluation and submit a report within 90 days after the day on which the forensic evaluator receives the commitment order from the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c): The report shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(i): assess whether the defendant is exhibiting false or exaggerated physical or psychological symptoms;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(ii): describe any diagnostic instruments, methods, and observations used by the evaluator to make the determination;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(iii): describe the defendant's current mental illness or intellectual disability, if any;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(iv): state the forensic evaluator's opinion as to the effect of any false or exaggerated symptoms on the defendant's competency to stand trial;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(v): assess the facility's or program's capacity to provide appropriate restoration treatment for the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(vi): assess the nature of restoration treatment provided to the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(vii): assess what progress the defendant has made toward competency restoration, with respect to the factors identified by the court in its initial order;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(viii): assess whether the defendant can reasonably be restored to competency in the foreseeable future given the restoration treatment currently being provided and the facility's or program's capacity to provide appropriate restoration treatment for the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(ix): assess the likelihood of restoration to competency, the amount of time estimated to achieve competency, or the amount of time estimated to determine whether restoration to competency may be achieved; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(x): include a statement by the facility's treating physician regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(x)(A): whether the defendant is taking any antipsychotic medication as prescribed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(x)(B): whether ongoing administration of antipsychotic medication is necessary to maintain the defendant's competency to stand trial;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(x)(C): whether antipsychotic medication is substantially likely to maintain the defendant's competency to stand trial;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(x)(D): whether antipsychotic medication is substantially unlikely to produce side effects which would significantly interfere with the defendant's ability to assist in the defendant's defense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(x)(E): that no less intrusive means are available, and whether any of those means have been attempted to render the defendant competent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(2)(c)(x)(F): whether antipsychotic medication is medically appropriate and in the defendant's best medical interest in light of the defendant's medical condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(3)(a): The court on its own motion or upon motion by either party or the department may appoint an additional forensic evaluator to conduct a progress toward competency evaluation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(3)(b): If the court appoints an additional forensic evaluator upon motion of a party, that party shall pay the costs of the additional forensic evaluator.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(4)(a): Within 15 days after the day on which the court receives the forensic evaluator's report of the progress toward competency evaluation, the court shall hold a hearing to review the defendant's competency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(4)(b): At the hearing, the burden of proving that the defendant is competent to stand trial is on the proponent of competency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(4)(c): Following the hearing, the court shall determine by a preponderance of evidence whether the defendant:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(4)(c)(i): is competent to stand trial;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(4)(c)(ii): is competent, but requires the ongoing administration of antipsychotic medication in order to maintain the defendant's competency to stand trial;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(4)(c)(iii): is incompetent to proceed, with a substantial probability that the defendant may become competent in the foreseeable future; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(4)(c)(iv): is incompetent to proceed, without a substantial probability that the defendant may become competent in the foreseeable future.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5)(a): If at any time the court determines that the defendant is competent to stand trial, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5)(a)(i): proceed with the trial or other procedures as may be necessary to adjudicate the charges;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5)(a)(ii): order that the defendant be returned to the placement and status that the defendant was in at the time when the petition for the adjudication of competency was filed or raised by the court, unless the court determines that placement of the defendant in a less restrictive environment is more appropriate;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5)(a)(iii): order the ongoing administration of antipsychotic medication to the defendant for the purpose of maintaining the defendant's competency to stand trial, if the court finds that the administration of antipsychotic medication is necessary to maintain the defendant's competency to stand trial under Subsection (4)(c)(ii); and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5)(a)(iv): require the agency, jail, or prison with custody over the defendant to report to the court any noncompliance with the court's orders under this Subsection (5) within 48 hours of the noncompliance.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5)(b): If the court determines that the defendant is incompetent to proceed with a substantial probability that the defendant may become competent in the foreseeable future, the court may order that the defendant remain committed to the department or the department's designee for the purpose of restoration treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5)(c)(i): If the court determines that the defendant is incompetent to proceed without a substantial probability that the defendant may become competent in the foreseeable future, the court shall order the defendant released from commitment to the department, unless the prosecutor or another individual informs the court that civil commitment proceedings pursuant to Title 26B, Chapter 5, Health Care - Substance Use and Mental Health, or Title 26B, Chapter 6, Part 4, Division of Services for People with Disabilities, will be initiated.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5)(c)(ii): The commitment proceedings must be initiated by a petition filed within seven days after the day on which the court makes the determination described in Subsection (4)(c)(iv), unless the court finds that there is good cause to delay the initiation of the civil commitment proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5)(c)(iii): The court may order the defendant to remain committed to the department until the civil commitment proceedings conclude.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(5)(c)(iv): If the defendant is civilly committed and admitted to a secure setting, the department shall provide notice to the court that adjudicated the defendant incompetent to proceed and to the prosecution agency that prosecuted the case at least 60 days before any proposed release of the committed individual from the secure setting.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(6)(a): At any time following the court's order under Subsection (5)(a)(iii), the defendant, the prosecuting attorney, the department, the treating physician, or the agency, jail, or prison with custody over the defendant, may notify the court of the need to review the medication order under Subsection (5)(a)(iii) for continued appropriateness and feasibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(6)(b): The court shall set the matter for a hearing if the notification under Subsection (6)(a) establishes good cause to review the matter.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(7): If a court, under Subsection (5)(b), extends a defendant's commitment, the court shall schedule a competency review hearing for the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(7)(a): the department's best estimate of when the defendant may be restored to competency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(7)(b): three months after the day on which the court determined under Subsection (5)(b) to extend the defendant's commitment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(8): Unless the defendant is charged with a crime listed in Subsection (9), if a defendant is incompetent to proceed by the day of the competency review hearing that follows the extension of a defendant's commitment, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(8)(a): order the defendant be:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(8)(a)(i): released or temporarily detained pending civil commitment proceedings as described in Subsection (5)(c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(8)(a)(ii): terminate the defendant's commitment to the department for restoration treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(8)(b): if the forensic evaluator reports to the court that there is a substantial probability that restoration treatment will bring the defendant to competency to stand trial in the foreseeable future, extend the defendant's commitment for restoration treatment up to 45 additional days.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(9): If the defendant is charged with aggravated murder, murder, attempted murder, manslaughter, or a first degree felony and the court determines that the defendant is making reasonable progress towards restoration of competency at the time of the hearing held pursuant to Subsection (7), the court may extend the commitment for a period not to exceed nine months for the purpose of restoration treatment, with a mandatory review hearing at the end of the nine-month period.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(10): Unless the defendant is charged with aggravated murder or murder, if, at the nine-month review hearing described in Subsection (9), the court determines that the defendant is incompetent to proceed, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(10)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(10)(a)(i): order the defendant be released or temporarily detained pending civil commitment proceedings as provided in Subsection (5)(c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(10)(a)(ii): terminate the defendant's commitment to the department for restoration treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(10)(b): if the forensic evaluator reports to the court that there is a substantial probability that restoration treatment will bring the defendant to competency to stand trial in the foreseeable future, extend the defendant's commitment for restoration treatment for up to 135 additional days.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(11): If the defendant is charged with aggravated murder or murder and the court determines that the defendant is making reasonable progress towards restoration of competency at the time of the nine-month review hearing described in Subsection (9), the court may extend the commitment for a period not to exceed 24 months for the purpose of restoration treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(12): If the court extends the defendant's commitment term under Subsection (11), the court shall hold a hearing no less frequently than at 12-month intervals following the extension for the purpose of determining the defendant's competency status.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(13): If, at the end of the 24-month commitment period described in Subsection (11), the court determines that the defendant is incompetent to proceed, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(13)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(13)(a)(i): order the defendant be released or temporarily detained pending civil commitment proceedings as provided in Subsection (5)(c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(13)(a)(ii): terminate the defendant's commitment to the department for restoration treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(13)(b): if the forensic evaluator reports to the court that there is a substantial probability that restoration treatment will bring the defendant to competency to stand trial in the foreseeable future, extend the defendant's commitment for restoration treatment for up to 12 additional months.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(14): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(14)(a): Neither release from a pretrial incompetency commitment under the provisions of this section nor civil commitment requires dismissal of criminal charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(14)(b): The court may retain jurisdiction over the criminal case and may order periodic reviews.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(15): A defendant who is civilly committed pursuant to Title 26B, Chapter 5, Health Care - Substance Use and Mental Health, or Title 26B, Chapter 6, Part 4, Division of Services for People with Disabilities, may still be adjudicated competent to stand trial under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(16): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(16)(a): The remedy for a violation of the time periods specified in this section, other than those specified in Subsection (5)(c), (8), (10), or (13), shall be a motion to compel the hearing, or mandamus, but not release from detention or dismissal of the criminal charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(16)(b): The remedy for a violation of the time periods specified in Subsection (5)(c), (8), (9), or (13), or is not dismissal of the criminal charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(17): In cases in which the treatment of the defendant is precluded by court order for a period of time, that time period may not be considered in computing time limitations under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(18): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(18)(a): If, at any time, the defendant becomes competent to stand trial while the defendant is committed to the department, the clinical director of the Utah State Hospital, the department, or the department's designee shall certify that fact to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(18)(b): The court shall conduct a competency review hearing:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(18)(b)(i): within 15 working days after the day on which the court receives the certification described in Subsection (18)(a); or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(18)(b)(ii): within 30 working days after the day on which the court receives the certification described in Subsection (18)(a), if the court determines that more than 15 working days are necessary for good cause related to the defendant's competency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(19): The court may order a hearing at any time on the court's own motion or upon recommendations of the clinical director of the Utah State Hospital or other facility or the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6(20): Notice of a hearing on competency to stand trial shall be given to the prosecuting attorney and all counsel of record.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5 Petition for involuntary medication of incompetent defendant.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(1): As used in this section, "final order" means a court order that determines the rights of the parties and concerning which appellate remedies have been exhausted or the time for appeal has expired.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(2): 77-15-6; (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(2)(a): 77-15-6 At any time after a defendant has been found incompetent to proceed and has been committed to the department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(2)(b): (2)(a) The department shall provide the notification under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(3): (2)(a) In the notice under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(3)(a): medication is necessary to render the defendant competent;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(3)(b): medication is substantially likely to render the defendant competent;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(3)(c): medication is substantially unlikely to produce side effects which would significantly interfere with the defendant's ability to assist in the defendant's defense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(3)(d): no less intrusive means are available, and whether any of those means have been attempted to render the defendant competent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(3)(e): medication is medically appropriate and is in the defendant's best medical interest in light of the defendant's medical condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(4): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(4)(a): (2)(a) The court shall conduct a hearing within 15 days, or, for good cause, within 30 days after the day on which the court receives the notice described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(4)(b): The prosecuting attorney shall represent the state at any hearing under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(4)(c): The court shall consider whether the following factors apply in determining whether the defendant should be involuntarily medicated:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(4)(c)(i): important state interests are at stake in restoring the defendant's competency;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(4)(c)(ii): involuntary medication will significantly further the important state interests, in that the medication proposed:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(4)(c)(ii)(A): is substantially likely to render the defendant competent to stand trial; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(4)(c)(ii)(B): is substantially unlikely to produce side effects which would significantly interfere with the defendant's ability to assist in the defendant's defense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(4)(c)(iii): involuntary medication is necessary to further important state interests, because any less intrusive treatments are unlikely to achieve substantially the same results; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(4)(c)(iv): the administration of the proposed medication is medically appropriate, as it is in the defendant's best medical interest in light of the defendant's medical condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(5): In determining whether the proposed treatment is medically appropriate and is in the defendant's best medical interest, the potential penalty the defendant may be subject to, if the defendant is convicted of any charged offense, is not a relevant consideration.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(6): (4)(c); 77-15-6; (6)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(6)(a): (4)(c); 77-15-6 If the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that the involuntary administration of antipsychotic medication is appropriate, it shall make findings addressing each of the factors in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(6)(b): (6)(a) When issuing an order under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(7): 77-15-6; (2) The provisions in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(7)(a): the court has issued a final order for the involuntary medication of the defendant, and the defendant has been medicated under that order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(7)(b): the court has issued a final order that the defendant will not be involuntarily medicated.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-6.5(8): This section applies only when an order of involuntary medication is sought solely for the purpose of rendering a defendant competent to stand trial.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-7 Statute of limitations and speedy trial -- Effect of incompetency of defendant.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-7(1): The statute of limitations is tolled during any period in which the defendant is adjudicated incompetent to proceed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-7(2): Any period of time during which the defendant has been adjudicated incompetent to proceed and any period during which the defendant is being evaluated for competency may not be computed in determining the defendant's speedy trial rights.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-8 Bail exonerated on commitment of defendant.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
When a defendant awaiting trial is committed to a mental health facility, bail shall be exonerated.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-9 Expenses.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-9(1): In determining the competence of a defendant to proceed, expenses of examination, observation, or treatment, excluding travel to and from any mental health facility, shall be charged to the department when the offense is a state offense.  Travel expenses incurred by the defendant shall be charged to the county where prosecution is commenced.  Examination of a defendant on local ordinance violations shall be charged by the department to the municipality or county commencing the prosecution.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-9(2): When examination is initiated by the court or on motion of the prosecutor, expenses of commitment and treatment of the defendant, if the defendant is determined to be incompetent to proceed, shall also be charged to the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-9(3): Expenses of examination, treatment, or confinement in a mental health facility for any individual who has been convicted of a crime and placed in a state correctional facility shall be charged to the Department of Corrections.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15-9(4): If, after evaluation, the court determines that a defendant is competent to stand trial, all subsequent costs are charged to the county commencing prosecution. If the defendant requested the examination and is found to be competent to stand trial by the court, the department may recover the expenses of the examination from the defendant.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-15a-102 "Intellectually disabled" defined.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter, a defendant is " intellectually disabled" if:Utah Code Annotated § 77-15a-102(1): the defendant has significant subaverage general intellectual functioning that results in and exists concurrently with significant deficiencies in adaptive functioning that exist primarily in the areas of reasoning or impulse control, or in both of these areas; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15a-102(2): (1) the subaverage general intellectual functioning and the significant deficiencies in adaptive functioning under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 77-15a-103 Court may raise issue of intellectual disability at any time.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The court in which a capital charge is pending may raise the issue of the defendant's intellectual disability at any time.  If raised by the court, counsel for each party shall be allowed to address the issue of intellectual disability.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-15a-105 Defendant's wilful failure to cooperate -- Expert testimony regarding intellectual disability is barred.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15a-105(1): If the defendant files notice, raises the issue, or intends to present evidence or make an argument that the defendant is exempt from the death penalty under this chapter, the defendant shall make himself available and fully cooperate in any examination by mental health experts appointed by the Department of Health and Human Services and any other independent examiners for the defense or the prosecution.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-15a-105(2): If the defendant wilfully fails to make himself available and fully cooperate in the examination, and that failure is established to the satisfaction of the court, the defendant is barred from presenting expert testimony relating to any exemption from the death penalty under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 16a - Commitment and Treatment of Individuals with a Mental Condition
**************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(1): 77-27-2 "Board" means the Board of Pardons and Parole established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(2): "Department" means the Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(3): "Executive director" means the executive director of the Department of Health and Human Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(4): "Forensic evaluator" means a licensed mental health professional who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(4)(a): not involved in the defendant's treatment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(4)(b): trained and qualified to conduct a guilty with a mental condition evaluation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(5): 76-2-305 "Mental condition" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(6): 76-2-305 "Mental disability" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(7): "Mental health facility" means the Utah State Hospital or other facility that provides mental health services under contract with the division, a local mental health authority, or organization that contracts with a local mental health authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(8): 77-16a-103 "Mental health supervision" includes regular and periodic activities including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(8)(a): the review of a defendant's assessment, diagnostic formulation, individual service plan development, and progress toward completion of care;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(8)(b): identification of barriers to a defendant's care, assistance in removing barriers to a defendant's care, continuation of services to a defendant, authorization of care for a defendant, and the observation of the delivery of clinical care to a defendant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(8)(c): 77-16a-103 the provision of an update report to a court as required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(9): 76-2-305 "Mental illness" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(10): "Offender with a mental condition" means an individual who has been adjudicated guilty with a mental condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(11): "Secure setting" means a jail, prison, or locked inpatient medical facility approved by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-101(12): "UDC" means the Department of Corrections.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102 Jury instructions.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(1): If a defendant asserts a defense of not guilty by reason of insanity, the court shall instruct the jury that the jury may find the defendant:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(1)(a): guilty;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(1)(b): guilty with a mental condition at the time of the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(1)(c): guilty of a lesser offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(1)(d): guilty of a lesser offense with a mental condition at the time of the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(1)(e): not guilty by reason of insanity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(1)(f): not guilty.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(2): 76-2-305; 76-5-205.5(2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(2)(a): 76-2-305; 76-5-205.5(2)(a) When a defendant asserts a mental defense pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(2)(b): If the jury finds the defendant guilty of the charged offense by proof beyond a reasonable doubt, and by special verdict finds the defendant had a mental condition at the time of the offense, the jury shall return the general verdict of "guilty with a mental condition at the time of the offense."
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(2)(c): If the jury finds the defendant guilty of a lesser offense by proof beyond a reasonable doubt, and by special verdict finds the defendant had a mental condition at the time of the offense, the jury shall return the general verdict of "guilty of a lesser offense with a mental condition at the time of the offense."
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(2)(d): If the jury finds the defendant guilty of the charged offense or a lesser included offense and does not find that the defendant had a mental condition at the time of the offense, the jury shall return a verdict of "guilty" of the offense, along with the special verdict form indicating that the jury did not find that the defendant had a mental condition at the time of the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(2)(e): The special verdict shall be returned by the jury at the same time as the general verdict, to indicate the basis for the jury's general verdict.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(3)(a): In determining whether a defendant should be found guilty with a mental condition at the time of the offense, the court shall instruct the jury that the standard of proof applicable to a finding of mental condition is by a preponderance of the evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(3)(b): The court shall also instruct the jury that the standard of preponderance of the evidence does not apply to the elements establishing a defendant's guilt, and that the proof of the elements establishing a defendant's guilt of an offense must be proven beyond a reasonable doubt.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(4): 76-5-205.5(2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(4)(a): 76-5-205.5(2)(b) When special mitigation based on extreme emotional distress is at issue pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-102(4)(b): The special verdict shall be returned by the jury at the same time as the general verdict, to indicate the basis for the jury's general verdict.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103 Plea of guilty with a mental condition-- Procedures -- Sentencing -- Reduction -- Costs.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1)(a)(i): If a defendant wishes to enter a plea of guilty with a mental condition, the parties may stipulate as to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1)(a)(i)(A): whether the defendant had a mental condition at the time of the commission of the offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1)(a)(i)(B): whether the defendant could benefit from supervision or treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1)(a)(ii): If the parties stipulate as described in Subsection (1)(a)(i), the court shall enter findings consistent with the parties' stipulation if the stipulation is supported by sufficient evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1)(b): If the parties do not stipulate to Subsection (1)(a)(i), the court shall hold a hearing and determine, by clear and convincing evidence:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1)(b)(i): whether the defendant had a mental condition at the time of the commission of the offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1)(b)(ii): whether the defendant could benefit from supervision or treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1)(c): After reviewing the stipulation described in Subsection (1)(a)(i) or conducting a hearing under Subsection (1)(b):
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1)(c)(i): if the court finds that the defendant had a mental condition at the time of the offense, the court shall accept the defendant's plea of guilty with a mental condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(1)(c)(ii): if the court finds that the defendant did not have a mental condition at the time of the offense, the court may not accept the defendant's plea of guilty with a mental condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(a): If a defendant wishes to enter a plea of guilty with a mental condition for a felony offense and the parties do not stipulate to Subsection (1)(a)(i), before holding the hearing described in Subsection (1)(b), the court may order the defendant to submit to an examination, which may be conducted only by a forensic evaluator appointed by the department, to determine:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(a)(i): whether the defendant had a mental condition at the time of the commission of the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(a)(ii): whether the defendant could benefit from supervision or treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(a)(iii): whether the defendant currently is competent to enter a plea.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(b)(i): If a defendant wishes to enter a plea of guilty with a mental condition for a misdemeanor offense and the parties do not stipulate to Subsection (1)(a)(i), before holding the hearing described in Subsection (1)(b), the court may order the defendant to submit to an examination by a forensic evaluator.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(b)(ii): The examination shall determine:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(b)(ii)(A): whether the defendant had a mental condition at the time of the commission of the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(b)(ii)(B): whether the defendant could benefit from supervision or treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(b)(ii)(C): whether the defendant currently is competent to enter a plea.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(c): Before an examination is conducted pursuant to Subsection (1)(b) or this Subsection (2):
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(c)(i): the petitioner or other party, as directed by the court or requested by the department, shall provide to the forensic evaluation provider nonmedical information and materials relevant to a treatment assessment, including the charging document, arrest or incident reports pertaining to the charged offense, known criminal history information, and known prior mental health evaluations and treatments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(c)(ii): for purposes of a guilty with a mental condition evaluation, a custodian of mental health records pertaining to the defendant, including the defendant's prior mental health evaluations or records relating to the defendant's substance use disorder, may provide the records to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(c)(ii)(A): with the defendant's consent, a forensic evaluation provider or the department on the department's request; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(2)(c)(ii)(B): pursuant to an order of the court, a forensic evaluation provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(3)(a): If a defendant relies on a private mental health evaluation in support of the defendant's plea of guilty with a mental condition and the parties do not stipulate to Subsection (1)(a)(i), upon the request of the prosecutor before the hearing described in Subsection (1)(b), the court shall order the defendant to submit to an examination by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(3)(a)(i): the department if the offense is a felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(3)(a)(ii): the department or a forensic evaluator if the offense is a misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(3)(b): The petitioner or other party, as directed by the court or requested by the department, shall provide to the private mental health evaluation provider nonmedical information and materials relevant to a treatment assessment, including the charging document, arrest or incident reports pertaining to the charged offense, known criminal history information, and known prior mental health evaluations and treatments.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(3)(c): For purposes of a guilty with a mental condition evaluation, a custodian of mental health records pertaining to the defendant, including the defendant's prior mental health evaluations or records relating to the defendant's substance use disorder, may provide the records to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(3)(c)(i): with the defendant's consent, a private mental health evaluation provider or the department on the department's request; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(3)(c)(ii): pursuant to an order of the court, a private mental health evaluation provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(4): If a court finds that a defendant was guilty with a mental condition at the time of the offense in accordance with Subsection (1)(c)(i) but would not benefit from available supervision or treatment, the court shall hold a sentencing hearing within 45 days of the entry of the defendant's plea of guilty with a mental condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5): 76-3-406
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(a): If a court finds that a defendant had a mental condition at the time of the commission of the offense, the defendant could benefit from supervision or treatment, and has entered a plea of guilty with a mental condition in accordance with Subsection (1)(c)(i), the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(a)(i): shall order:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(a)(i)(A): the department to provide a treatment assessment of the defendant and to submit to the court treatment recommendations for the defendant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(a)(i)(B): the defendant to arrange for a treatment assessment of the defendant with a private provider and for the private provider to submit to the court treatment recommendations for the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(a)(ii): shall schedule a treatment review hearing within 30 days after the day on which the court entered the plea of guilty with a mental condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(a)(iii): may defer sentencing for up to one year in accordance with Subsection (6), if the defendant consents to a deferred sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(b): The petitioner or other party, as directed by the court or requested by the department, shall provide to the treatment assessment provider nonmedical information and materials relevant to a treatment assessment, including the charging document, arrest or incident reports pertaining to the charged offense, known criminal history information, and known prior mental health evaluations and treatments.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(c): For purposes of a guilty with a mental condition treatment assessment, a custodian of mental health records pertaining to the defendant, including the defendant's prior mental health evaluations or records relating to the defendant's substance use disorder, may provide the records to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(c)(i): with the defendant's consent, a treatment assessment provider or the department on the department's request; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(c)(ii): pursuant to an order of the court, a treatment assessment provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(d): At the treatment review hearing described in Subsection (5)(a)(ii), the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(d)(i): consider all available diagnosis, treatment, and supervision recommendations;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(d)(ii): if a party does not agree with treatment recommendations issued by the department under Subsection (5)(a)(i)(A), hold a hearing on the issue of the department's recommendations and make appropriate modifications to the recommendations if necessary; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(d)(iii): order the defendant to comply with all treatment and supervision recommendations that are in the best interest of the defendant and public safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(e)(i): In determining treatment and supervision recommendations under Subsection (5)(d), the court may order the defendant to be placed in a secure setting as described in Subsections (5)(e)(ii) and (iii) if the court finds that the placement would be in the best interest of the defendant, a victim of the defendant, or public safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(e)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(e)(ii)(A): If the offense is a class C misdemeanor, the court may not place the defendant in a secure setting for more than 90 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(e)(ii)(B): If the offense is a class B misdemeanor, the court may not place the defendant in a secure setting for more than six months.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(e)(ii)(C): If the offense is a class A misdemeanor or a felony, the court may place the defendant in a secure setting for up to one year.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(e)(iii): The court shall, before making a determination as to a secure setting placement, notify the executive director of the proposed placement and provide the department with an opportunity to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(e)(iii)(A): evaluate the defendant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(e)(iii)(B): make a recommendation regarding placement to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(f): 76-3-406 If the court determines that the defendant is eligible for supervised release as part of the defendant's treatment and supervision recommendations under Subsection (5)(d), except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(f)(i): if the offense is a felony:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(f)(i)(A): supervision by Adult Probation and Parole, or a third party that is approved by Adult Probation and Parole, for a period of up to one year in accordance with the applicable supervision provisions described in Title 64, Chapter 13, Department of Corrections - State Prison; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(f)(i)(B): mental health supervision by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(f)(i)(B)(I): the department or a local mental health authority; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(f)(i)(B)(II): if the court determines that it is appropriate, a public or private entity that provides mental or behavioral health services and is approved by the; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(f)(ii): if the offense is a misdemeanor, mental health supervision by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(f)(ii)(A): a local mental health authority; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(f)(ii)(B): if the court determines that it is appropriate, a public or private entity that provides mental or behavioral health services and is approved by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(g): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(g)(i): After the initial review hearing described in Subsection (5)(a), the court shall hold periodic review hearings approximately every 90 days, the frequency of which may be modified by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(g)(ii): At a review hearing described in Subsection (5)(g)(i):
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(g)(ii)(A): the department or the department's designee shall report on the progress of the defendant, provide recommendations for the defendant's future care, treatment, and secure or unsecure placement, and advise the court on the medical necessity of treatments for the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(g)(ii)(B): the court shall review the status of the defendant and determine whether any changes are needed to the defendant's supervision or treatment plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(g)(ii)(C): a party may request, if the party has a good faith basis, that the court review or change the defendant's placement within a secure or non-secure setting.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(h): If a defendant is willfully non-compliant with the treatment or supervision ordered by the court under this Subsection (5), the court shall hold an order to show cause hearing to determine whether the court should:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(h)(i): proceed with sentencing under Subsection (6);
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(h)(ii): change the defendant's placement to a secure setting;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(h)(iii): impose another sanction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(5)(h)(iv): take no action.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(a): The court shall defer sentencing for a defendant who has pleaded guilty with a mental condition as described in Subsection (5) until:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(a)(i): the court determines, after an order to show cause hearing or a review hearing as described in Subsection (5), that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(a)(i)(A): the defendant is willfully non-compliant with treatment or supervision and is unlikely to become compliant with further ordered treatment or supervision; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(a)(i)(B): the defendant has reached the maximum benefit of treatment and supervision; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(a)(ii): one year has elapsed after the day on which the court entered the defendant's plea of guilty with a mental condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(b): At the sentencing hearing, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(b)(i): consider all treatment and supervision that has occurred before the sentencing hearing in the defendant's case;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(b)(ii): credit any time the defendant has spent in a mental health facility or other residential treatment facility or a secure facility against the defendant's sentence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(b)(iii): consider victim input;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(b)(iv): consider the best interests of the defendant, including which sentence will help prevent the defendant:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(b)(iv)(A): from losing the defendant's ability to control the defendant's state of mental health; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(b)(iv)(B): from committing additional criminal conduct related to the defendant's mental condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(b)(v): consider the best interest of public safety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(6)(b)(vi): consider any other relevant factor or circumstance.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(8)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(8)(a)(i): Except as provided in Subsection (8)(a)(iv), when the offense is a state offense, expenses of examination, observation, and treatment for the defendant shall be paid by the department when not paid for by the defendant's insurance.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(8)(a)(ii): Travel expenses shall be paid by the county where prosecution is commenced.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(8)(b)(i): Provisions in this part for the support at public expense of a defendant with a mental condition do not release an insurer of a defendant with a mental condition from liability for the care or treatment of the defendant with a mental condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(8)(b)(ii): The department is authorized to collect amounts spent on a defendant with a mental condition from an insurer of the defendant with a mental condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-103(8)(b)(iii): A health insurance company may not deny coverage for court-ordered treatment or supervision of a defendant with a mental condition solely based on the fact that the treatment or supervision is ordered by a court if the treatment or supervision is medically necessary and would otherwise be a covered benefit under the defendant's insurance plan.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201 Probation.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(1): 76-3-406
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(1)(a): In felony cases, when the court proposes to place on probation a defendant who has pled or is found guilty with a mental condition at the time of the offense, it shall request UDC to provide a presentence investigation report regarding whether probation is appropriate for that defendant and, if so, recommending a specific treatment program.  If the defendant is placed on probation, that treatment program shall be made a condition of probation, and the defendant shall remain under the jurisdiction of the sentencing court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(1)(b): 76-3-406 The court may not place an offender who has been convicted of the felony offenses listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(2): The period of probation for a felony offense committed by a defendant who has been found guilty with a mental condition at the time of the offense may not be subsequently reduced by the sentencing court without consideration of an updated report on the mental health status of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(3)(a): Treatment ordered by the court under this section may be provided by or under contract with the department, a mental health facility, a local mental health authority, or, with the approval of the sentencing court, any other public or private mental health provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(3)(b): The entity providing treatment under this section shall file a report with the defendant's probation officer at least every six months during the term of probation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(3)(c): Any request for termination of probation regarding a defendant who is receiving treatment under this section shall include a current mental health report prepared by the treatment provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(4): Failure to continue treatment or any other condition of probation, except by agreement with the entity providing treatment and the sentencing court, is a basis for initiating probation violation hearings.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(5): The court may not release an offender with a mental condition into the community, as a part of probation, if it finds by clear and convincing evidence that the offender:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(5)(a): poses an immediate physical danger to self or others, including jeopardizing the offender's own or others' safety, health, or welfare if released into the community; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(5)(b): lacks the ability to provide the basic necessities of life, such as food, clothing, and shelter, if released into the community.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-201(6): (5) An offender with a mental condition who is not eligible for release into the community under the provisions of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(2)(a)(ii): progress since commitment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(2)(a)(iii): prognosis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(2)(b): that includes a recommendation regarding whether the offender with a mental condition should be:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(2)(b)(i): transferred to UDC; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(2)(b)(ii): remain in the custody of the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(a): The executive director shall notify the UDC medical administrator and the board's mental health adviser that an offender with a mental condition is eligible for transfer to UDC if the review team finds that the offender:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(a)(i): no longer has a mental condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(a)(ii): has a mental condition and may continue to be a danger to self or others, but can be controlled if adequate care, medication, and treatment are provided by UDC; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(a)(iii): the offender's condition has been stabilized to the point that commitment to the department and admission to the Utah State Hospital are no longer necessary to ensure adequate mental health treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(b): The administrator of the mental health facility where the offender is located shall provide the UDC medical administrator with a copy of the reviewing staff's recommendation and:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(b)(i): all available clinical facts;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(b)(ii): the diagnosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(b)(iii): the course of treatment received at the mental health facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(b)(iv): the prognosis for remission of symptoms;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(b)(v): the potential for recidivism;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(b)(vi): an estimation of the offender's dangerousness, either to self or others; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-203(3)(b)(vii): recommendations for future treatment.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-204 UDC acceptance of transfer of persons found guilty with a mental condition -- Retransfer from UDC to department for admission to the Utah State Hospital.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-204(4): In the event that the department and UDC do not agree on the transfer of an offender with a mental condition, the administrator of the mental health facility where the offender is located shall notify the mental health adviser for the board, in writing, of the dispute.  The mental health adviser shall be provided with copies of all reports and recommendations.  The board's mental health adviser shall make a recommendation to the board on the transfer and the board shall issue its decision within 30 days.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205 Parole.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(1): When an offender with a mental condition who has been committed to the department becomes eligible to be considered for parole, the board shall request a recommendation from the executive director and from UDC before placing the offender on parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(2): Before setting a parole date, the board shall request that its mental health adviser prepare a report regarding the offender with a mental condition, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(2)(a): all available clinical facts;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(2)(b): the diagnosis;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(2)(c): the course of treatment received at the mental health facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(2)(d): the prognosis for remission of symptoms;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(2)(e): potential for recidivism;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(2)(f): an estimation of the dangerousness of the offender with a mental condition either to self or others; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(2)(g): recommendations for future treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(3): (2) Based on the report described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(4): UDC, through Adult Probation and Parole, shall monitor the status of an offender with a mental condition who has been placed on parole.  UDC may provide treatment by contracting with the department, a local mental health authority, any other public or private provider, or in-house staff.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-205(5): The board may not subsequently reduce the period of parole without considering an updated report on the offender's current mental condition.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-302 Persons found not guilty by reason of insanity -- Disposition.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-302(1): Upon a verdict of not guilty by reason of insanity, the court shall conduct a hearing within 10 days to determine whether the defendant currently has a mental condition.  The defense counsel and prosecutors may request further evaluations and present testimony from those examiners.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-302(2): After the hearing and upon consideration of the record, the court shall order the defendant committed to the department if it finds by clear and convincing evidence that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-302(2)(a): the defendant has a mental condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-302(2)(b): because of that mental condition the defendant presents a substantial danger to self or others.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-302(3): (2) The period of commitment described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-303 Court determinations.
------------------------------------------------------
After entry of judgment of not guilty by reason of insanity, the court shall:Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-303(1): determine on the record the offense of which the person otherwise would have been convicted and the maximum sentence he could have received; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16a-303(2): make specific findings regarding whether there is a victim of the crime for which the defendant has been found not guilty by reason of insanity and, if so, whether the victim wishes to be notified of any conditional release, discharge, or escape of the defendant.
