Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 16b - Involuntary Feeding and Hydration of Inmates
*******************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Involuntary Feeding and Hydration of Inmates."

Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(1): 64-13-1; 80-1-102 "Correctional facility" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(1)(a): a county jail;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(1)(b): 64-13-1 a secure correctional facility as defined by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(1)(c): 80-1-102 a secure care facility as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(2): "Correctional facility administrator" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(2)(a): a county sheriff in charge of a county jail;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(2)(b): a designee of the executive director of the Utah Department of Corrections; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(2)(c): a designee of the director of the Division of Juvenile Justice and Youth Services.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(3): "Medical supervision" means under the direction of a licensed physician, physician assistant, or nurse practitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(4): 58-60-102 "Mental health therapist" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(5): "Prisoner" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(5)(a): any individual who is a pretrial detainee or who has been committed to the custody of a sheriff or the Utah Department of Corrections, and who is physically in a correctional facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-102(5)(b): any individual who is 18 years old or older and younger than 21 years old, and who has been committed to the custody of the Division of Juvenile Justice and Youth Services.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103 Involuntary feeding or hydration of prisoners -- Petition procedures, venue -- Prisoner rights.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(1): A correctional facility administrator may petition the district court where the correctional facility is located for an order permitting the involuntary feeding or hydration of any prisoner who is likely to suffer severe harm or death by refusing to accept sufficient nutrition or hydration.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(2): Prior to the filing of a petition under this section, a mental health therapist who is designated by the correctional facility administrator shall conduct a mental health evaluation of the subject prisoner.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(3): Upon the filing of a petition, the district court shall hold a hearing within two working days.  The court:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(3)(a): shall confidentially review the prisoner's medical and mental health records as they are available;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(3)(b): may hear testimony or receive evidence, subject to the Utah Rules of Evidence, concerning the circumstances of the prisoner's lack of nutrition or hydration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(3)(c): may exclude from the hearing any person whose presence is not necessary for the purposes of the hearing, due to the introduction of personal medical and mental health evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(4): (3) After conducting the hearing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(4)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(4)(a)(i): the prisoner is likely to suffer severe harm or death by refusing to accept sufficient nutrition or hydration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(4)(a)(ii): the correctional facility's medical or penological objectives are valid and outweigh the prisoner's right to refuse treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(4)(b): the prisoner is refusing sufficient nutrition or hydration with the intent to obstruct or delay any judicial or administrative proceeding pending against the prisoner.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(5): The district court shall state its findings of fact and conclusions of law on the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(6): (3) The correctional facility administrator shall serve copies of the petition and a notice of the district court hearing on the prisoner and the prisoner's counsel, if the prisoner is represented by counsel, at least 24 hours in advance of the hearing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-103(7): The prisoner has the right to attend the hearing, testify, present evidence, and cross-examine witnesses.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-104 Involuntary feeding or hydration of prisoners -- Standards, continuing jurisdiction, and records.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-104(1): Any involuntary nutrition or hydration of a prisoner pursuant to this chapter shall be conducted under immediate medical supervision and in a medically recognized and acceptable manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-104(2): 77-16b-102 Upon the filing of a petition pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-104(3): 63G-2-304 A correctional facility shall maintain records of any involuntary feeding or hydration of prisoners under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-104(3)(a): 63G-2-304 The records are classified as "controlled" under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-104(3)(b): All medical or mental health records submitted to the court under this chapter shall be kept under seal.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-16b-105 Involuntary feeding or hydration of prisoners -- Exceptions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not apply to medically imposed fasts for the purpose of conducting medical procedures or tests, or to religious fasts of reasonable duration.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 17 - The Trial
*******************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-1 Doubt as to degree -- Conviction only on lowest.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When it appears the defendant has committed a public offense and there is reasonable doubt as to which of two or more degrees he is guilty, he shall be convicted only of the lower degree.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-2 Discharging one of several defendants -- To testify for state.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When two or more persons are included in the same charge, the court may at any time, on the application of the prosecuting attorney, direct any defendant to be discharged or his case severed so that he may be a witness for the prosecution.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-3 Discharge for insufficient evidence.
------------------------------------------------------------------
When it appears to the court that there is not sufficient evidence to put a defendant to his defense, it shall forthwith order him discharged.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-4 Conspiracy -- Pleading -- Evidence -- Proof necessary.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On a trial for conspiracy in a case where an overt act is necessary to constitute the offense, the defendant shall not be convicted unless one or more overt acts are expressly alleged in the information or indictment, and unless one of the acts alleged has been proved. However, proof of overt acts not alleged may be given in evidence.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-5 Proof of corporate existence or powers generally.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In a criminal case the existence, constitution or powers of any corporation may be proved by general reputation, or by the printed statutes of the state, government or country by which this corporation was created.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-6 Lottery tickets -- Evidence.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-6(1): On a trial for violation of any of the lottery provisions of the Utah Criminal Code, it is not necessary to prove:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-6(1)(a): The existence of any lottery in which any lottery tickets shall purport to have been issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-6(1)(b): The actual signing of any ticket or share, or pretended share of any pretended lottery; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-6(1)(c): That any lottery ticket, share or interest was signed or issued by the authority of any manager, or of any person assuming to have authority as manager.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-6(2): In all cases, proof of the sale, furnishing, bartering or procuring of any lottery ticket, share or interest therein, or of any instrument purporting to be a ticket, or part or share of any ticket shall be evidence that the share or interest was signed and issued according to its purport.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-7 Conviction on testimony of accomplice -- Instruction to jury.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-7(1): A conviction may be had on the uncorroborated testimony of an accomplice.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-7(2): In the discretion of the court, an instruction to the jury may be given to the effect that such uncorroborated testimony should be viewed with caution, and such an instruction shall be given if the trial judge finds the testimony of the accomplice to be self contradictory, uncertain or improbable.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-8 Mistake in charging offense -- Procedure -- Witnesses.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-8(1): 77-20-102; 77-20-205(4) If, at any time before verdict or judgment, a mistake is made in charging the proper offense, and there is probable cause to believe that the defendant is chargeable with another offense, the court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-8(1)(a): 77-20-102 release the individual on the individual's own recognizance, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-8(1)(b): 77-20-205(4) designate a condition, or a combination of conditions, described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-8(1)(c): order the individual be detained during the time the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-8(2): 77-20-102 A court may require a witness to post monetary bail, as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-9 Separation or sequestration of jurors -- Oath of officer having custody.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-9(1): The court, at any time before the submission of the case to the jury, may permit the jury to separate or order that it be sequestered in charge of a proper officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-9(2): If the jury is sequestered the officer shall be sworn to keep the jurors together until the next meeting of the court, to prevent any person from speaking or communicating with them, and not to do so himself on any subject connected with the trial, and to return the jury to the court pursuant to its order.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-10 Court to determine law; the jury, the facts.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-10(1): In a jury trial, questions of law are to be determined by the court, questions of fact by the jury.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-10(2): The jury may find a general verdict which includes questions of law as well as fact but they are bound to follow the law as stated by the court.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-11 Jury to retire for deliberation -- Oath of officer having custody.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
After hearing the court's instructions and arguments of counsel, the jury shall retire for deliberation. An officer shall be sworn to keep them together in some private and convenient place and not permit any person to speak to or communicate with them or to do so himself except upon the order of the court, or to ask them whether they have agreed on a verdict. He shall return them to court when they have agreed and the court has so ordered, or when otherwise ordered by the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-12 Defendant on bail appearing for trial may be committed.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
When a defendant who has given bail appears for trial, the court may, at any time after his appearance for trial, order him to be committed to the custody of the proper officer to await the judgment or further order of the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13 Expert testimony generally -- Notice requirements.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(1)(a): If the prosecution or the defense intends to call any expert to testify in a felony case at trial or any hearing, excluding a preliminary hearing held pursuant to Rule 7 of the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure, the party intending to call the expert shall give notice to the opposing party as soon as practicable but not less than 30 days before trial or 10 days before the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(1)(b): Notice shall include the name and address of the expert, the expert's curriculum vitae, and one of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(1)(b)(i): a copy of the expert's report, if one exists; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(1)(b)(ii): a written explanation of the expert's proposed testimony sufficient to give the opposing party adequate notice to prepare to meet the testimony; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(1)(b)(iii): a notice that the expert is available to cooperatively consult with the opposing party on reasonable notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(1)(c): The party intending to call the expert is responsible for any fee charged by the expert for the consultation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(2): If an expert's anticipated testimony will be based in whole or part on the results of any tests or other specialized data, the party intending to call the witness shall provide to the opposing party the information upon request.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(3): (1)(b) As soon as practicable after receipt of the expert's report or the information concerning the expert's proposed testimony, the party receiving notice shall provide to the other party notice of witnesses whom the party anticipates calling to rebut the expert's testimony, including the information required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(4)(a): If the defendant or the prosecution fails to substantially comply with the requirements of this section, the opposing party shall, if necessary to prevent substantial prejudice, be entitled to a continuance of the trial or hearing sufficient to allow preparation to meet the testimony.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(4)(b): If the court finds that the failure to comply with this section is the result of bad faith on the part of any party or attorney, the court shall impose appropriate sanctions.  The remedy of exclusion of the expert's testimony will only apply if the court finds that a party deliberately violated the provisions of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(5)(a): For purposes of this section, testimony of an expert at a preliminary hearing held pursuant to Rule 7 of the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure constitutes notice of the expert, the expert's qualifications, and a report of the expert's proposed trial testimony as to the subject matter testified to by the expert at the preliminary hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(5)(b): Upon request, the party who called the expert at the preliminary hearing shall provide the opposing party with a copy of the expert's curriculum vitae as soon as practicable prior to trial or any hearing at which the expert may be called as an expert witness.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-17-13(6): This section does not apply to the use of an expert who is an employee of the state or its political subdivisions, so long as the opposing party is on reasonable notice through general discovery that the expert may be called as a witness at trial, and the witness is made available to cooperatively consult with the opposing party upon reasonable notice.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 18 - The Judgment
**********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "The Judgment."

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(1): 77-1-3 "Assessment" means the same as the term "risk and needs assessment" in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(2): "Board" means the Board of Pardons and Parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(3): 77-32b-102 "Civil accounts receivable" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(4): 77-32b-102 "Civil judgment of restitution" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(5): 76-3-201 "Convicted" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(6): 77-32b-102 "Criminal accounts receivable" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(7): 77-32b-102 "Default" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(8): 77-32b-102 "Delinquent" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(9): 64-13-2 "Department" means the Department of Corrections created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(10): "Habitual offender" means an individual who has been convicted in:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(10)(a): at least six cases for one or more felony offenses in each case; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(10)(b): each case described in Subsection (10)(a) within five years before the day on which the defendant is convicted of the felony offense before the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(11): 77-32b-102 "Payment schedule" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(12): 77-38b-102 "Restitution" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(13): "Screening" means a tool or questionnaire that is designed to determine whether an individual needs further assessment or any additional resource or referral for treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-102(14): "Substance use disorder treatment" means treatment obtained through a substance use disorder program that is licensed by the Office of Licensing within the Department of Health and Human Services.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103 Presentence investigation report -- Classification of presentence investigation report -- Evidence or other information at sentencing.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(1): Before the imposition of a sentence, the court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(1)(a): upon agreement of the defendant, continue the date for the imposition of the sentence for a reasonable period of time for the purpose of obtaining a presentence investigation report from the department or a law enforcement agency, or information from any other source about the defendant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(1)(b): if the defendant is convicted of a felony or a class A misdemeanor, request that the department or a law enforcement agency prepare a presentence investigation report for the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(2)(a): Notwithstanding Subsection (1), if a defendant is convicted of a felony offense and the defendant is a habitual offender, the prosecuting attorney shall notify the court that the defendant is a habitual offender.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(2)(b): Upon a notification under Subsection (2)(a), the court may not impose a sentence for the conviction without ordering and obtaining a presentence investigation report, unless the court finds good cause to proceed with sentencing without the presentence investigation report.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(3): 77-18-109; 77-38b-203; 77-38b-203; 17-22-5.5 If a presentence investigation report is required under Subsection (2) or the standards established by the department described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(3)(a): 77-38b-203 any impact statement provided by a victim as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(3)(b): 77-38b-203 information on restitution as described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(3)(c): recommendations for treatment for the defendant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(3)(d): 17-22-5.5 the number of days since the commission of the offense that the defendant has spent in the custody of the jail and the number of days, if any, the defendant was released to a supervised release program or an alternative incarceration program under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(4): The department or law enforcement agency shall provide the presentence investigation report to the defendant's attorney, or the defendant if the defendant is not represented by counsel, the prosecuting attorney, and the court for review within three working days before the day on which the defendant is sentenced.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(5)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(5)(a)(i): If there is an alleged inaccuracy in the presentence investigation report that is not resolved by the parties and the department or law enforcement agency before sentencing:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(5)(a)(i)(A): the alleged inaccuracy shall be brought to the attention of the court at sentencing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(5)(a)(i)(B): the court may grant an additional 10 working days after the day on which the alleged inaccuracy is brought to the court's attention to allow the parties and the department to resolve the alleged inaccuracy in the presentence investigation report.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(5)(a)(ii): If the court does not grant additional time under Subsection (5)(a)(i)(B), or the alleged inaccuracy cannot be resolved after 10 working days, and if the court finds that there is an inaccuracy in the presentence investigation report, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(5)(a)(ii)(A): enter a written finding as to the relevance and accuracy of the challenged portion of the presentence investigation report; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(5)(a)(ii)(B): provide the written finding to the department or the law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(5)(b): The department shall attach the written finding to the presentence investigation report as an addendum.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(5)(c): If a party fails to challenge the accuracy of the presentence investigation report at the time of sentencing, the matter shall be considered waived.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(6): The contents of the presentence investigation report are protected and not available except by court order for purposes of sentencing as provided by rule of the Judicial Council or for use by the department or law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(7): 63G-2-403; 63G-2-404
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(7)(a): A presentence investigation report is classified as protected in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(7)(b): 63G-2-403; 63G-2-404 Notwithstanding Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8): 63G-2-202; 64-13-25 Except for disclosure at the time of sentencing in accordance with this section, the department or law enforcement agency may disclose a presentence investigation only when:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(a): 63G-2-202 ordered by the court in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(b): requested by a law enforcement agency or other agency approved by the department for purposes of supervision, confinement, and treatment of a defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(c): requested by the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(d): requested by the subject of the presentence investigation report or the subject's authorized representative;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(e): requested by the victim of the offense discussed in the presentence investigation report, or the victim's authorized representative, if the disclosure is only information relating to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(e)(i): statements or materials provided by the victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(e)(ii): the circumstances of the offense, including statements by the defendant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(e)(iii): the impact of the offense on the victim or the victim's household; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(f): 64-13-25 requested by a sex offender treatment provider:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(f)(i): 64-13-25 who is certified to provide treatment under the certification program established in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(f)(ii): who is providing, at the time of the request, sex offender treatment to the offender who is the subject of the presentence investigation report; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(f)(iii): who provides written assurance to the department that the report:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(f)(iii)(A): is necessary for the treatment of the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(f)(iii)(B): will be used solely for the treatment of the defendant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(8)(f)(iii)(C): will not be disclosed to an individual or entity other than the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(9)(a): At the time of sentence, the court shall receive any testimony, evidence, or information that the defendant or the prosecuting attorney desires to present concerning the appropriate sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(9)(b): Testimony, evidence, or information under Subsection (9)(a) shall be presented in open court on record and in the presence of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-103(10): The court may not rely solely on an algorithm or a risk assessment tool score in determining the appropriate sentence for a defendant.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105 Pleas held in abeyance -- Suspension of a sentence -- Probation -- Supervision -- Terms and conditions of probation -- Time periods for probation -- Bench supervision for payments on criminal accounts receivable.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(1): If a defendant enters a plea of guilty or no contest in conjunction with a plea in abeyance agreement, the court may hold the plea in abeyance:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(1)(a): in accordance with Chapter 2a, Pleas in Abeyance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(1)(b): under the terms of the plea in abeyance agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(2): 76-3-201 If a defendant is convicted, the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(2)(a): 76-3-201 shall impose a sentence in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(2)(b): subject to Subsection (5), may suspend the execution of the sentence and place the defendant:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(2)(b)(i): on probation under the supervision of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(2)(b)(ii): on probation under the supervision of an agency of a local government or a private organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(2)(b)(iii): on court probation under the jurisdiction of the sentencing court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(3)(a): The legal custody of all probationers under the supervision of the department is with the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(3)(b): The legal custody of all probationers under the jurisdiction of the sentencing court is vested as ordered by the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(3)(c): The court has continuing jurisdiction over all probationers.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(4): 17-55-201
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(4)(a): Court probation may include an administrative level of services, including notification to the sentencing court of scheduled periodic reviews of the probationer's compliance with conditions.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(4)(b): Supervised probation services provided by the department, an agency of a local government, or a private organization shall specifically address the defendant's risk of reoffending as identified by a screening or an assessment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(4)(c): 17-55-201 If a court orders supervised probation and determines that a public probation provider is unavailable or inappropriate to supervise the defendant, the court shall make available to the defendant the list of private probation providers prepared by a criminal justice coordinating council under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(5)(a): Before ordering supervised probation, the court shall consider the supervision costs to the defendant for each entity that can supervise the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(5)(b)(i): A court may order an agency of a local government to supervise the probation for an individual convicted of any crime if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(5)(b)(i)(A): the agency has the capacity to supervise the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(5)(b)(i)(B): the individual's supervision needs will be met by the agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(5)(b)(ii): A court may only order:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(5)(b)(ii)(A): the department to supervise the probation for an individual convicted of a class A misdemeanor or any felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(5)(b)(ii)(B): a private organization to supervise the probation for an individual convicted of a class A, B, or C misdemeanor or an infraction.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(5)(c): A court may not order a specific private organization to supervise an individual unless there is only one private organization that can provide the specific supervision services required to meet the individual's supervision needs.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6): 77-18-106; 77-18-107; 76-3-410
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(a): 77-18-106; 77-18-107; 76-3-410 If a defendant is placed on probation, the court may order the defendant as a condition of the defendant's probation:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(a)(i): to provide for the support of persons for whose support the defendant is legally liable;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(a)(ii): to participate in available treatment programs, including any treatment program in which the defendant is currently participating if the program is acceptable to the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(a)(iii): 77-18-106 be voluntarily admitted to the custody of the Division of Substance Abuse and Mental Health for treatment at the Utah State Hospital in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(a)(iv): if the defendant is on probation for a felony offense, to serve a period of time as an initial condition of probation that does not exceed one year in a county jail designated by the department, after considering any recommendation by the court as to which jail the court finds most appropriate;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(a)(v): 77-18-107 to serve a term of home confinement in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(a)(vi): 76-3-410 to participate in compensatory service programs, including the compensatory service program described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(a)(vii): to pay for the costs of investigation, probation, or treatment services;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(a)(viii): to pay restitution to a victim with interest in accordance with Chapter 38b, Crime Victims Restitution Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(a)(ix): to comply with other terms and conditions the court considers appropriate to ensure public safety or increase a defendant's likelihood of success on probation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(b)(i): Notwithstanding Subsection (6)(a)(iv), the court may modify the probation of a defendant to include a period of time that is served in a county jail immediately before the termination of probation as long as that period of time does not exceed one year.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(6)(b)(ii): If a defendant is ordered to serve time in a county jail as a sanction for a probation violation, the one-year limitation described in Subsection (6)(a)(iv) or (6)(b)(i) does not apply to the period of time that the court orders the defendant to serve in a county jail under this Subsection (6)(b)(ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(7): 63M-7-401.1; 63M-7-401.1; 64-13-21; 76-7-201
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(7)(a): 63M-7-401.1; 63M-7-401.1 Except as provided in Subsection (7)(b), probation of an individual placed on probation after December 31, 2018:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(7)(a)(i): may not exceed the individual's maximum sentence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(7)(a)(ii): 63M-7-401.1 shall be for a period of time that is in accordance with the adult sentencing and supervision length guidelines, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(7)(a)(iii): 63M-7-401.1 shall be terminated in accordance with the adult sentencing and supervision length guidelines, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(7)(b): Probation of an individual placed on probation after December 31, 2018, whose maximum sentence is one year or less, may not exceed 36 months.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(7)(c): 64-13-21 Probation of an individual placed on probation on or after October 1, 2015, but before January 1, 2019, may be terminated at any time at the discretion of the court or upon completion without violation of 36 months probation in felony or class A misdemeanor cases, 12 months in cases of class B or C misdemeanors or infractions, or as allowed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(7)(d): 76-7-201 This Subsection (7) does not apply to the probation of an individual convicted of an offense for criminal nonsupport under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(8): 77-32b-103; 77-18-114; 76-7-201
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(8)(a): 77-32b-103 Notwithstanding Subsection (7), if there is an unpaid balance of the criminal accounts receivable for the defendant upon termination of the probation period for the defendant under Subsection (7), the court may require the defendant to continue to make payments towards the criminal accounts receivable in accordance with the payment schedule established by the court under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(8)(c): 77-18-114 If the court requires a defendant to continue to pay in accordance with the payment schedule for the criminal accounts receivable under this Subsection (8) and the defendant defaults on the criminal accounts receivable, the court shall proceed with an order for a civil judgment of restitution and a civil accounts receivable for the defendant as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(8)(d):

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-105(8)(d)(ii): A court may hold a defendant in contempt for failure to make payments for a criminal accounts receivable in accordance with Title 78B, Chapter 6, Part 3, Contempt.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-106 Treatment at the Utah State Hospital -- Condition of probation or stay of sentence.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The court may order as a condition of probation, or a stay of sentence, that the defendant be voluntarily admitted to the custody of the Office of Substance Use and Mental Health for treatment at the Utah State Hospital only if the superintendent of the Utah State Hospital, or the superintendent's designee, certifies to the court that:Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-106(1): the defendant is appropriate for, and can benefit from, treatment at the Utah State Hospital;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-106(2): there is space at the Utah State Hospital for treatment of the defendant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-106(3): 26B-5-306(2)(g) individuals described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-107 Home confinement -- Electronic monitoring for home confinement.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-107(1): 76-3-406; 76-5-406.5 The court may order home confinement as a condition of probation under the supervision of the department, except as provided in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-107(2): The department shall establish procedures and standards for home confinement for all defendants supervised by the department for home confinement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-107(3): (1) If the court places the defendant on probation and orders the defendant to participate in home confinement under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-107(4): The electronic monitoring of a defendant shall alert the department and the appropriate law enforcement agency of the defendant's whereabouts.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-107(5): An electronic monitoring device shall be used under conditions that require:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-107(5)(a): the defendant to wear an electronic monitoring device at all times; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-107(5)(b): the device be placed in the home of the defendant to monitor the defendant's compliance with the court's order.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108 Termination, revocation, modification, or extension of probation -- Violation of probation -- Hearing on violation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(a): The department shall send a written notice to the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(a)(i): when the department is recommending termination of supervision for a defendant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(a)(ii): before a defendant's supervision will be terminated by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(b): The written notice under this Subsection (1) shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(b)(i): a probation progress report; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(b)(ii): if the department is responsible for the collection of the defendant's criminal accounts receivable, a summary of the criminal accounts receivable, including the amount of restitution ordered and the amount of restitution that has been paid.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(c)(i): Upon receipt of the written notice under Subsection (1)(a), the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(c)(i)(A): file the written notice on the docket; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(c)(i)(B): provide notice to all parties in the criminal case.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(c)(ii): A party shall have a reasonable opportunity to respond to the written notice under Subsection (1)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(1)(d): If a defendant's probation is being terminated, and the defendant's criminal accounts receivable has an unpaid balance or there is any outstanding debt with the department, the department shall send a written notice to the Office of State Debt Collection with a summary of the defendant's criminal accounts receivable, including the amount of restitution ordered and the amount of restitution that has been paid.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(2): 63M-7-401.1; 77-38b-205
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(2)(a): 63M-7-401.1 The court may modify the defendant's probation in accordance with the adult sentencing and supervision length guidelines, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(2)(b): 77-38b-205 The court may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(2)(b)(i): extend the length of a defendant's probation, except upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(2)(b)(i)(A): waiver of a hearing by the defendant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(2)(b)(i)(B): a hearing and a finding by the court that the defendant has violated the terms of probation;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(2)(b)(ii): revoke a defendant's probation, except upon a hearing and a finding by the court that the terms of probation have been violated; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(2)(b)(iii): 77-38b-205 terminate a defendant's probation before expiration of the probation period until the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(2)(b)(iii)(A): reviews the docket to determine whether the defendant owes a balance on the defendant's criminal accounts receivable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(2)(b)(iii)(B): 77-38b-205 enters a finding of whether the defendant owes restitution under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(2)(c): The court may find under Subsection (2)(b)(iii)(B) that the defendant does not owe restitution if no request for restitution has been filed with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(a): Upon the filing of an affidavit, or an unsworn written declaration executed in substantial compliance with Title 78B, Chapter 18a, Uniform Unsworn Declarations Act, alleging with particularity facts asserted to constitute violation of the terms of a defendant's probation, the court shall determine if the affidavit or unsworn written declaration establishes probable cause to believe that revocation, modification, or extension of the defendant's probation is justified.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(b)(i): If the court determines there is probable cause, the court shall order that the defendant be served with:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(b)(i)(A): a warrant for the defendant's arrest or a copy of the affidavit or unsworn written declaration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(b)(i)(B): an order to show cause as to why the defendant's probation should not be revoked, modified, or extended.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(b)(ii): The order under Subsection (3)(b)(i)(B) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(b)(ii)(A): be served upon the defendant at least five days before the day on which the hearing is held;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(b)(ii)(B): specify the time and place of the hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(b)(ii)(C): inform the defendant of the right to be represented by counsel at the hearing, the right to have counsel appointed if the defendant is indigent, and the right to present evidence at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(b)(iii): The defendant shall show good cause for a continuance of the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(c): At the hearing, the defendant shall admit or deny the allegations of the affidavit or unsworn written declaration.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(d)(i): If the defendant denies the allegations of the affidavit or unsworn written declaration, the prosecuting attorney shall present evidence on the allegations.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(d)(ii): If the affidavit, or unsworn written declaration, alleges that a defendant is delinquent, or in default, on a criminal accounts receivable, the prosecuting attorney shall present evidence to establish, by a preponderance of the evidence, that the defendant:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-108(3)(d)(ii)(A): was aware of the defendant's obligation to pay the balance of the criminal accounts receivable;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-109 Standards for supervision and presentence investigation.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-109(1)(a): the type of offense;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-109(1)(c): the demand for services;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-109(1)(d): the availability of agency resources;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-109(1)(e): public safety; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-109(1)(f): other criteria established by the department to determine what level of services shall be provided.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-109(2): The department shall submit proposed supervision and presentence investigation standards annually to the Judicial Council and the board for review and comment before the department adopts the standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-109(3): The Judicial Council and the department shall establish procedures to implement the supervision and presentence investigation standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-109(4): (1) The Judicial Council and the department shall annually consider modifications to the standards based upon criteria in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-109(5): The Judicial Council and the department shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-109(5)(b): submit the impact report to the appropriate legislative appropriations subcommittee.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-110 Disposition of fines.
-----------------------------------------------------
A fine imposed by the district court shall be paid in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-111 Sentence -- Term -- Construction.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-111(1): If an individual is convicted of a crime and the judgment provides for a commitment to the state prison, the court shall not fix a definite term of imprisonment unless otherwise provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-111(2): The sentence and judgment of imprisonment shall be for an indeterminate term of not less than the minimum and not to exceed the maximum term provided by law for the particular crime.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-111(3): Except as otherwise expressly provided by law, every sentence, regardless of the sentence's form or terms, which purports to be for a shorter or different period of time, shall be construed to be a sentence for the term between the minimum and maximum periods of time provided by law and shall continue until the maximum period has been reached unless sooner terminated or commuted by authority of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-111(4): 76-3-208; 76-3-403; 77-27-5.4
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-111(4)(a): A court may not order that a term of imprisonment commences before the day upon which the sentence of imprisonment is imposed, except to correct a sentence consistent with Rule 22(e) or 30(b) of the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-111(4)(b): 76-3-208; 76-3-403; 77-27-5.4 The board may grant an individual credit for time served or other credit against a sentence, including as provided in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-112 Reports by courts and prosecuting attorneys to Board of Pardons and Parole.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In cases where an indeterminate sentence is imposed, the court and prosecuting attorney may, within 30 days, mail a statement to the board setting forth the term for which the prisoner ought to be imprisoned together with any information which might aid the board in passing on the application for termination or commutation of the sentence or for parole or pardon.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-116 Costs imposed on defendant -- Restrictions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless specifically authorized by statute, a defendant shall not be required to pay court costs in a criminal case as:Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-116(1): a part of a sentence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-116(2): a condition of probation or dismissal.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-117 Fine not paid -- Commitment.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-117(1): When a defendant is sentenced to pay a fine in addition to a jail or a prison sentence and the judgment is that the jail or prison sentence be suspended upon payment of the fine, the service of the jail or prison sentence shall satisfy the judgment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-117(2): If a defendant fails to pay the fine and the court finds that the defendant failed to make a good faith effort to pay the fine, the court may, after a hearing, order the execution of the suspended jail or prison sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-18-117(3): If a defendant is sentenced to pay a fine only, or is sentenced to jail or prison and a fine, with neither suspended, the defendant may not later be committed to jail for failure to pay the fine.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-18a-2 Capital cases.
---------------------------------------------
After the resolution of an initial appeal of a capital case when the sentence of death has been imposed, a subsequent appeal may not be entertained by any court and a stay of execution of the sentence may not be granted when the appeal does not raise any new matter not previously resolved or when the new matter could have been raised at the previous appeal.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 19 - The Execution
***********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-1 Judgment for fine or costs -- Enforcement.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the judgment is for a fine or costs when allowed by statute and the fine is not paid as ordered by the court, execution or garnishment may be issued as on a judgment in a civil action. The prosecuting attorney, upon written request of the court clerk, shall effectuate collection through execution or garnishment when the fine or costs have not been paid as ordered by the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-2 Judgment of imprisonment -- Commitment.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
If the judgment is for imprisonment, the sheriff of the county or other appropriate custodial officer designated by the court shall, upon receipt of a certified copy of the judgment, deliver the defendant to the warden of the state prison or keeper of the jail. Such custodial officer shall also deliver a certified copy of the judgment and take a receipt from the warden or keeper of the jail for the defendant and return it to the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-3 Special release from city or county jail -- Purposes.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-3(1): (2) Any person incarcerated in any city or county jail may, in accordance with the release policy of the facility, be released from jail during those hours which are reasonable and necessary to accomplish any of the purposes under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-3(1)(a): the offense is not one for which release is prohibited under state law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-3(1)(b): the judge has not entered an order prohibiting a special release.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-3(2): (1) The custodial authority at the jail may release an inmate who qualifies under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-3(2)(a): working at his employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-3(2)(b): seeking employment;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-3(2)(d): obtaining necessary medical treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-3(2)(e): any other reasonable purpose as determined by the custodial authority of the jail.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-4 Special release from city or county jail -- Conditions and limitations.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-4(1): 77-19-3 All released prisoners under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-4(2): The judge may order that the prisoner:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-4(2)(a): pay money earned from employment during the jail term to those persons he is legally responsible to support; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-4(2)(b): retain sufficient money to pay his costs of transportation, meals, and other incidental and necessary expenses related to his special release.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-4(3): The custodial authority of the jail shall establish all other conditions of special release.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-4(4): During all hours when the prisoner is not serving the function for which he is awarded release time, he shall be confined to jail.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-4(5): The prisoner shall obtain his own transportation to and from the place where he performs the function for which he is released.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-5 Special release from city or county jail -- Revocation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The judge may, for good cause, revoke any release time previously awarded, and shall notify the prisoner that, if he makes written request, a hearing shall be afforded to him to challenge the revocation.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-6 Judgment of death -- Warrant -- Delivery of warrant -- Determination of execution time.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-6(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-6(1)(a): When judgment of death is rendered, a warrant, signed by the judge and attested by the clerk under the seal of the court, shall be drawn and delivered to the sheriff of the county where the conviction is had.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-6(1)(b): The sheriff shall deliver the warrant and a certified copy of the judgment to the executive director of the Department of Corrections or the executive director's designee at the time of delivering the defendant to the custody of the Department of Corrections.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-6(2): 63G-1-301 The warrant shall state the conviction, the judgment, the method of execution, and the appointed day the judgment is to be executed, which may not be fewer than 30 days nor more than 60 days from the date of issuance of the warrant, and may not be a Sunday, Monday, or a legal holiday, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-6(3): The Department of Corrections shall determine the hour, within the appointed day, at which the judgment is to be executed.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-7 Judgment of death -- Statement to Board of Pardons and Parole.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The judge of a court where a judgment of death was had shall, immediately after the conviction, transmit to the chair of the Board of Pardons and Parole a statement of the conviction and judgment and a summary of the evidence given at trial.
