Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-9 Judgment of death not executed -- Order for execution.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-9(1): If for any reason a judgment of death has not been executed and remains in force, the court where the conviction was had, on application of the prosecuting attorney, shall order the defendant to be brought before it or, if the defendant is at large, issue a warrant for the defendant's apprehension.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-9(2): 63G-1-301; 77-19-6 When the defendant is brought before the court, it shall inquire into the facts and, if no legal reason exists against the execution of judgment, the court shall make an order requiring the executive director of the Department of Corrections or the executive director's designee to ensure that the judgment is executed on a specified day, which may not be fewer than 30 nor more than 60 days after the court's order, and may not be a Sunday, Monday, or a legal holiday, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-9(3): The Department of Corrections shall determine the hour, within the appointed day, at which the judgment is to be executed.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-10 Judgment of death -- Location and procedures for execution.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-10(1): 77-18-113 The executive director of the Department of Corrections or a designee shall ensure that the method of judgment of death specified in the warrant or as required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-10(2): When the judgment of death is to be carried out by lethal intravenous injection, the executive director of the department or a designee shall select two or more persons trained in accordance with accepted medical practices to administer intravenous injections, who shall each administer a continuous intravenous injection, one of which shall be of a lethal quantity of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-10(2)(a): sodium thiopental; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-10(2)(b): other equally or more effective substance sufficient to cause death.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-10(3): 77-18-113(2); (3); (4) If the judgment of death is to be carried out by firing squad under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-10(4): 77-18-113(2); (3); (4) Compensation for persons administering intravenous injections and for members of a firing squad under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-10(5): Death under this section shall be certified by a physician.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-10(6): The department shall adopt and enforce rules governing procedures for the execution of judgments of death.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11 Who may be present -- Photographic and recording equipment.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(1)(a): "Close relative of the deceased victim" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(1)(a)(i): the spouse of the victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(1)(a)(ii): a parent or stepparent of the victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(1)(a)(iii): a brother, sister, stepbrother, stepsister, child, or stepchild of the victim; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(1)(a)(iv): any person who had a close relationship with the deceased victim, or with a close relative of the victim, upon the recommendation of the victim assistance coordinator for the Department of Corrections or for the Office of the Attorney General.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(1)(b): "Director" means the executive director of the Department of Corrections, or the director's designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(2): (1)(a) At the discretion of the director, the following persons may attend the execution:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(2)(a): the prosecuting attorney, or a designated deputy, of the county in which the defendant committed the offense for which he is being executed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(2)(b): no more than two law enforcement officials from the county in which the defendant committed the offense for which he is being executed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(2)(c): the attorney general or a designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(2)(d): religious representatives, friends, or relatives designated by the defendant, not exceeding a total of five persons; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(2)(e): (1)(a) unless approved by the director, no more than five close relatives of the deceased victim, as selected by the director, but giving priority in the order listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(3): (2) The persons listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(4): The director shall permit the attendance at the execution of members of the press and broadcast news media:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(4)(a): as named by the director in accordance with rules of the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(4)(b): with the agreement of the selected news media members that they serve as a pool for other members of the news media.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(5): (5)(b); (5)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(5)(a): (5)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(5)(b): Audio recording equipment may be used by the department for the purpose of recording the defendant's last words.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(5)(c): (5)(b) The department shall permanently destroy the recording made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(5)(d): A violation of this subsection is a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(6): All persons in attendance are subject to reasonable search as a condition of attendance.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(7)(a): The following persons may also attend the execution:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(7)(a)(i): staff as determined by the director; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(7)(a)(ii): no more than three correctional officials from other states that are preparing for executions, but no more than two correctional officials may be from any one state, as designated by the director.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(7)(b): A person younger than 18 years of age may not attend.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-11(8): The department shall adopt rules governing the attendance of persons, including the number of media representatives, at the execution.  These rules shall be in accordance with this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-12 Return upon death warrant.
---------------------------------------------------------
After the execution, the executive director of the Department of Corrections or his designee shall make a return upon the death warrant, showing the time, place, and manner in which it was executed.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-201 Definition.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part, "incompetent to be executed" means that, due to mental condition, an inmate is unaware of either the punishment he is about to suffer or why he is to suffer it.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-202 Incompetency or pregnancy of person sentenced to death -- Procedures.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-202(1): If, after judgment of death, the executive director of the Department of Corrections has good reason to believe that an inmate sentenced to death is pregnant, or has good reason to believe that an inmate's competency to be executed under this chapter should be addressed by a court, the executive director of the Department of Corrections or the executive director's designee shall immediately give written notice to the court in which the judgment of death was rendered, to the prosecuting attorney, and counsel for the inmate.  The judgment shall be stayed pending further order of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-202(2): (1); 77-19-204; 77-19-6; 63G-1-301
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-202(2)(a): (1); 77-19-204 On receipt of the notice under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-202(2)(b): If the inmate is found incompetent, the court shall immediately transmit a certificate of the findings to the Board of Pardons and Parole and continue the stay of execution pending further order of the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-202(2)(c): 77-19-6; 63G-1-301 If the inmate is subsequently found competent at any time, the judge shall immediately transmit a certificate of the findings to the Board of Pardons and Parole, and shall draw and have delivered another warrant under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-202(3): 77-19-6; 63G-1-301
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-202(3)(a): If the court finds the inmate is pregnant, it shall immediately transmit a certificate of the finding to the Board of Pardons and Parole and to the executive director of the Department of Corrections or the executive director's designee, and the court shall issue an order staying the execution of the judgment of death during the pregnancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-202(3)(b): 77-19-6; 63G-1-301 When the court determines the inmate is no longer pregnant, it shall immediately transmit a certificate of the finding to the Board of Pardons and Parole and draw and have delivered another warrant under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-202(4): The Department of Corrections shall determine the hour, within the appointed day, at which the judgment is to be executed.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-203 Petition for inquiry as to competency to be executed -- Filing -- Contents -- Successive petitions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-203(1): (2) If an inmate who has been sentenced to death is or becomes incompetent to be executed, a petition under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-203(2): The petition shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-203(2)(a): contain a certificate stating that it is filed in good faith and on reasonable grounds to believe the inmate is incompetent to be executed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-203(2)(b): contain a specific recital of the facts, observations, and conversations with the inmate that form the basis for the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-203(3): The petition may be based upon knowledge or information and belief and may be filed by the inmate alleged to be incompetent, legal counsel for the inmate, or by an attorney representing the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-203(4): Before ruling on a petition filed by an inmate or his counsel alleging that the inmate is incompetent to be executed, the court shall give the state and the Department of Corrections an opportunity to respond to the allegations of incompetency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-203(5): Title 77, Chapter 15, Inquiry into Sanity of Defendant If a petition is filed after an inmate has previously been found competent under either this chapter or under
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-203(5)(a): alleges with specificity a substantial change of circumstances subsequent to the previous determination of competency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-203(5)(b): is sufficient to raise a significant question about the inmate's competency to be executed.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204 Order for hearing -- Examinations of inmate -- Scope of examination and report.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(1): When a court has good reason to believe an inmate sentenced to death is incompetent to be executed, it shall stay the execution and shall order the Department of Health and Human Services to examine the inmate and report to the court concerning the inmate's mental condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(2)(a): (1) The inmate subject to examination under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(2)(b): The Department of Corrections shall provide information and materials to the examiners relevant to a determination of the inmate's competency to be executed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(3): The inmate shall make himself available and fully cooperate in the examination by the Department of Health and Human Services and any other independent examiners for the defense or the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(4): The examiners shall in the conduct of their examinations and in their reports to the court consider and address, in addition to any other factors determined to be relevant by the examiners:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(4)(a): the inmate's awareness of the fact of the inmate's impending execution;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(4)(b): the inmate's understanding that the inmate is to be executed for the crime of murder;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(4)(c): the nature of the inmate's mental disorder, if any, and its relationship to the factors relevant to the inmate's competency; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(4)(d): whether psychoactive medication is necessary to maintain or restore the inmate's competency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(5): The examiners who are examining the inmate shall each provide an initial report to the court and the attorneys for the state and the inmate within 60 days of the receipt of the court's order.  The report shall inform the court of the examiner's opinion concerning the competency of the inmate to be executed, or, in the alternative, the examiner may inform the court in writing that additional time is needed to complete the report.  If the examiner informs the court that additional time is needed, the examiner shall have up to an additional 30 days to provide the report to the court and counsel.  The examiner shall provide the report within 90 days from the receipt of the court's order unless, for good cause shown, the court authorizes an additional period of time to complete the examination and provide the report.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(6)(a): All interviews with the inmate conducted by the examiners shall be videotaped, unless otherwise ordered by the court for good cause shown.  The Department of Corrections shall provide the videotaping equipment and facilitate the videotaping of the interviews.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(6)(b): Immediately following the videotaping, the videotape shall be provided to the attorney for the state, who shall deliver it as soon as practicable to the judge in whose court the competency determination is pending.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(6)(c): The court shall grant counsel for the state and for the inmate, and examiners who are examining the inmate under this part access to view the videotape at the court building where the court is located that is conducting the competency determination under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(7): Any written report submitted by an examiner shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(7)(a): identify the specific matters referred for evaluation;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(7)(b): describe the procedures, techniques, and tests used in the examination and the purpose or purposes for each;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(7)(c): state the examiner's clinical observations, findings, and opinions on each issue referred for examination by the court, and indicate specifically those issues, if any, on which the examiner could not give an opinion; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(7)(d): identify the sources of information used by the examiner and present the basis for the examiner's clinical findings and opinions.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(8)(a): When the reports are received, the court shall set a date for a competency hearing, which shall be held within not less than five and not more than 15 days, unless the court extends the time for good cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(8)(b): Any examiner directed by the Department of Health and Human Services to conduct the examination may be subpoenaed to provide testimony at the hearing.  If the examiners are in conflict as to the competency of the inmate, all of them should be called to testify at the hearing if they are reasonably available.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(8)(c): The court may call any examiner to testify at the hearing who is not called by the parties.  An examiner called by the court may be cross-examined by counsel for the parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(9)(a): An inmate shall be presumed competent to be executed unless the court, by a preponderance of the evidence, finds the inmate incompetent to be executed.  The burden of proof is upon the proponent of incompetency at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(9)(b): An adjudication of incompetency to be executed does not operate as an adjudication of the inmate's incompetency to give informed consent for medical treatment or for any other purpose, unless specifically set forth in the court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(10): (4)(a); (d)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(10)(a): (4)(a); (d) If the court finds the inmate incompetent to be executed, its order shall contain findings addressing each of the factors in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(10)(b): The order finding the inmate incompetent to be executed shall be delivered to the Department of Health and Human Services, and shall be accompanied by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(10)(b)(i): copies of the reports of the examiners filed with the court pursuant to the order of examination, if not provided previously;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(10)(b)(ii): copies of any of the psychiatric, psychological, or social work reports submitted to the court relative to the mental condition of the inmate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(10)(b)(iii): any other documents made available to the court by either the defense or the state, pertaining to the inmate's current or past mental condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-204(10)(c): A copy of the order finding the inmate incompetent to be executed shall be delivered to the Department of Corrections.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205 Procedures on finding of incompetency to be executed -- Subsequent hearings -- Notice to attorneys.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(1): 77-19-204; (1)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(1)(a): 77-19-204; (1)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(1)(a)(i): 77-19-204 If after the hearing under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(1)(a)(ii): (1)(a)(i) Appropriate mental health treatment under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(1)(b): The court shall order the executive director of the Department of Health and Human Services to provide periodic assessments to the court regarding the inmate's competency to be executed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(1)(c): The inmate shall be held in secure confinement, either at the prison or the State Hospital, as agreed upon by the executive director of the Department of Corrections and the executive director of the Department of Health and Human Services.  If the inmate remains at the prison, the Department of Health and Human Services shall consult with the Department of Corrections regarding the inmate's mental health treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(2)(a): The examiner or examiners designated by the executive director of the Department of Health and Human Services to assess the inmate's progress toward competency may not be involved in the routine treatment of the inmate.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(2)(b): The examiner or examiners shall each provide a full report to the court and counsel for the state and the inmate within 90 days of receipt of the court's order.  If any examiner is unable to complete the assessment within 90 days, that examiner shall provide to the court and counsel for the state and the inmate a summary progress report which informs the court that additional time is necessary to complete the assessment, in which case the examiner has up to an additional 90 days to provide the full report, unless the court enlarges the time for good cause.  The full report shall assess:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(2)(b)(i): the facility's or program's capacity to provide appropriate treatment for the inmate;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(2)(b)(ii): the nature of treatments provided to the inmate;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(2)(b)(iii): what progress toward restoration of competency has been made;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(2)(b)(iv): the inmate's current level of mental disorder and need for treatment, if any; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(2)(b)(v): the likelihood of restoration of competency and the amount of time estimated to achieve it.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(3): The court on its own motion or upon motion by either party may order the Department of Health and Human Services to appoint additional mental health examiners to examine the inmate and advise the court on the inmate's current mental status and progress toward competency restoration.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(4)(a): Upon receipt of the full report, the court shall hold a hearing to determine the inmate's current status.  At the hearing, the burden of proving that the inmate is competent is on the proponent of competency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(4)(b): Following the hearing, the court shall determine by a preponderance of evidence whether the inmate is competent to be executed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(5): 77-19-202(2)(c); (1)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(5)(a): 77-19-202(2)(c) If the court determines that the inmate is competent to be executed, it shall enter findings and shall proceed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(5)(b): (1)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(5)(b)(i): If the court determines the inmate is still incompetent to be executed, the inmate shall continue to receive appropriate mental health treatment, and the court shall hold hearings no less frequently than at 18-month intervals for the purpose of determining the defendant's competency to be executed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(5)(b)(ii): (1)(a)(i) Continued appropriate mental health treatment under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(6): (6)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(6)(a): If at any time the clinical director of the Utah State Hospital or the primary treating mental health professional determines that the inmate has been restored to competency, he shall notify the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(6)(b): (6)(a) The court shall conduct a hearing regarding the inmate's competency to be executed within 30 working days of the receipt of the notification under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-205(7): Notice of a hearing on competency to be executed shall be given to counsel for the state and for the inmate, as well as to the office of the prosecutor who prosecuted the inmate on the original capital charge.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-19-206 Expenses -- Allocation.
-------------------------------------------------------
The Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Corrections shall each pay 1/2 of the costs of any examination of the inmate conducted pursuant to Sections

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 20 - Bail
**************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Bail."

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(1): "Bail" means pretrial release.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(2): 31A-35-102 "Bail bond" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(3): 31A-35-102 "Bail bond agency" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(4): 31A-35-102 "Bail bond producer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(5): "County jail official" means a county sheriff or the county sheriff's designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(6): "Exonerate" means to release and discharge a surety, or a surety's bail bond producer, from liability for a bail bond.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(7): "Financial condition" means any monetary condition that is imposed to secure an individual's pretrial release.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(8): "Forfeiture" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(8)(a): to divest an individual or surety from a right to the repayment of monetary bail; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(8)(b): to enforce a pledge of assets or real or personal property from an individual or surety used to secure an individual's pretrial release.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(9): 77-1-3 "Magistrate" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(10)(a): "Material change in circumstances" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(10)(a)(i): an unreasonable delay in prosecution that is not attributable to the defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(10)(a)(ii): a material change in the risk that an individual poses to a victim, a witness, or the public if released due to the passage of time or any other relevant factor;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(10)(a)(iii): a material change in the conditions of release or the services that are reasonably available to the defendant if released;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(10)(a)(iv): a willful or repeated failure by the defendant to appear at required court appearances; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(10)(a)(v): any other material change related to the defendant's risk of flight or danger to any other individual or to the community if released.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(10)(b): "Material change in circumstances" does not include any fact or consideration that is known at the time that the pretrial status order is issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(11): "Monetary bail" means a financial condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(12): "Own recognizance" means the release of an individual without any condition of release other than the individual's promise to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(12)(a): appear for all required court proceedings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(12)(b): not commit any criminal offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(13): 77-20-206 "Pretrial detention hearing" means a hearing described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(14): "Pretrial release" means the release of an individual from law enforcement custody during the time the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(15): "Pretrial risk assessment" means an objective, research-based, validated assessment tool that measures an individual's risk of flight and risk of anticipated criminal conduct while on pretrial release.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(16): "Pretrial services program" means a program that is established to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(16)(a): gather information on individuals booked into a jail facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(16)(b): conduct pretrial risk assessments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(16)(c): supervise individuals granted pretrial release.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(17): "Pretrial status order" means an order issued by a magistrate or judge that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(17)(a): releases the individual on the individual's own recognizance while the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(17)(b): sets the terms and conditions of the individual's pretrial release while the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(17)(c): denies pretrial release and orders that the individual be detained while the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(18): 31A-35-102 "Principal" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(19): "Surety" means a surety insurer or a bail bond agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(20): 31A-35-102 "Surety insurer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(21): "Temporary pretrial status order" means an order issued by a magistrate that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(21)(a): releases the individual on the individual's own recognizance until a pretrial status order is issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(21)(b): sets the terms and conditions of the individual's pretrial release until a pretrial status order is issued; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(21)(c): denies pretrial release and orders that the individual be detained until a pretrial status order is issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-102(22): "Unsecured bond" means an individual's promise to pay a financial condition if the individual fails to appear for any required court appearance.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103 Release data requirements.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1): (1)(b)(i); (1)(b)(i) The Administrative Office of the Courts shall submit the following data on cases involving individuals for whom the Administrative Office of the Courts has a state identification number broken down by judicial district to the Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice before July 1 of each year:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a): for the preceding calendar year:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(i): the number of individuals charged with a criminal offense who failed to appear at a required court preceding while on pretrial release under each of the following categories of release:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(i)(A): the individual's own recognizance;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(i)(B): a financial condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(i)(C): a release condition other than a financial condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(ii): the number of offenses that carry a potential penalty of incarceration an individual committed while on pretrial release under each of the following categories of release:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(ii)(A): the individual's own recognizance;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(ii)(B): a financial condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(ii)(C): a release condition other than a financial condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(iii): the total amount of fees and fines, including bond forfeiture, collected by the court from an individual for the individual's failure to comply with a condition of release under each of the following categories of release:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(iii)(A): an individual's own recognizance;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(iii)(B): a financial condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(a)(iii)(C): a release condition other than a financial condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(b): (1)(b)(i); (1)(b)(i) at the end of the preceding calendar year:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(b)(i): the total number of outstanding warrants of arrest for individuals who were released from law enforcement custody on pretrial release under each of the following categories of release:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(1)(b)(i)(A): the individual's own recognizance;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(2)(c): the amount of monetary bail, any fees, and any other money paid by or on behalf of individuals collected by the county jail.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-103(3): The Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice shall compile the data collected under this section and shall submit the compiled data in an electronic report to the Law Enforcement and Criminal Justice Interim Committee before November 1 of each year.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201 Right to bail -- Capital felony.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1): 76-9-101 An individual charged with, or arrested for, a criminal offense shall be admitted to bail as a matter of right, except if the individual is charged with:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(a): a capital felony when there is substantial evidence to support the charge;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(b): a felony committed while on parole or on probation for a felony conviction, or while free on bail awaiting trial on a previous felony charge, when there is substantial evidence to support the current felony charge;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(c): a felony when there is substantial evidence to support the charge and the court finds, by clear and convincing evidence, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(c)(i): the individual would constitute a substantial danger to any other individual or to the community after considering available conditions of release that the court may impose if the individual is released on bail; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(c)(ii): the individual is likely to flee the jurisdiction of the court if the individual is released on bail;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(d): a felony when there is substantial evidence to support the charge and the court finds, by clear and convincing evidence, that the individual violated a material condition of release while previously on bail;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(e): a domestic violence offense if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(e)(i): there is substantial evidence to support the charge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(e)(ii): the court finds, by clear and convincing evidence, that the individual would constitute a substantial danger to an alleged victim of domestic violence after considering available conditions of release that the court may impose if the individual is released on bail;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(f): the offense of driving under the influence or driving with a measurable controlled substance in the body if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(f)(i): the offense results in death or serious bodily injury to an individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(f)(ii): there is substantial evidence to support the charge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(f)(iii): the court finds, by clear and convincing evidence, that the individual would constitute a substantial danger to the community after considering available conditions of release that the court may impose if the individual is released on bail;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(g): 76-9-101 a felony violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(g)(i): there is substantial evidence to support the charge; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(g)(ii): the court finds, by clear and convincing evidence, that the individual is not likely to appear for a subsequent court appearance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(h): except as provided in Subsection (4), the offense of driving under the influence or driving with a measurable controlled substance in the body:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(h)(i): if committed while on parole or on probation for a driving under the influence or driving with a measurable controlled substance in the body conviction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(1)(h)(ii): while the individual is out of custody awaiting trial on a previous driving under the influence or driving with a measurable controlled substance in the body charge, when the court finds there is substantial evidence to support the current charge.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(2): Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, there is a rebuttable presumption that an individual is a substantial danger to the community under Subsection (1)(f)(iii):
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(2)(a): as long as the individual has a blood or breath alcohol concentration of .05 grams or greater if the individual is arrested for, or charged with, the offense of driving under the influence and the offense resulted in death or serious bodily injury to an individual; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(2)(b): if the individual has a measurable amount of controlled substance in the individual's body, the individual is arrested for, or charged with, the offense of driving with a measurable controlled substance in the body and the offense resulted in death or serious bodily injury to an individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(3): 76-5-202 For purposes of Subsection (1)(a), any arrest or charge for a violation of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(3)(a): the prosecuting attorney files a notice of intent to not seek the death penalty; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(3)(b): the time for filing a notice to seek the death penalty has expired and the prosecuting attorney has not filed a notice to seek the death penalty.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(4): 41-6a-506 For purposes of Subsection (1)(h), there is a rebuttable presumption that an individual would not constitute a substantial danger to any other person or the community if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(4)(a): the court orders the person to participate in an inpatient drug and alcohol treatment program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-201(4)(b): 41-6a-506 the court orders the person to participate in home confinement through the use of electronic monitoring as described in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202 Collection of pretrial information.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1): 77-36-2.1 When an individual is arrested without a warrant for an offense and booked at a jail facility, an employee at the jail facility, or an employee of a pretrial services program, shall submit the following information to the court with the probable cause statement:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(a): identification information for the individual, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(a)(i): the individual's legal name and any known aliases;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(a)(ii): the individual's date of birth;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(a)(iii): the individual's state identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(a)(iv): the individual's mobile phone number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(a)(v): the individual's email address;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(b): the individual's residential address;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(c): any pending criminal charge or warrant for the individual, including the offense tracking number of the current offense for which the individual is booked;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(d): the individual's probation or parole supervision status;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(e): whether the individual was on pretrial release for another criminal offense prior to the booking of the individual for the current criminal offense if the employee knows that the individual was on pretrial release for a prior criminal offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(f): the individual's financial circumstances to the best of the individual's knowledge at the time of booking, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(f)(i): the individual's current employer;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(f)(ii): the individual's monthly income, including any alimony or child support that contributes to the individual's monthly income;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(f)(iii): the individual's monthly expenses, including any alimony or child support obligation that the individual is responsible for paying;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(f)(iv): the individual's ownership of, or any interest in, personal or real property, including any savings or checking accounts or cash;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(f)(v): the number, ages, and relationships of any dependents;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(f)(vi): any financial support or benefit that the individual receives from a state or federal government; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(f)(vii): any other information about the individual's financial circumstances that may be relevant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(g): any ties the individual has to the community, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(g)(i): the length of time that the individual has been at the individual's residential address;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(g)(ii): any enrollment in a local college, university, or trade school; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(g)(iii): the name and contact information for any family member or friend that the individual believes would be willing to provide supervision of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(h): 77-36-2.1 the results of a lethality assessment completed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(1)(i): whether the individual is under the influence of alcohol or a controlled substance to a degree that would endanger the individual or another individual if the individual is released.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(2): Upon request, the jail facility, or the pretrial services program, shall provide the information described in Subsection (1) to the individual, the individual's attorney, or the prosecuting attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(3): Any information collected from an individual under Subsection (1) is inadmissible in any court proceeding other than:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(3)(a): a criminal proceeding addressing the individual's pretrial release or indigency for the offense, or offenses, for which the individual was arrested or charged with; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(3)(b): another criminal proceeding regarding prosecution for providing a false statement under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-202(4): Nothing in this section prohibits a court and a county from entering into an agreement regarding information to be submitted to the court with a probable cause statement.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(1): 77-36-1.1; 76-6-106; 78B-7-801; 76-3-203.5 As used in this section:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(2)(a): the individual was arrested without a warrant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(2)(b): 76-9-101 the individual was not arrested for:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(2)(c): law enforcement has not submitted a probable cause statement to a court or magistrate;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(2)(d): the individual agrees in writing to appear for any future criminal proceedings related to the arrest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(2)(e): the individual qualifies for release under the written policy described in Subsection (4) for the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(3): 64-13-29 A county jail official may not release an individual from a jail facility if the individual is subject to a 72-hour hold placed on the individual by the Department of Corrections as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(a): A county sheriff shall create and approve a written policy for the county that governs the release of an individual on the individual's own recognizance.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(b): The written policy shall describe the criteria an individual shall meet to be released on the individual's own recognizance.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(c): A county sheriff may include in the written policy the criteria for release relating to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(c)(i): criminal history;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(c)(ii): prior instances of failing to appear for a mandatory court appearance;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(c)(iv): residency;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(c)(v): ties to the community;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(c)(vi): an offense for which the individual was arrested;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(c)(vii): any potential criminal charges that have not yet been filed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(c)(viii): the individual's health condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(c)(ix): any potential risks to a victim, a witness, or the public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(4)(c)(x): any other similar factor a sheriff determines is relevant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (5)(b)(ii), a jail facility shall detain an individual for up to 24 hours from booking if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5)(a)(i): the individual is on supervised probation or parole and that information is reasonably available; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5)(a)(ii): the individual was arrested for:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5)(a)(ii)(A): a violent felony; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5)(a)(ii)(B): a qualifying domestic violence offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5)(b): The jail facility shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5)(b)(i): notify the entity supervising the individual's probation or parole that the individual is being detained; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5)(b)(ii): release the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5)(b)(ii)(A): to the Department of Corrections if the Department of Corrections supervises the individual and requests the individual's release; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5)(b)(ii)(B): if a court or magistrate orders release.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(5)(c): This Subsection (5) does not prohibit a jail facility from holding the individual in accordance with this chapter for a new criminal offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-203(6): This section does not prohibit a court and a county from entering into an agreement regarding release.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-204(7): Once a magistrate begins a review of an individual's case under Rule 9 of the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-204(7)(b): if a county jail official fixed a financial condition for the individual before the magistrate's review, the individual may no longer be released on the financial condition.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205 Pretrial release by a magistrate or judge.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(a): At the time that a magistrate issues a warrant of arrest, or finds there is probable cause to support the individual's arrest under Rule 9 of the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure, the magistrate shall issue a temporary pretrial status order that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(a)(i): releases the individual on the individual's own recognizance during the time the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(a)(ii): designates a condition, or a combination of conditions, to be imposed upon the individual's release during the time the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(a)(iii): orders the individual be detained during the time the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(b): At the time that a magistrate issues a summons, the magistrate may issue a temporary pretrial status order that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(b)(i): releases the individual on the individual's own recognizance during the time the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(b)(ii): designates a condition, or a combination of conditions, to be imposed upon the individual's release during the time the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(c): Notwithstanding Subsection (1)(a) or (b), a magistrate shall issue a temporary pretrial status order under Subsection (1) that detains an individual if the individual is arrested for a felony offense and the magistrate finds:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(c)(i): there is substantial evidence to support the individual's arrest for the felony offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(c)(ii): the individual committed the felony offense while:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(c)(ii)(A): the individual was on parole or probation for a conviction of a felony offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(c)(ii)(B): the individual was released and awaiting trial on a previous charge for a felony offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(c)(iii): based on information reasonably available to the magistrate, the individual has at least nine cases where the individual has been charged or convicted, or entered a plea of guilty, within five years from the day on which the individual was arrested for the felony offense described in Subsection (1)(c)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(1)(d): Subsection (1)(c) does not limit or prohibit a magistrate's authority to detain an individual who does not meet the requirements described in Subsection (1)(c).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(2): 77-20-206
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), the magistrate or judge shall issue a pretrial status order at an individual's first appearance before the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(2)(b): 77-20-206 The magistrate or judge may delay the issuance of a pretrial status order at an individual's first appearance before the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(2)(b)(i): 77-20-206 until a pretrial detention hearing is held if a prosecuting attorney makes a motion for pretrial detention as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(2)(b)(ii): if a party requests a delay; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(2)(b)(iii): if there is good cause to delay the issuance.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(2)(c): If a magistrate or judge delays the issuance of a pretrial status order under Subsection (2)(b), the magistrate or judge shall extend the temporary pretrial status order until the issuance of a pretrial status order.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(3)(a): When a magistrate or judge issues a pretrial status order, the pretrial status order shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(3)(a)(i): release the individual on the individual's own recognizance during the time the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(3)(a)(ii): designate a condition, or a combination of conditions, to be imposed upon the individual's release during the time the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(3)(a)(iii): order the individual to be detained during the time that individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(3)(b): In making a determination about pretrial release in a pretrial status order, the magistrate or judge may not give any deference to a magistrate's decision in a temporary pretrial status order.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(4): In making a determination about pretrial release, a magistrate or judge shall impose:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(4)(a): only conditions of release that are reasonably available; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(4)(b): conditions of release that reasonably ensure:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(4)(b)(i): the individual's appearance in court when required;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(4)(b)(ii): the safety of any witnesses or victims of the offense allegedly committed by the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(4)(b)(iii): the safety and welfare of the public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(4)(b)(iv): that the individual will not obstruct, or attempt to obstruct, the criminal justice process.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5): (1)(c) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(a): not commit a federal, state, or local offense during the period of pretrial release;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(b): avoid contact with a victim of the alleged offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(c): avoid contact with a witness who:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(c)(i): may testify concerning the alleged offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(c)(ii): is named in the pretrial status order;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(d): not consume alcohol or any narcotic drug or other controlled substance unless prescribed by a licensed medical practitioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(e): submit to drug or alcohol testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(f): complete a substance abuse evaluation and comply with any recommended treatment or release program;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(g): submit to electronic monitoring or location device tracking;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(h): participate in inpatient or outpatient medical, behavioral, psychological, or psychiatric treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(i): maintain employment or actively seek employment if unemployed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(j): maintain or commence an education program;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(k): comply with limitations on where the individual is allowed to be located or the times that the individual shall be, or may not be, at a specified location;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(l): comply with specified restrictions on personal associations, place of residence, or travel;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(m): report to a law enforcement agency, pretrial services program, or other designated agency at a specified frequency or on specified dates;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(n): comply with a specified curfew;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(o): forfeit or refrain from possession of a firearm or other dangerous weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(p): if the individual is charged with an offense against a child, limit or prohibit access to any location or occupation where children are located, including any residence where children are on the premises, activities where children are involved, locations where children congregate, or where a reasonable person would know that children congregate;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(q): comply with requirements for house arrest;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(r): return to custody for a specified period of time following release for employment, schooling, or other limited purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(s): remain in custody of one or more designated individuals who agree to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(s)(i): supervise and report on the behavior and activities of the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(s)(ii): encourage compliance with all court orders and attendance at all required court proceedings;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(t): comply with a financial condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(5)(u): comply with any other condition that is reasonably available and necessary to ensure compliance with Subsection (4).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(6)(a): If a county or municipality has established a pretrial services program, the magistrate or judge shall consider the services that the county or municipality has identified as available in determining what conditions of release to impose.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(6)(b): The magistrate or judge may not order conditions of release that would require the county or municipality to provide services that are not currently available from the county or municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(6)(c): Notwithstanding Subsection (6)(a), the magistrate or judge may impose conditions of release not identified by the county or municipality so long as the condition does not require assistance or resources from the county or municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(7): 77-20-204
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(7)(a): If the magistrate or judge determines that a financial condition, other than an unsecured bond, is necessary to impose as a condition of release, the magistrate or judge shall consider the individual's ability to pay when determining the amount of the financial condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(7)(b): 77-20-204 If the magistrate or judge determines that a financial condition is necessary to impose as a condition of release, and a county jail official fixed a financial condition for the individual under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(7)(b)(i): the county jail official's action to fix a financial condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(7)(b)(ii): the amount of the financial condition that the individual was required to pay for pretrial release.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(7)(c): If a magistrate or judge orders a financial condition as a condition of release, the judge or magistrate shall set the financial condition at a single amount per case.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8): 78B-22-201.5; 77-36-2.1 In making a determination about pretrial release, the magistrate or judge may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(a): 78B-22-201.5; 77-36-2.1 rely upon information contained in:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(a)(vii): any other reliable record or source, including proffered evidence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b): consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(i): the nature and circumstances of the offense, or offenses, that the individual was arrested for, or charged with, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(i)(A): whether the offense is a violent offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(i)(B): the vulnerability of a witness or alleged victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(ii): the nature and circumstances of the individual, including the individual's:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(ii)(A): character;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(ii)(B): physical and mental health;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(ii)(C): family and community ties;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(ii)(D): employment status or history;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(ii)(G): history of drug or alcohol abuse; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(ii)(H): history of timely appearances at required court proceedings;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(iii): the potential danger to another individual, or individuals, posed by the release of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(iv): whether the individual was on probation, parole, or release pending an upcoming court proceeding at the time the individual allegedly committed the offense or offenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(v): the availability of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(v)(A): other individuals who agree to assist the individual in attending court when required; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(v)(B): supervision of the individual in the individual's community;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(vi): the eligibility and willingness of the individual to participate in various treatment programs, including drug treatment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(8)(b)(vii): other evidence relevant to the individual's likelihood of fleeing or violating the law if released.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(9): The magistrate or judge may not base a determination about pretrial release solely:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-205(9)(a): on the seriousness or type of offense that the individual is arrested for or charged with, unless the individual is arrested for or charged with a capital felony; or

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-209 Right to expedited appeal of pretrial detention.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a magistrate or judge issues a pretrial status order that orders the individual be detained during the time the individual awaits trial or other resolution of criminal charges, the individual has the right to an expedited appeal of the pretrial status order.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-301 Grounds for detaining or releasing defendant on conviction and prior to sentence.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-301(1): Upon conviction, by plea or trial, the court shall order that the convicted defendant who is waiting imposition or execution of sentence be detained, unless the court finds, by clear and convincing evidence, presented by the defendant that the defendant:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-301(1)(a): is not likely to flee the jurisdiction of the court if released; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-301(1)(b): will not pose a danger to the physical, psychological, or financial and economic safety or well-being of any other person or the community if released.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-301(2): 77-20-205(5) If the court finds the defendant does not need to be detained, the court shall order the release of the defendant on suitable conditions, including conditions of release described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-403(2)(a)(ii): 20% of the forfeited amount shall be paid to the General Fund; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-403(2)(a)(iii): 77-20-505 20% of the forfeited amount shall be paid to the prosecuting agency that brings an action to collect under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-403(2)(b): 63M-7-215 where the financial condition was paid without the assistance of a surety:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-403(2)(b)(i): 63M-7-215 75% of the forfeited amount shall be paid to the Pretrial Release Programs Special Revenue Fund established in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501 Liability on a bail bond -- Failure to appear -- Notice to surety.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(1): 77-20-504(5)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(1)(a): 77-20-504(5) Unless exonerated under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(1)(b): Any failure of the defendant to appear when required is a breach of the conditions of the bail bond and subjects the bail bond to forfeiture regardless of whether notice of the required appearance was given to the surety.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(2): (2)(b)(i); (2)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(2)(a): If a defendant, who has posted monetary bail by a bail bond, fails to appear before the appropriate court as required, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(2)(a)(i): within 28 days after the day on which the defendant fails to appear, issue a bench warrant that includes the original case number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(2)(a)(ii): direct the clerk of the court to notify the surety of the defendant's failure to appear.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(2)(b): (2)(b)(i); (2)(b)(i) The clerk of the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(2)(b)(i): email notice of the defendant's failure to appear to the surety at the email address provided on the bond;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(2)(b)(ii): notify the surety as listed on the bail bond of the name, address, and telephone number of the prosecuting attorney;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(2)(b)(iii): (2)(b)(i); (2)(b)(i) email a copy of the notice sent under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(2)(b)(iv): ensure that the name, address, business email address, and telephone number of the surety or the surety's agent as listed on the bail bond is stated on the bench warrant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(3): The prosecuting attorney may email notice of the defendant's failure to appear to the address of the surety as listed on the bail bond within 35 days after the day on which the defendant fails to appear.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(4)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(4)(a)(i): If a defendant appears in court within seven days after a missed, scheduled court appearance, the court may reinstate the bail bond without further notice to the surety.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(4)(a)(ii): If the defendant, while in custody, appears on the case for which the bail bond was posted, the court may not reinstate the bail bond without the consent of the bail bond company.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-501(4)(b): If a defendant fails to appear within seven days after a scheduled court appearance, the court may not reinstate the bail bond without the consent of the surety.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-505(4): (5)

Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-505(4)(b)(iv): be docketed by the clerk of the court in the civil judgment docket.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-20-505(5): A prosecuting attorney may immediately commence collection proceedings to execute a judgment of bail bond forfeiture against the assets of the surety.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 21 - Uniform Act to Secure the Attendance of Witnesses from Without a State in Criminal Proceedings
********************************************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-21-1 Short title -- Construction.
----------------------------------------------------------
This chapter may be cited as the "Uniform Act to Secure the Attendance of Witnesses from Without a State in Criminal Proceedings." It shall be interpreted and construed as to effectuate its general purpose to make uniform the law of the states which enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-21-2 Procedure to secure attendance in another state.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a judge of a court of record in any state, which by its laws has made provisions for commanding persons within that state to attend and testify in this state, certifies under the seal of the court that there is a criminal prosecution pending in the court, or that a grand jury investigation has commenced or is about to commence, that a person being within this state is a material witness in the prosecution or grand jury investigation and that his presence will be required for a specified number of days, upon presentation of the certificate to any judge of a court of record within this state in the county in which the person is found, the judge shall fix a time and place for a hearing and make an order directing the witness to appear at a time and place certain for the hearing.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-21-3 Procedure to secure attendance of witness from without state.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a person in any state, which by its laws has made provision for commanding persons within its borders to attend and testify in criminal prosecutions, or grand jury investigations commenced or about to commence, in this state, is a material witness in a prosecution pending in a court of record in this state, or in a grand jury investigation which has commenced or is about to commence, a judge of the court may issue a certificate under the seal of the court stating these facts and specifying the number of days the witness will be required. The certificate may include a recommendation that the witness be taken into immediate custody and delivered to an officer of this state to assure his attendance in this state. This certificate shall be presented to a judge of a court of record in the county in which the witness is found.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-21-4 Fees.
-----------------------------------
Whenever a judge of a court of record of this state issues a certificate under the provisions of this chapter to obtain the attendance of a witness for the prosecution from without the state in a criminal prosecution or grand jury investigation commenced or about to commence he shall designate therein a suitable peace officer of this state to present the certificate to the proper officer or tribunal of the state wherein the witness is found and to tender to the witness his per diem and mileage fees.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-21-5 Witnesses not subject to arrest or service of process.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a person comes into this state in obedience to a summons directing him to attend and testify in this state he shall not, while in this state pursuant to such summons, be subject to arrest or the service of process, civil or criminal, in connection with matters which arose before his entrance into this state under the summons.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 22 - Subpoena Powers for Aid of Criminal Investigation and Grants of Immunity
**********************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-1 Declaration of necessity.
-------------------------------------------------------
It is declared, as a matter of legislative determination, that it is necessary to grant subpoena powers in aid of criminal investigations and to provide a method of keeping information gained from investigations secret both to protect the innocent and to prevent criminal suspects from having access to information prior to prosecution.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-2 Investigations -- Right to subpoena witnesses and require production of evidence -- Contents of subpoena -- Rights of witnesses -- Interrogation before closed court -- Disclosure of information.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-2(1): 77-22-4.5 As used in this section, "prosecutor" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-2(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-2(2)(a): In any matter involving the investigation of a crime or malfeasance in office, or any criminal conspiracy or activity, the prosecutor may, upon application and approval of the district court and for good cause shown, conduct a criminal investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-2(2)(b): The application and statement of good cause shall state whether another investigative order related to the investigation at issue has been filed in another court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-2(3): (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-2(3)(a): (3)(b) Subject to the conditions established in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-2(3)(a)(i): subpoena witnesses;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-2(3)(a)(ii): compel their attendance and testimony under oath to be recorded by a suitable electronic recording device or to be given before any certified court reporter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-2(3)(a)(iii): require the production of books, papers, documents, recordings, and any other items that are evidence or may be relevant to the investigation.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-4.5 Prosecutorial authority to compromise an offense regarding a witness.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-4.5(1): As used in this section, "prosecutor" includes the state attorney general and any assistant, a district attorney and any deputy, a county attorney and any deputy, and a municipal prosecutor and any deputy.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-4.5(2): This chapter does not prohibit or limit the authority of a prosecutor to divert, reduce, or compromise any criminal charge against a witness or other party when the witness voluntarily enters into an agreement to provide testimony or other evidence against himself or another accused in consideration for the diversion, reduction, or compromise if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-4.5(2)(a): the prosecutor holds authority to prosecute the offense against the witness or other party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-4.5(2)(b): the complete agreement with the witness is in writing and a copy of the agreement is given to the witness.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-4.5(3): (2) Any agreement under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 77-22-5 Prosecutorial powers.
---------------------------------------------------
The powers of this chapter are in addition to any other powers granted to the attorney general or county attorneys.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 22a - Administrative Subpoenas in Controlled Substances Investigations
***************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-1 Administrative subpoenas -- Controlled substances investigations -- Procedures -- Witness fees.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-1(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-1(1)(a): The administrative subpoena process of this chapter may be used only to obtain third party information under circumstances where it is clear that the subpoenaed information is not subject to a claim of protection under the Fourth, Fifth, or Sixth Amendment, United States Constitution, or a similar claim under Article I, Sec. 12 and Sec. 14, Utah Constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-1(1)(b): A party subpoenaed under this chapter shall be advised by the subpoena that the party has a right to challenge the subpoena by motion to quash filed in the appropriate district court named in the subpoena before compliance is required.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-1(2): 17-18a-202; 17-18a-203; 17-18a-602
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-1(2)(a): 17-18a-202; 17-18a-203; 17-18a-602 In any investigation relating to an attorney's functions under this chapter regarding controlled substances, the attorney general or a deputy or assistant attorney general, the county attorney or a deputy county attorney, or the district attorney or deputy district attorney may subpoena witnesses, compel the attendance and testimony of witnesses, or require the production of any records including books, papers, documents, and other tangible things that constitute or contain evidence found by the attorney general or a deputy or assistant attorney general or the county attorney or district attorney, as provided under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-1(2)(b): The attendance of witnesses or the production of records may be required from any place within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-1(3): Witnesses subpoenaed under this section shall be paid the same fees and mileage costs as witnesses in the state district courts.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-1(4): If the attorney general, a deputy or assistant attorney general, or the county attorney or district attorney, or a deputy attorney determines that disclosure of the existence of an administrative subpoena or of the information sought or of the existence of the investigation under which it is issued would pose a threat of harm to a person or otherwise impede the investigation, the subpoena shall contain language on its face directing that the witness not disclose to any person the existence or service of the subpoena, the information being sought, or the existence of an investigation.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-2 Service of administrative subpoena.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-2(1): A subpoena issued under this section may be served by any person designated in the subpoena for that purpose.  Service upon a natural person may be made by personal delivery of the subpoena to him.  Service may be made upon a domestic or foreign corporation or upon a partnership or other unincorporated association subject to suit under a common name by delivering the subpoena to an officer, managing or general agent, or other agent authorized by appointment or law to receive service of process.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-2(2): The affidavit of the person serving the subpoena, when entered on a copy of the subpoena by the person serving it, is proof of service.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-3 Compliance with administrative subpoena.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-3(1): In the case of contumacy by or refusal to obey a subpoena issued to any person, the attorney general or a deputy or assistant attorney general or the county attorney or district attorney or his deputy may compel compliance with the subpoena through the district court:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-3(1)(a): in the jurisdiction where the investigation is carried on;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-3(1)(b): where the subpoenaed person is an inhabitant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-3(1)(c): where he carries on business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-3(1)(d): where he may be found.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-3(2): The court may issue an order requiring the person subpoenaed to produce records or to appear before the attorney general or deputy or assistant attorney general, or the county attorney or district attorney or his deputy  who issued the subpoena testimony touching the matter under investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-3(3): Any failure to obey the court order may be punished by the court as contempt.  All process in the case may be served in any judicial district in which the person may be found within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-22a-3(4): A witness may not be held liable in any civil or criminal proceeding for producing records or disclosing information to the person issuing the administrative subpoena as commanded by the subpoena.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-102(1): "Administrative traffic checkpoint" means a roadblock procedure where enforcement officers stop all, or a designated sequence of, motor vehicles traveling on highways and roads and subject those vehicles to inspection or testing and the drivers or occupants to questioning or the production of documents.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-102(2): "Command level officer" includes all sheriffs, heads of law enforcement agencies, and all supervisory enforcement officers of sergeant rank or higher.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-102(3): "Emergency circumstances" means circumstances where enforcement officers reasonably believe road conditions, weather conditions, or persons present a significant hazard to persons or the property of other persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-102(4): Title 53, Chapter 13, Peace Officer Classifications; Title 53, Chapter 13, Peace Officer Classifications; Title 53, Chapter 13, Peace Officer Classifications; Title 53, Chapter 13, Peace Officer Classifications "Enforcement officer" includes:
