Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-103 Circumstances permitting an administrative traffic checkpoint.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A motor vehicle may be stopped and the occupants detained by an enforcement officer when the enforcement officer:Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-103(1): is acting pursuant to a duly authorized search warrant or arrest warrant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-103(2): has probable cause to arrest or search;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-103(3): has reasonable suspicion that criminal activity has occurred or is occurring;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-103(4): is acting under emergency circumstances; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-103(5): 77-23-104 is acting pursuant to duly authorized administrative traffic checkpoint authority granted by a magistrate in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104 Written plan -- Approval of magistrate.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(1): An administrative traffic checkpoint may be established and operated upon written authority of a magistrate.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2): Title 23A, Wildlife Resources Act A magistrate may issue written authority to establish and operate an administrative traffic checkpoint if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(a): a command level officer submits to the magistrate a written plan signed by the command level officer describing:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(a)(i): the location of the checkpoint including geographical and topographical information;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(a)(ii): the date, time, and duration of the checkpoint;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(a)(iii): the sequence of traffic to be stopped;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(a)(iv): the purpose of the checkpoint, including the inspection or inquiry to be conducted;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(a)(v): the minimum number of personnel to be employed in operating the checkpoint, including the rank of the officer or officers in charge at the scene;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(a)(vi): the configuration and location of signs, barriers, and other means of informing approaching motorists that they must stop and directing them to the place to stop;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(a)(vii): any advance notice to the public at large of the establishment of the checkpoint; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(a)(viii): the instructions to be given to the enforcement officers operating the checkpoint;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(b): the magistrate makes an independent judicial determination that the plan appropriately:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(b)(i): minimizes the length of time the motorist will be delayed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(b)(ii): minimizes the intrusion of the inspection or inquiry;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(b)(iii): minimizes the fear and anxiety the motorist will experience;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(b)(iv): minimizes the degree of discretion to be exercised by the individual enforcement officers operating the checkpoint; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(b)(v): maximizes the safety of the motorist and the enforcement officers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(c): Title 23A, Wildlife Resources Act the administrative traffic checkpoint has the primary purpose of inspecting, verifying, or detecting:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(c)(i): drivers that may be under the influence of alcohol or drugs;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(c)(ii): license plates, registration certificates, insurance certificates, or driver licenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(c)(iii): Title 23A, Wildlife Resources Act violations of
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(2)(c)(iv): other circumstances that are specifically distinguishable by the magistrate from a general interest in crime control.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(3): (2) Upon determination by the magistrate that the plan meets the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(4): A copy of the plan and signed authorization shall be issued to the checkpoint command level officer participating in the operation of the checkpoint.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(5): Any enforcement officer participating in the operation of the checkpoint shall conform the enforcement officer's activities as nearly as practicable to the procedures outlined in the plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104(6): The checkpoint command level officer shall be available to exhibit a copy of the plan and signed authorization to any motorist who has been stopped at the checkpoint upon request of the motorist.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-104.5 Signs -- Prohibitions.
--------------------------------------------------------
An enforcement officer may not display a sign that notifies motorists of an administrative traffic checkpoint unless the checkpoint is being operated under the authority of a magistrate as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-210(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-210(3)(a): The officer may enter without notice only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-210(3)(a)(i): there is reasonable suspicion to believe that the notice will endanger the life or safety of the officer or another person;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-210(3)(a)(ii): there is probable cause to believe that evidence may be easily or quickly destroyed; or

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-210(4): An officer executing a warrant under this section may use only that force which is reasonable and necessary to execute the warrant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-210(5): An officer executing a warrant under this section shall wear readily identifiable markings, including a badge and vest or clothing with a distinguishing label or other writing which indicates that he or she is a law enforcement officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-210(6):

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-210(6)(b): The employing agency's policy regarding the use of body-worn cameras shall include a provision that an officer executing a warrant under this section shall wear a body-worn camera when a camera is available, except in exigent circumstances where it is not practicable to do so.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-210(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-210(7)(a): The officer shall take reasonable precautions in execution of any search warrant to minimize the risks of unnecessarily confrontational or invasive methods which may result in harm to any person.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-210(7)(b): The officer shall minimize the risk of searching the wrong premises by verifying that the premises being searched is consistent with a particularized description in the search warrant, including such factors as the type of structure, the color, the address, and orientation of the target property in relation to nearby structures as is reasonably necessary.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-301(3)(b): If a law enforcement officer conducts a search of a parolee's person, personal effects, or vehicle pursuant to a stop, the law enforcement officer shall notify a parole officer as soon as reasonably possible after conducting the search.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23-301(4): A search conducted under this section may not be for the purpose of harassment.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 23a - Interception of Communications Act
*********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-1 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This act shall be known and may be cited as the "Interception of Communications Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-2 Legislative findings.
----------------------------------------------------
The Legislature finds and determines that:Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-2(1): Wire communications are normally conducted through facilities which form part of an interstate network. The same facilities are used for interstate and intrastate communications.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-2(2): In order to protect effectively the privacy of wire and oral communications, to protect the integrity of court and administrative proceedings, and to prevent the obstruction of intrastate commerce, it is necessary for the legislature to define the circumstances and conditions under which the interception of wire and oral communications may be authorized and to prohibit any unauthorized interception of these communications and the use of the contents thereof in evidence in courts and administrative proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-2(3): Organized criminals make extensive use of wire and oral communications in their criminal activities. The interception of such communications to obtain evidence of the commission of crimes or to prevent their commission is an indispensable aid to law enforcement and the administration of justice.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-2(4): To safeguard the privacy of innocent persons, the interception of wire or oral communications when none of the parties to the communication has consented to the interception should be allowed only when authorized by a court of competent jurisdiction and should remain under the control and supervision of the authorizing court. Interception of wire and oral communications should further be limited to certain major types of offenses and specific categories of crime with assurance that the interception is justified and that the information obtained thereby will not be misused.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(1): "Aggrieved person" means a person who was a party to any intercepted wire, electronic, or oral communication, or a person against whom the interception was directed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(2): "Aural transfer" means any transfer containing the human voice at any point between and including the point of origin and the point of reception.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(3): "Communications common carrier" means any person engaged as a common carrier for hire in intrastate, interstate, or foreign communication by wire or radio, including a provider of electronic communication service.  However, a person engaged in radio broadcasting is not, when that person is so engaged, a communications common carrier.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(4): "Contents" when used with respect to any wire, electronic, or oral communication includes any information concerning the substance, purport, or meaning of that communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(5): "Electronic communication" means any transfer of signs, signals, writings, images, sounds, data, or intelligence of any nature transmitted in whole or in part by a wire, radio, electromagnetic, photoelectronic, or photo-optical system, but does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(5)(a): the radio portion of a cordless telephone communication that is transmitted between the cordless telephone handset and the base unit;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(5)(b): any wire or oral communications;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(5)(c): any communication made through a tone-only paging device; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(5)(d): any communication from an electronic or mechanical device that permits the tracking of the movement of a person or object.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(6): "Electronic communications service" means any service that provides for users the ability to send or receive wire or electronic communications.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(7): "Electronic communications system" means any wire, radio, electromagnetic, photoelectronic, or photo-optical facilities for the transmission of electronic communications, and any computer facilities or related electronic equipment for the electronic storage of the communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(8): "Electronic, mechanical, or other device" means any device or apparatus that may be used to intercept a wire, electronic, or oral communication other than:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(8)(a): any telephone or telegraph instrument, equipment or facility, or a component of any of them:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(8)(a)(i): furnished by the provider of wire or electronic communications service or by the subscriber or user, and being used by the subscriber or user in the ordinary course of its business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(8)(a)(ii): being used by a provider of wire or electronic communications service in the ordinary course of its business, or by an investigative or law enforcement officer in the ordinary course of his duties; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(8)(b): a hearing aid or similar device being used to correct subnormal hearing to not better than normal.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(9): "Electronic storage" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(9)(a): any temporary intermediate storage of a wire or electronic communication incident to the electronic transmission of it; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(9)(b): any storage of the communication by an electronic communications service for the purposes of backup protection of the communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(10): "Intercept" means the acquisition of the contents of any wire, electronic, or oral communication through the use of any electronic, mechanical, or other device.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(11): 53-13-106 "Investigative or law enforcement officer" means any officer of the state or of a political subdivision, who by law may conduct investigations of or make arrests for offenses enumerated in this chapter, or any federal officer as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(12): "Judge of competent jurisdiction" means a judge of a district court of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(13): "Oral communication" means any oral communication uttered by a person exhibiting an expectation that the communication is not subject to interception, under circumstances justifying that expectation, but does not include any electronic communication.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(14): "Pen register" means a device that records or decodes electronic or other impulses that identify the numbers dialed or otherwise transmitted on the telephone line to which the device is attached.  "Pen register" does not include any device used by a provider or customer of a wire or electronic communication service for billing or recording as an incident to billing, for communications services provided by the provider, or any device used by a provider or customer of a wire communications service for cost accounting or other like purposes in the ordinary course of its business.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(15): "Person" means any employee or agent of the state or a political subdivision, and any individual, partnership, association, joint stock company, trust, or corporation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(16): "Readily accessible to the general public" means, regarding a radio communication, that the communication is not:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(16)(a): scrambled or encrypted;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(16)(b): transmitted using modulation techniques with essential parameters that have been withheld from the public with the intention of preserving the privacy of the communication;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(16)(c): carried on a subcarrier or signal subsidiary to a radio transmission;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(16)(d): transmitted over a communications system provided by a common carrier, unless the communication is a tone-only paging system communication; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(16)(e): transmitted on frequencies allocated under Part 25, Subpart D, E, or F of Part 74, or Part 94, Rules of the Federal Communications Commission unless, in the case of a communication transmitted on a frequency allocated under Part 74 that is not exclusively allocated to broadcast auxiliary services, the communication is a two-way voice communication by radio.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(17): "Trap and trace device" means a device, process, or procedure that captures the incoming electronic or other impulses that identify the originating number of an instrument or device from which a wire or electronic communication is transmitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(18): "User" means any person or entity who:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(18)(a): uses an electronic communications service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(18)(b): is authorized by the provider of the service to engage in the use.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(19): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(19)(a): "Wire communication" means any aural transfer made in whole or in part through the use of facilities for the transmission of communications by the aid of wire, cable, or other like connection between the point of origin and the point of reception, including the use of the connection in a switching station, furnished or operated by any person engaged as a common carrier in providing or operating these facilities for the transmission of intrastate, interstate, or foreign communications.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-3(19)(b): "Wire communication" includes the electronic storage of the communication, but does not include the radio portion of a cordless telephone communication that is transmitted between the cordless telephone handset and the base unit.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4 Offenses -- Criminal and civil -- Lawful interception.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(1): (1)(b); (10); (11)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(1)(a): (1)(b); (10); (11) Except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, any person who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(1)(b): A person commits a violation of this subsection who:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(1)(b)(i): intentionally or knowingly intercepts, endeavors to intercept, or procures any other person to intercept or endeavor to intercept any wire, electronic, or oral communication;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(1)(b)(ii): intentionally or knowingly uses, endeavors to use, or procures any other person to use or endeavor to use any electronic, mechanical, or other device to intercept any oral communication, when the device is affixed to, or otherwise transmits a signal through a wire, cable, or other like connection used in wire communication or when the device transmits communications by radio, or interferes with the transmission of the communication;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(1)(b)(iii): intentionally or knowingly discloses or endeavors to disclose to any other person the contents of any wire, electronic, or oral communication, knowing or having reason to know that the information was obtained through the interception of a wire, electronic, or oral communication in violation of this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(1)(b)(iv): intentionally or knowingly uses or endeavors to use the contents of any wire, electronic, or oral communication, knowing or having reason to know that the information was obtained through the interception of a wire, electronic, or oral communication in violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(2): The operator of a switchboard, or an officer, employee, or agent of a provider of wire or electronic communication service whose facilities are used in the transmission of a wire communication may intercept, disclose, or use that communication in the normal course of his employment while engaged in any activity which is a necessary incident to the rendition of his service or to the protection of the rights or property of the provider of that service.  However, a provider of wire communications service to the public may not utilize service observing or random monitoring except for mechanical or service quality control checks.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(3): 77-23a-10(7)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(3)(a): 77-23a-10(7) Providers of wire or electronic communications service, their officers, employees, or agents, and any landlords, custodians, or other persons may provide information, facilities, or technical assistance to persons authorized by law to intercept wire, oral, or electronic communications or to conduct electronic surveillance if the provider and its officers, employees, or agents, and any landlords, custodians, or other specified persons have been provided with:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(3)(a)(i): a court order directing the assistance signed by the authorizing judge; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(3)(a)(ii): 77-23a-10(7) a certification in writing by a person specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(3)(b): The order or certification under this subsection shall set the period of time during which the provision of the information, facilities, or technical assistance is authorized and shall specify the information, facilities, or technical assistance required.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(4): 77-23a-11
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(4)(a): The providers of wire or electronic communications service, their officers, employees, or agents, and any landlords, custodians, or other specified persons may not disclose the existence of any interception or surveillance or the device used to accomplish the interception or surveillance regarding which the person has been furnished an order or certification under this section except as is otherwise required by legal process, and then only after prior notification to the attorney general or to the county attorney or district attorney of the county in which the interception was conducted, as is appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(4)(b): 77-23a-11 Any disclosure in violation of this subsection renders the person liable for civil damages under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(5): A cause of action does not lie in any court against any provider of wire or electronic communications service, its officers, employees, or agents, or any landlords, custodians, or other specified persons for providing information, facilities, or assistance in accordance with the terms of a court order or certification under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(6): (3); (4); (5) Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(7)(a): A person acting under color of law may intercept a wire, electronic, or oral communication if that person is a party to the communication or one of the parties to the communication has given prior consent to the interception.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(7)(b): A person not acting under color of law may intercept a wire, electronic, or oral communication if that person is a party to the communication or one of the parties to the communication has given prior consent to the interception, unless the communication is intercepted for the purpose of committing any criminal or tortious act in violation of state or federal laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(7)(c): An employee of a telephone company may intercept a wire communication for the sole purpose of tracing the origin of the communication when the interception is requested by the recipient of the communication and the recipient alleges that the communication is obscene, harassing, or threatening in nature.  The telephone company and its officers, employees, and agents shall release the results of the interception, made under this subsection, upon request of the local law enforcement authorities.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(8): A person may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(8)(a): intercept or access an electronic communication made through an electronic communications system that is configured so that the electronic communication is readily accessible to the general public;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(8)(b)(iii): a station operating on an authorized frequency within the bands allocated to the amateur, citizens' band, or general mobile radio services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(8)(b)(iv): by a marine or aeronautics communications system;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(8)(c): intercept any wire or electronic communication, the transmission of which is causing harmful interference to any lawfully operating station or consumer electronic equipment, to the extent necessary to identify the source of the interference; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4(8)(d): as one of a group of users of the same frequency, intercept any radio communication made through a system that utilizes frequencies monitored by individuals engaged in the provision or the use of the system, if the communication is not scrambled or encrypted.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4.5(2): (1) Any person who violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-4.5(3): (1)

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-5 Traffic in intercepting devices -- Offenses -- Lawful activities.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-5(1): Except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, any person is guilty of a third degree felony who intentionally:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-5(1)(a): sends through the mail, or sends or carries in intrastate, interstate, or foreign commerce any electronic, mechanical, or other device, knowing or having reason to know that the design of the device renders it primarily useful for the purpose of the surreptitious interception of wire, electronic, or oral communications;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-5(1)(b): manufactures, assembles, possesses, or sells any electronic, mechanical, or other device, knowing or having reason to know that the design of the device renders it primarily useful for the purpose of the surreptitious interception of wire, electronic, or oral communications; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-5(1)(c): places in any newspaper, magazine, handbill, or other publication any advertisement of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-5(1)(c)(i): any electronic, mechanical, or other device knowing or having reason to know that the design of the device renders it primarily useful for the purpose of the surreptitious interception of wire, electronic, or oral communications; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-5(1)(c)(ii): any other electronic, mechanical, or other device, where the advertisement promotes the use of the device for the purpose of the surreptitious interception of wire, electronic, or oral communications.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-5(2): The following persons may send through the mail, send or carry in intrastate, interstate, or foreign commerce, or manufacture, assemble, possess, or sell any electronic, mechanical, or other device knowing or having reason to know that the design of the device renders it primarily useful for the purpose of surreptitious interception of wire, electronic, or oral communication:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-5(2)(a): a provider in the normal course of the business of providing that wire or electronic communications service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-5(2)(b): an officer, agent, or employee of, or a person under contract with, the United States, a state, or a political subdivision, in the normal course of the activities of the United States, a state, or a political subdivision.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any electronic, mechanical or other device used, sent, carried, manufactured, assembled, possessed, sold, or advertised in violation of Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-7 Evidence -- Exclusionary rule.
-------------------------------------------------------------
When any wire, electronic, or oral communication has been intercepted, no part of the contents of the communication and no evidence derived from it may be received in evidence in any trial, hearing, or other proceeding in or before any court, grand jury, department, officer, agency, regulatory body, legislative committee, or other authority of the state, or a political subdivision of the state, if the disclosure of that information would be in violation of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-8 Court order to authorize or approve interception -- Procedure.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-8(1): The attorney general of the state, any assistant attorney general specially designated by the attorney general, any county attorney, district attorney, deputy county attorney, or deputy district attorney specially designated by the county attorney or by the district attorney, may authorize an application to a judge of competent jurisdiction for an order for an interception of wire, electronic, or oral communications by any law enforcement agency of the state, the federal government or of any political subdivision of the state that is responsible for investigating the type of offense for which the application is made.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-9 Disclosure or use of intercepted information.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-9(1): Any investigative or law enforcement officer who, by any means authorized by this chapter, has obtained knowledge of the contents of any wire, electronic, or oral communication, or evidence derived from any of these, may disclose those contents to another investigative or law enforcement officer to the extent that the disclosure is appropriate to the proper performance of the official duties of the officer making or receiving the disclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-9(2): Any investigative or law enforcement officer who, by any means authorized by this chapter, has obtained knowledge of the contents of any wire, electronic, or oral communication or evidence derived from any of them may use those contents to the extent the use is appropriate to the proper performance of his official duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-9(3): Any person who has received, by any means authorized by this chapter, any information concerning a wire, electronic, or oral communication or evidence derived from any of them intercepted in accordance with this chapter may disclose the contents of that communication or the derivative evidence while giving testimony under oath or affirmation in any proceeding held under the authority of the United States or of any state or political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-9(4): An otherwise privileged wire, electronic, or oral communication intercepted in accordance with, or in violation of, the provisions of this chapter does not lose its privileged character.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-9(5): (1); (2); (3) When an investigative or law enforcement officer, while engaged in intercepting wire, electronic, or oral communications in the manner authorized, intercepts wire, electronic, or oral communications relating to offenses other than those specified in the order of authorization or approval, the contents, and evidence derived from the contents, may be disclosed or used as provided in Subsections

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-10(5)(a): An order entered under this chapter may not authorize or approve the interception of any wire, electronic, or oral communications for any period longer than is necessary to achieve the objective of the authorization, but in any event for no longer than 30 days.  The 30-day period begins on the day the investigative or law enforcement officer first begins to conduct an interception under the order, or 10 days after the order is entered, whichever is earlier.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-10(5)(d): If the intercepted communication is in a code or foreign language, and an expert in that foreign language or code is not reasonably available during the interception period, the minimizing of the interception may be accomplished as soon as practicable after the interception.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-10(5)(e): An interception under this chapter may be conducted in whole or in part by government personnel or by an individual under contract with the government and acting under supervision of an investigative or law enforcement officer authorized to conduct the interception.

These reports shall be made at intervals the judge may require.

The judge, upon the filing of the motion by the aggrieved person, may in the judge's discretion make available to the aggrieved person or the aggrieved person's counsel for inspection portions of the intercepted communication or evidence derived from the intercepted communication as the judge determines to be in the interests of justice.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-11(3)(b)(ii): statutory damages of $100 a day for each day of violation, or $10,000, whichever is greater.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-12 Enjoining a violation -- Civil action by attorney general.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-12(1): When it appears that a person is engaged or is about to engage in any act that constitutes or will constitute a felony violation of this chapter or is otherwise prohibited by this chapter, the attorney general may initiate a civil action in a district court of the state to enjoin the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-12(2): The court shall proceed as soon as practicable to the hearing and determination of the action and may at any time before final determination enter a restraining order or prohibition, or take other action as warranted to prevent a continuing and substantial injury to the state or to any person or class of persons for whose protection the action is brought.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-12(3): A proceeding under this section is governed by the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, except if an information has been filed or an indictment has been returned against the respondent, discovery is governed by the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-16(1): 77-23a-15(2)(b) Upon the request of an attorney for the government or an officer of a law enforcement agency authorized to install and use pen registers under this chapter, a provider of wire or electronic communications service, landlord, custodian, or other person shall furnish investigative or law enforcement officers forthwith all information, facilities, and technical assistance necessary to accomplish the installation of the pen register unobtrusively and with a minimum of interference with the services the person ordered by the court accords the party regarding whom the installation and use is to take place, if such assistance is directed by a court order as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-16(2): 77-23a-15(2)(b)

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-16(4): A cause of action does not lie in any court against the provider of wire or electronic communications service, its officers, employees, agents, or other specified persons, for providing information, facilities, or assistance in accordance with the terms of a court order under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23a-16(5): A good faith reliance on a court order, a legislative authorization, or a statutory authorization, is a complete defense against any civil or criminal action brought under this chapter or any other law.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23b-9 Judicial scope of chapter remedies and sanctions.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 23c - Electronic Information Privacy Act
*********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2 Definitions.
-----------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(1): "Electronic communication service" means a service that provides to users of the service the ability to send or receive wire or electronic communications.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(2): "Electronic device" means a device that enables access to or use of an electronic communication service, remote computing service, or location information service.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(3)(a): "Electronic information" means information or data including a sign, signal, writing, image, sound, or intelligence of any nature transmitted or stored in whole or in part by a wire, radio, electromagnetic, photoelectronic, or photooptical system.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(3)(b): "Electronic information" includes the location information, stored data, or transmitted data of an electronic device.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(3)(c): "Electronic information" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(3)(c)(i): a wire or oral communication;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(3)(c)(ii): a communication made through a tone-only paging device; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(3)(c)(iii): electronic funds transfer information stored by a financial institution in a communications system used for the electronic storage and transfer of money.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(4): (4)(a) "Law enforcement agency" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(4)(a): an entity of the state or a political subdivision of the state that exists to primarily prevent, detect, or prosecute crime and enforce criminal statutes or ordinances; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(4)(b): (4)(a) an individual or entity acting for or on behalf of an entity described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(5)(a): "Location information" means information concerning the geographical location of an electronic device that, in whole or in part, is generated or derived from or obtained by the operation of an electronic device or the operation of a software application on an electronic device.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(5)(b): "Location information" includes past, current, and future location information.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(6): "Location information service" means the provision of a global positioning service or other mapping, location, or directional information service.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(7): 77-23a-3 "Oral communication" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(8): "Remote computing service" means the provision to the public of computer storage or processing services by means of an electronic communications system.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(9): "Transmitted data" means electronic information that is transmitted wirelessly:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(9)(a): from an electronic device to another electronic device without the use of an intermediate connection or relay; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(9)(b): from an electronic device to a nearby antenna or from a nearby antenna to an electronic device.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23c-101.2(10): 77-23a-3 "Wire communication" means the same as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 23d - Surveillance Privacy
*******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Imaging Surveillance Privacy."

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(1): 72-10-102 "Airport" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(2): "Authorized property" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(2)(a): a building or part of a building owned or leased by a law enforcement agency or a correctional facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(2)(b): critical infrastructure if owned or operated by a government entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(2)(c): an elementary or secondary public or charter school;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(2)(d): a courthouse; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(2)(e): an airport.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(3): "Biometric surveillance information" means the analysis of surveillance information using biometric software to identify an individual's identity or location using the individual's physical attributes or manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(4): 76-6-106.3 "Critical infrastructure" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(5)(a): "Government entity" means the state, a county, a municipality, a higher education institution, a special district, a special service district, charter school, or any other political subdivision of the state or an administrative subunit of a political subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(5)(b): "Government entity" includes a law enforcement entity or any other investigative entity, agency, department, division, bureau, board, or commission, or an individual acting or purporting to act for or on behalf of a state or local agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(6): "Imaging surveillance device" means a device that uses radar, sonar, infrared, or other remote sensing or detection technology used by the individual operating the device to obtain information, not otherwise directly observable, about individuals, items, or activities within a closed structure.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(7): 76-5-107 "Public safety threat" means a documented reasonable articulable suspicion of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(7)(a): a threat to commit a violent felony by a specific individual towards a person, a group of people, or a place; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(7)(b): 76-5-107 a threat by a specific individual to commit an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(8): "Surveillance information" means future, current, or historical information produced by the digital monitoring of an area that can be used to create biometric surveillance information.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(9): "Target" means a person or a structure upon which a government entity intentionally collects or attempts to collect information using an imaging surveillance device.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23d-102(10): 76-3-203.5 "Violent felony" means the same as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23e-102(3)(a): "Facial recognition comparison" means the process of comparing an image or facial biometric data to an image database.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 23f - Access to Reverse-Location Information
*************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(1): "Anonymized" means that the identifying information connected to an electronic device has been rendered anonymous in a manner such that the subject, including an individual, household, device, or Internet protocol address, is not identifiable to a law enforcement agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(2): "Cell site" means transmission or reception equipment, including a base-station antenna, that connects an electronic device to a network.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(3): "Cell site record" means the cell site location information of an electronic device that corresponds to a specific cell site and time frame.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(4): "Electronic device" means a device that enables access to or use of a location information service or can otherwise create or provide location information.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(5): "Geofence" means a specified geographic area defined by a virtual perimeter or geographic coordinates.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(6): "Identifying information" means information tied to an electronic device that identifies the user's or owner's:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(6)(a): name;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(6)(b): address;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(6)(c): phone number;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(6)(d): email; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(6)(e): other identifying information that would identify the owner or user of the electronic device.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(7): 77-23c-101.2 "Law enforcement agency" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(8): 77-23c-101.2 "Location information" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(9): "Reverse-location information" means historical location information for:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(9)(a): a defined time period;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(9)(b): a defined or undefined area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-101(9)(c): a defined or undefined number of electronic devices, for which the identities of the owners or users of the electronic devices are unknown to law enforcement.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-23f-102 Obtaining reverse-location information within a geofence -- Warrant required for disclosure -- Procedure.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
"NOTICE: This warrant application seeks judicial authorization for the disclosure of reverse-location information of electronic devices near a crime at or near the time of the crime. If authorized, the warrant allows law enforcement to obtain historical location information of all devices within the area described in the warrant during the specified time from entities in possession of the relevant data. The electronic devices captured in the warrant may be owned or used by both alleged criminal perpetrators and individuals not involved in the commission of a crime. For this reason, any warrant issued must require the anonymization of all devices associated with the reverse-location information."; andUtah Code Annotated § 77-23f-102(1): 77-23f-106; Title 23A, Wildlife Resources Act Except as provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 25 - Justice Courts
************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-25-2 Venue of prosecution by information.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Any prosecution by information, except in the case of a felony or class A misdemeanor, shall be commenced before a magistrate in the precinct of the county or municipality where the offense was alleged to have been committed, except as otherwise provided by law.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 27 - Pardons and Parole
****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(1): "Appearance" means any opportunity to address the board, a board member, a panel, or hearing officer, including an interview.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(2): "Board" means the Board of Pardons and Parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(3)(a): "Case action plan" means a document developed by the Department of Corrections that identifies the program priorities for the treatment of the offender.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(3)(b): "Case action plan" includes the criminal risk factors as determined by a risk and needs assessment conducted by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(4): 63M-7-201 "Commission" means the State Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(5): "Commutation" is the change from a greater to a lesser punishment after conviction.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(6): 77-32b-102 "Criminal accounts receivable" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(7): "Criminal risk factors" means a person's characteristics and behaviors that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(7)(a): affect that person's risk of engaging in criminal behavior; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(7)(b): are diminished when addressed by effective treatment, supervision, and other support resources resulting in reduced risk of criminal behavior.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(8)(a): "Deliberative process" means the board or any number of the board's individual members together engaging in discussions, whether written or verbal, regarding a parole, a pardon, a commutation, termination of sentence, or fines, fees, or restitution in an individual case.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(8)(b): "Deliberative process" includes the votes, mental processes, written notes, and recommendations of individual board members and staff.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(8)(c): "Deliberative process" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(8)(c)(i): a hearing where the offender is present;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(8)(c)(ii): any factual record the board is considering, including records of the offender's criminal convictions, records regarding the offender's current or previous incarceration and supervision, and records regarding the offender's physical or mental health;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(8)(c)(iii): recommendations regarding the offender's incarceration or supervision from any other individual, governmental entity, or agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(8)(c)(iv): testimony received by the board regarding the offender, whether written or verbal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(8)(c)(v): the board's decision or rationale for the decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(9): "Department" means the Department of Corrections.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(10): "Expiration" means when the maximum sentence has run.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(11): "Family" means any individual related to the victim as a spouse, child, sibling, parent, or grandparent, or the victim's legal guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(12): "Hearing" or "full hearing" means an appearance before the board, a panel, a board member or hearing examiner, at which an offender or inmate is afforded an opportunity to be present and address the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(13): "Location," in reference to a hearing, means the physical location at which the board, a panel, a board member, or a hearing examiner is conducting the hearing, regardless of the location of any person participating by electronic means.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(14): "Open session" means any hearing, before the board, a panel, a board member, or a hearing examiner, that is open to the public, regardless of the location of any person participating by electronic means.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(15): "Panel" means members of the board assigned by the chairperson to a particular case.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(16): "Pardon" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(16)(a): an act of grace that forgives a criminal conviction and restores the rights and privileges forfeited by or because of the criminal conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(16)(b): the release of an offender from the entire punishment prescribed for a criminal offense and from disabilities that are a consequence of the criminal conviction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(16)(c): the reinstatement of any civil rights lost as a consequence of conviction or punishment for a criminal offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(17): "Parole" means a release from imprisonment on prescribed conditions which, if satisfactorily performed by the parolee, enables the parolee to obtain a termination of the parolee's sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(18): 77-32b-102 "Payment schedule" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(19): 77-38b-102 "Pecuniary damages" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(20): "Probation" means an act of grace by the court suspending the imposition or execution of a convicted offender's sentence upon prescribed conditions.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(21): 77-32b-102 "Remit" or "remission" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(22): "Reprieve" or "respite" means the temporary suspension of the execution of the sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(23): 77-38b-102 "Restitution" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(24): "Termination" means the act of discharging from parole or concluding the sentence of imprisonment before the expiration of the sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(25): "Victim" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(25)(a): a person against whom the defendant committed a felony or class A misdemeanor offense for which a hearing is held under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1(25)(b): the victim's family if the victim is deceased as a result of the offense for which a hearing is held under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1.5 Appearance by inmate, offender, or witness.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1.5(1): 77-27-8 An appearance by an inmate, offender, or witness before the board, a panel, board member, or hearing officer may be in person, through videoconferencing or other electronic means.  Any appearance by videoconference or other electronic means shall be recorded as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-1.5(2): An inmate's or offender's electronic appearance by telephone is permissible with the consent of the inmate or offender, when the inmate or offender is incarcerated in a facility outside of this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2 Board of Pardons and Parole -- Creation -- Compensation -- Functions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(1): Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 2, Vacancies; Title 67, Chapter 22, State Officer Compensation
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(1)(a): There is created the Board of Pardons and Parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(1)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 2, Vacancies The board shall consist of five full-time members and not more than five pro tempore members to be appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(1)(c): The members of the board shall be resident citizens of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(1)(d): Title 67, Chapter 22, State Officer Compensation The governor shall establish salaries for the members of the board within the salary range fixed by the Legislature in
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2): (2)(e)(iii); Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 3, Conflicts of Interest; (2)(f)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(a)(i)(A): The full-time board members shall serve terms of five years.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(a)(i)(B): The terms of the full-time members shall be staggered so one board member is appointed for a term of five years on March 1 of each year.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(a)(ii)(A): The pro tempore members shall serve terms of five years, beginning on March 1 of the year of appointment, with no more than one pro tempore member term beginning or expiring in the same calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(a)(ii)(B): If a pro tempore member vacancy occurs, the board may submit the names of not fewer than three or more than five persons to the governor for appointment to fill the vacancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(b): All vacancies occurring on the board for any cause shall be filled by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate in accordance with this section for the unexpired term of the vacating member.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(c): The governor may at any time remove any member of the board for inefficiency, neglect of duty, malfeasance or malfeasance in office, or for cause upon a hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(d)(i): A member of the board may not hold any other office in the government of the United States, this state or any other state, or of any county government or municipal corporation within a state.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(d)(ii): A member may not engage in any occupation or business inconsistent with the member's duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(e): (2)(e)(iii); Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 3, Conflicts of Interest
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(e)(i): A majority of the board constitutes a quorum for the transaction of business, including the holding of hearings at any time or any location within or without the state, or for the purpose of exercising any duty or authority of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(e)(ii): An action is deemed the action of the board if the action is taken by a majority of the board regarding whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(e)(ii)(A): parole, pardon, commutation, or termination of a sentence is granted in an offender's case;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(e)(ii)(B): remission of a criminal accounts receivable, or a fines or forfeiture, is granted in an offender's case; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(e)(ii)(C): an offender's payment schedule for a criminal accounts receivable is modified.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(e)(iii): A majority vote of the five full-time members of the board is required for adoption of rules or policies of general applicability as provided by statute.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(e)(iv): (2)(e)(iii) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(e)(v): Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 3, Conflicts of Interest A board member shall comply with the conflict of interest provisions described in

Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(f)(ii): (2)(f)(i) When an action under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(g): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(g)(i): When a full-time board member is absent or in other extraordinary circumstances, the chair may, as dictated by public interest and efficient administration of the board, assign a pro tempore member to act in the place of a full-time member.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(g)(ii): Pro tempore members shall receive a per diem rate of compensation as established by the Division of Finance and all actual and necessary expenses incurred in attending to official business.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(2)(h): The chair may request staff and administrative support as necessary from the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(4)(c)(v): conduct hearings as necessary in the preparation of reports and recommendations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-2(4)(c)(vi): perform other duties as assigned by the board.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-4 Chairperson and vice chairperson.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-4(1): The governor shall select one of the members of the board to serve as chairperson and board administrator at the governor's pleasure.   The chairperson may exercise the duties and powers, in addition to those established by this chapter, necessary for the administration of daily operations of the board, including personnel, budgetary matters, panel appointments, and scheduling of hearings.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-4(2): The chairperson shall appoint a vice chairperson to act in the absence of the chairperson.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5 Board of Pardons and Parole authority.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1): 77-32b-105; 77-32b-106; 77-32b-103
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(a): Subject to this chapter and other laws of the state, and except for a conviction for treason or impeachment, the board shall determine by majority decision when and under what conditions an offender's conviction may be pardoned or commuted.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(b): 77-32b-105; 77-32b-106; 77-32b-103 The board shall determine by majority decision when and under what conditions an offender committed to serve a sentence at a penal or correctional facility, which is under the jurisdiction of the department, may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(b)(i): be released upon parole;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(b)(ii): have a fine or forfeiture remitted;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(b)(iii): 77-32b-105; 77-32b-106 have the offender's criminal accounts receivable remitted in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(b)(iv): 77-32b-103 have the offender's payment schedule modified in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(b)(v): have the offender's sentence terminated.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(c): The board shall prioritize public safety when making a determination under Subsection (1)(a) or (1)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(d)(i): The board may sit together or in panels to conduct hearings.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(d)(ii): The chair shall appoint members to the panels in any combination and in accordance with rules made by the board in accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(d)(iii): The chair may participate on any panel and when doing so is chair of the panel.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(d)(iv): The chair of the board may designate the chair for any other panel.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(e)(i): Except after a hearing before the board, or the board's appointed examiner, in an open session, the board may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(e)(i)(A): remit a fine or forfeiture for an offender or the offender's criminal accounts receivable;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(e)(i)(B): release the offender on parole; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(e)(i)(C): commute, pardon, or terminate an offender's sentence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(e)(ii): An action taken under this Subsection (1) other than by a majority of the board shall be affirmed by a majority of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(1)(f): A commutation or pardon may be granted only after a full hearing before the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(2): 77-27-9.5
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(2)(a): In the case of a hearing, timely prior notice of the time and location of the hearing shall be given to the offender.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(2)(b): The county or district attorney's office responsible for prosecution of the case, the sentencing court, and law enforcement officials responsible for the defendant's arrest and conviction shall be notified of any board hearings through the board's website.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(2)(c): Whenever possible, the victim or the victim's representative, if designated, shall be notified of original hearings and any hearing after that if notification is requested and current contact information has been provided to the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(2)(d): 77-27-9.5
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(2)(d)(i): 77-27-9.5 Notice to the victim or the victim's representative shall include information provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(2)(d)(ii): The information under Subsection (2)(d)(i) shall be provided in terms that are reasonable for the lay person to understand.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(3): 63G-2-103
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(3)(a): A decision by the board is final and not subject for judicial review if the decision is regarding:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(3)(a)(i): a pardon, parole, commutation, or termination of an offender's sentence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(3)(a)(ii): the modification of an offender's payment schedule for restitution; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(3)(a)(iii): the remission of an offender's criminal accounts receivable or a fine or forfeiture.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(3)(b): Deliberative processes are not public and the board is exempt from Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act, when the board is engaged in the board's deliberative process.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(3)(c): 63G-2-103 Pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(3)(d): Unless it will interfere with a constitutional right, deliberative processes are not subject to disclosure, including discovery.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(3)(e): Nothing in this section prevents the obtaining or enforcement of a civil judgment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(4)(a): This chapter may not be construed as a denial of or limitation of the governor's power to grant respite or reprieves in all cases of convictions for offenses against the state, except treason or conviction on impeachment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(4)(b): Notwithstanding Subsection (4)(a), respites or reprieves may not extend beyond the next session of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(4)(c): At the next session of the board, the board:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(4)(c)(i): shall continue or terminate the respite or reprieve; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(4)(c)(ii): may commute the punishment or pardon the offense as provided.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(4)(d): In the case of conviction for treason, the governor may suspend execution of the sentence until the case is reported to the Legislature at the Legislature's next session.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(4)(e): The Legislature shall pardon or commute the sentence or direct the sentence's execution.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(5): 77-38b-205; 77-32b-105; 77-32b-106
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(5)(a): 77-38b-205 In determining when, where, and under what conditions an offender serving a sentence may be paroled or pardoned, have a fine or forfeiture remitted, have the offender's criminal accounts receivable remitted, or have the offender's sentence commuted or terminated, the board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(5)(a)(i): 77-38b-205 consider whether the offender has made restitution ordered by the court under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(5)(a)(ii): except as provided in Subsection (5)(b), develop and use a list of criteria for making determinations under this Subsection (5);
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(5)(a)(iii): consider information provided by the department regarding an offender's individual case action plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(5)(a)(iv): review an offender's status within 60 days after the day on which the board receives notice from the department that the offender has completed all of the offender's case action plan components that relate to activities that can be accomplished while the offender is imprisoned.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(5)(b): 77-32b-105; 77-32b-106 The board shall determine whether to remit an offender's criminal accounts receivable under this Subsection (5) in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(6): 76-3-202; 77-27-13 In determining whether parole may be terminated, the board shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(6)(a): the offense committed by the parolee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(6)(b): 76-3-202; 77-27-13 the parole period under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(7): 63M-7-401.1 For an offender placed on parole after December 31, 2018, the board shall terminate parole in accordance with the adult sentencing and supervision length guidelines, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(8): The board may not rely solely on an algorithm or a risk assessment tool score in determining whether parole should be granted or terminated for an offender.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(9): The board may intervene as a limited-purpose party in a judicial or administrative proceeding, including a criminal action, to seek:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(9)(a): correction of an order that has or will impact the board's jurisdiction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(9)(b): clarification regarding an order that may impact the board's jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5(10): A motion to intervene brought under Subsection (8)(a) shall be raised within 60 days after the day on which a court enters the order that impacts the board's jurisdiction.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.1 Board authority to order expungement.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.1(1): Upon granting a pardon, the board shall issue an expungement order, directing any criminal justice agency to remove the recipient's identifying information relating to the expunged convictions from its records.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.1(1)(a): When a pardon has been granted, employees of the Board of Pardons and Parole may not divulge any identifying information regarding the pardoned person to any person or agency, except for the pardoned person.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.1(1)(b): The Bureau of Criminal Identification may not count pardoned convictions against any future expungement eligibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.1(2): An expungement order, issued by the board, has at least the same legal effect and authority as an order of expungement issued by a court, pursuant to Title 77, Chapter 40a, Expungement of Criminal Records.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.1(3): The board shall provide clear written directions to the recipient along with a list of agencies known to be affected by the expungement order.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.2 Board authority to order removal from Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.2(1): If the board grants a pardon for a conviction that is the basis for an individual's registration on the Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry, the board shall issue an order directing the Department of Public Safety to remove the individual's name and personal information relating to the pardoned conviction from the Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.2(2): 77-41-113 An order described in Subsection (1), issued by the board, satisfies the notification requirement described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.3 Meritless and bad faith litigation.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.3(1): For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.3(1)(a): "Convicted" means a conviction by entry of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, guilty with a mental condition, no contest, and conviction of any crime or offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.3(1)(b): "Prisoner" means a person who has been convicted of a crime and is incarcerated for that crime or is being held in custody for trial or sentencing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.3(2): In any case filed in state or federal court in which a prisoner submits a claim that the court finds to be without merit and brought or asserted in bad faith, the Board of Pardons and Parole and any county jail administrator may consider that finding in any early release decisions concerning the prisoner.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4 Earned time program.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(1): The board shall establish an earned time program that reduces the period of incarceration for offenders who successfully complete specified programs, the purpose of which is to reduce the risk of recidivism.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(2): The earned time program shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(2)(a): provide not less than four months of earned time credit each for the completion of up to two programs that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(2)(a)(i): are approved by the board in collaboration with the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(2)(a)(ii): are recommended programs that are part of the offender's case action plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(2)(b): allow the board to grant in the board's discretion earned time credit in addition to the earned time credit provided under Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(3): The earned time program may not provide earned time credit for an offender:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(3)(a): whose previously ordered release date does not provide enough time, including time for transition services, for the board to grant the earned time credit;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(3)(b): who has been sentenced by the court to a term of life without the possibility of parole;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(3)(c): who has been ordered by the board to serve until the expiration of the offender's sentence, including a life sentence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(3)(d): who does not have a current release date;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(3)(e): who has not met a contingency requirement for release that has been ordered by the board; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(3)(f): who has been given a termination date by the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(4): The board may order the forfeiture of earned time credits under this section if the board determines a rescission hearing is necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(5): The department shall notify the board not more than 30 days after an offender completes a program as defined in Subsection (2)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(6): The board shall collect data for the fiscal year regarding the operation of the earned time credit program, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(6)(a): the number of offenders who have earned time credit under this section in the prior year;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(6)(b): the amount of time credit earned in the prior year;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(6)(c): the number of offenders who forfeited earned time credit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(6)(d): additional related information as requested by the Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(7): The board shall collaborate with the department in the establishment of the earned time credit program.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.4(8): To the extent possible, programming and hearings shall be provided early enough in an offender's incarceration to allow the offender to earn time credit.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5 Review procedure -- Commutation.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(1): The Board of Pardons and Parole may consider the commutation of a death sentence only to life without parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(2): Only the person who has been sentenced to death or his counsel may petition the Board of Pardons and Parole for commutation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(3): The petition shall be in writing, signed personally by the person sentenced to death, and shall include a statement of the grounds upon which the petitioner seeks review.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(4): The state shall be permitted to respond in writing to the petition as may be established by board rules.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(5): The board shall review the petition and determine whether the petition presents a substantial issue which has not been reviewed in the judicial process.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(6): The board shall not consider legal issues, including constitutional issues, which:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(6)(a): have been reviewed previously by the courts;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(6)(b): should have been raised during the judicial process; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(6)(c): if based on new information, are subject to judicial review.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(7)(a): If the board does not find a substantial issue, the board shall deny the hearing to the petitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-27-5.5(7)(b): If the board finds a substantial issue, the board shall conduct a hearing in which the petitioner and the state may present evidence and argument as may be provided by board rules.
