Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.3 Law enforcement officer's training.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
All training of law enforcement officers relating to domestic violence shall stress protection of the victim, enforcement of criminal laws in domestic situations, and the availability of community shelters, services, and resources.  Law enforcement agencies and community organizations with expertise in domestic violence shall cooperate in all aspects of that training.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.4 Violation of a protective order -- Mandatory arrest -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.4(1): 78B-7-119 A law enforcement officer shall arrest an alleged perpetrator for a violation of any of the provisions of an ex parte protective order or protective order in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.4(2): 76-5-108 A violation of a protective order is punishable in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.6 Appearance required -- Considerations by court.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.6(1): An alleged perpetrator who is arrested for an offense involving domestic violence shall appear in person or by video before the court or a magistrate within one judicial day after the day on which the arrest is made.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.6(2): An alleged perpetrator who is charged by citation, indictment, or information with an offense involving domestic violence but has not been arrested, shall appear before the court in person for arraignment or initial appearance as soon as practicable, but no later than 14 days after the next day on which court is in session following the issuance of the citation or the filing of the indictment or information.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.6(3): (1); (2); 78B-7-803 At the time of an appearance under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.6(4): Appearances required by this section are mandatory and may not be waived.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7 Dismissal -- Diversion prohibited -- Plea in abeyance -- Pretrial protective order.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(1): Chapter 2a, Pleas in Abeyance Because of the serious nature of domestic violence, the court, in domestic violence actions:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(1)(a): may not dismiss any charge or delay disposition because of concurrent divorce or other civil proceedings;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(1)(b): may not require proof that either party is seeking a dissolution of marriage before instigation of criminal proceedings;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(1)(c): shall waive any requirement that the victim's location be disclosed other than to the alleged perpetrator's attorney and order the alleged perpetrator's attorney not to disclose the victim's location to the client;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(1)(d): shall identify, on the docket sheets, the criminal actions arising from acts of domestic violence; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(1)(e): Chapter 2a, Pleas in Abeyance may hold a plea in abeyance, in accordance with the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(2): (1)(e); (1)(e) When the court holds a plea in abeyance in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(3): 78B-7-801; 78B-7-803 When an alleged perpetrator is charged with a crime involving a qualifying offense, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(4): 78B-7-113
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(4)(a): 78B-7-113 When a court dismisses criminal charges or a prosecutor moves to dismiss charges against an alleged perpetrator of a domestic violence offense, the specific reasons for dismissal shall be recorded in the court file and made a part of any related order or agreement on the statewide domestic violence network described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(4)(b): The court shall transmit the dismissal to the statewide domestic violence network.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(4)(c): Any pretrial protective orders, including jail release court orders and jail release agreements, related to the dismissed domestic violence criminal charge shall also be dismissed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-2.7(5): The court may not approve diversion for a perpetrator of domestic violence.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5 Sentencing -- Restricting contact with victim -- Electronic monitoring -- Counseling -- Cost assessed against perpetrator -- Sentencing protective order -- Continuous protective order.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5(1): 78B-7-804; 78B-7-804 When a perpetrator is found guilty of a crime involving domestic violence and a condition of the sentence restricts the perpetrator's contact with the victim, a sentencing protective order may be issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5(2): In determining the court's sentence, the court, in addition to penalties otherwise provided by law, may require the perpetrator to participate in an electronic or other type of monitoring program.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5(3): The court may also require the perpetrator to pay all or part of the costs of counseling incurred by the victim and any children affected by or exposed to the domestic violence offense, as well as the costs for the perpetrator's own counseling.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5(4): 80-2-301 The court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5(4)(a): 80-2-301 assess against the perpetrator, as restitution, any costs for services or treatment provided to the victim and affected child of the victim or the perpetrator by the Division of Child and Family Services under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5(4)(b): order those costs to be paid directly to the division or its contracted provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5(5): 26B-2-101 The court may order the perpetrator to obtain and satisfactorily complete treatment or therapy in a domestic violence treatment program, as defined in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1 Conditions of probation for domestic violence offense.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(1): Before a perpetrator who is convicted or adjudicated of a domestic violence offense may be placed on probation, the court shall consider the safety and protection of the victim and any member of the victim's family or household.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(2): 78B-7-804; Chapter 38b, Crime Victims Restitution Act The court may condition probation or a plea in abeyance on the perpetrator's compliance with one or more orders of the court, which may include:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(2)(a): 78B-7-804 a sentencing protective order issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(2)(b): prohibiting the perpetrator from possessing or consuming alcohol or controlled substances;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(2)(c): prohibiting the perpetrator from purchasing, using, or possessing a firearm or other specified weapon;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(2)(d): directing the perpetrator to surrender any weapons the perpetrator owns or possesses;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(2)(e): directing the perpetrator to participate in and complete, to the satisfaction of the court, a program of intervention for perpetrators, treatment for alcohol or substance abuse, or psychiatric or psychological treatment;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(2)(f): Chapter 38b, Crime Victims Restitution Act directing the perpetrator to pay restitution to the victim, enforcement of which shall be in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(2)(g): imposing any other condition necessary to protect the victim and any other designated family or household member or to rehabilitate the perpetrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(3): The perpetrator is responsible for the costs of any condition of probation, according to the perpetrator's ability to pay.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(4): 78B-7-804; (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-5.1(4)(a): 78B-7-804 Adult Probation and Parole, or other provider, shall immediately report to the court and notify the victim of any offense involving domestic violence committed by the perpetrator, the perpetrator's failure to comply with any condition imposed by the court, and any violation of a sentencing protective order issued by the court under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-6 Enforcement of orders.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-6(1): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 6, Cohabitant Abuse Protective Orders; 78B-7-803; 78B-7-804; Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 3, Uniform Interstate Enforcement of Domestic Violence Protection Orders Act Each law enforcement agency in this state shall enforce all orders of the court issued under the requirements and procedures described in this chapter, and shall enforce:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-6(1)(a): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 6, Cohabitant Abuse Protective Orders all protective orders and ex parte protective orders issued under
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-6(1)(b): 78B-7-803; 78B-7-804 pretrial protective orders issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-6(1)(c): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 3, Uniform Interstate Enforcement of Domestic Violence Protection Orders Act all foreign protection orders enforceable under
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-6(2): The requirements of this section apply statewide, regardless of the jurisdiction in which the order was issued or the location of the victim or the perpetrator.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-7 Prosecutor to notify victim of decision as to prosecution.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-7(1): The prosecutor who is responsible for making the decision of whether to prosecute a case shall advise the victim, if the victim has requested notification, of the status of the victim's case and shall notify the victim of a decision within five days after the decision has been made.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-7(2): Notification to the victim that charges will not be filed against an alleged perpetrator shall include a description of the procedures available to the victim in that jurisdiction for initiation of criminal and other protective proceedings.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-8 Peace officers' immunity from liability.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
A peace officer may not be held liable in any civil action brought by a party to an incident of domestic violence for making or failing to make an arrest or for issuing or failing to issue a citation in accordance with this chapter, for enforcing in good faith an order of the court, or for acting or omitting to act in any other way in good faith under this chapter, in situations arising from an alleged incident of domestic violence.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-9 Severability clause.
--------------------------------------------------
If any provision of this chapter or its application to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the remainder of the chapter or the application of the provision to other persons or circumstances is not affected.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-36-10 Authority to prosecute class A misdemeanor violations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Alleged class A misdemeanor violations of this chapter may be prosecuted by city attorneys.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 37 - Victims' Rights
*************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-1 Legislative intent.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-1(1): The Legislature recognizes the duty of victims and witnesses of crime to fully and voluntarily cooperate with law enforcement and prosecutorial agencies, the essential nature of citizen cooperation to state and local law enforcement efforts, and the general effectiveness and well-being of the criminal justice system of this state.  In this chapter, the Legislature declares its intent to ensure that all victims and witnesses of crime are treated with dignity, respect, courtesy, and sensitivity, and that the rights extended in this chapter to victims and witnesses of crime are honored and protected by law in a manner no less vigorous than protections afforded criminal defendants.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-1(2): The Legislature finds it is necessary to provide child victims and child witnesses with additional consideration and different treatment than that usually afforded to adults.  The treatment should ensure that children's participation in the criminal justice process be conducted in the most effective and least traumatic, intrusive, or intimidating manner.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(1): 53-10-801 "Alleged sexual offender" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(2): "Child" means a person who is younger than 18 years old, unless otherwise specified in statute.  The rights to information as extended in this chapter also apply to the parents, custodian, or legal guardians of children.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(3): "Family member" means spouse, child, sibling, parent, grandparent, or legal guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(4): 53-10-801 "HIV infection" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(5): 53-10-902 "Sexual assault kit" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(6): 76-7-102; 76-9-702; 76-9-702.1 "Sexual offense" means any conduct described in:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(6)(a): Title 76, Chapter 5, Part 4, Sexual Offenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(6)(b): Title 76, Chapter 5b, Sexual Exploitation Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(6)(c): 76-7-102 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(6)(d): 76-9-702 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(6)(e): 76-9-702.1 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(7): "Victim" means an individual, including a minor, against whom an offense has been allegedly committed.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-2(8): "Witness" means any person who has been subpoenaed or is expected to be summoned to testify for the prosecution or who by reason of having relevant information is subject to call or likely to be called as a witness for the prosecution, whether any action or proceeding has commenced.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3 Bill of rights.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(1): 76-8-508; 76-8-509; 80-6-710 The bill of rights for victims and witnesses is:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(1)(a): 76-8-508; 76-8-509 Victims and witnesses have a right to be informed as to the level of protection from intimidation and harm available to them, and from what sources, as they participate in criminal justice proceedings as designated by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(1)(b): Victims and witnesses, including children and their guardians, have a right to be informed and assisted as to their role in the criminal justice process. All criminal justice agencies have the duty to provide this information and assistance.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(1)(c): Victims and witnesses have a right to clear explanations regarding relevant legal proceedings; these explanations shall be appropriate to the age of child victims and witnesses.  All criminal justice agencies have the duty to provide these explanations.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(1)(d): Victims and witnesses should have a secure waiting area that does not require them to be in close proximity to defendants or the family and friends of defendants. Agencies controlling facilities shall, whenever possible, provide this area.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(1)(e): 80-6-710 Victims may seek restitution or reparations, including medical costs, as provided in Title 63M, Chapter 7, Criminal Justice and Substance Abuse, Title 77, Chapter 38b, Crime Victims Restitution Act, and Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(1)(f): Victims and witnesses have a right to have any personal property returned as provided in Chapter 11a, Seizure of Property and Contraband, and Chapter 11d, Lost or Mislaid Property. Criminal justice agencies shall expeditiously return the property when it is no longer needed for court law enforcement or prosecution purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(1)(g): Victims and witnesses have the right to reasonable employer intercession services, including pursuing employer cooperation in minimizing employees' loss of pay and other benefits resulting from their participation in the criminal justice process. Officers of the court shall provide these services and shall consider victims' and witnesses' schedules so that activities which conflict can be avoided. Where conflicts cannot be avoided, the victim may request that the responsible agency intercede with employers or other parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(1)(h): Victims and witnesses, particularly children, should have a speedy disposition of the entire criminal justice process. All involved public agencies shall establish policies and procedures to encourage speedy disposition of criminal cases.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(1)(i): Victims and witnesses have the right to timely notice of judicial proceedings they are to attend and timely notice of cancellation of any proceedings. Criminal justice agencies have the duty to provide these notifications. Defense counsel and others have the duty to provide timely notice to prosecution of any continuances or other changes that may be required.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2): 53-10-803; 53-10-802; 53-10-905; 53-10-905; 53-10-905 In addition to the rights of a victim described in Subsection (1), a victim of a sexual offense has the right to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(a): 53-10-803 request voluntary testing for themselves for HIV infection as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(b): 53-10-802 request mandatory testing of the alleged sexual offender for HIV infection as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(c): not to be prevented from, or charged for, a medical forensic examination;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(d): have the evidence from a sexual assault kit, or the contents of the sexual assault kit, preserved for the time periods described in Title 77, Chapter 11c, Retention of Evidence, without any charge to the victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(e): be informed whether a DNA profile was obtained from the testing of the evidence in a sexual assault kit or from other crime scene evidence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(f): be informed whether a DNA profile developed from the evidence in a sexual assault kit, or from other crime scene evidence, has been entered into the Utah Combined DNA Index System;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(g): be informed of any result from a sexual assault kit or from other crime scene evidence if that disclosure would not impede or compromise an ongoing investigation, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(g)(i): whether there is a match between a DNA profile developed from the evidence in a sexual assault kit, or from other crime scene evidence, and a DNA profile contained in the Utah Combined DNA Index System; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(g)(ii): a toxicology result or other information that is collected from a sexual assault kit as part of a medical forensic examination of the victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(h): be informed in writing of policies governing the collection and preservation of a sexual assault kit;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(i): be informed of the status and location of a sexual assault kit;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(j): 53-10-905 upon written request by the victim, receive a notice of intent from an agency, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(k): 53-10-905; 53-10-905 be granted further preservation of the sexual assault kit if the agency, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(l): designate a person of the victim's choosing to act as a recipient of the information provided under this Subsection (2) or Subsections (3) and (4); and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(2)(m): be informed of all the enumerated rights in this Subsection (2).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(3): Subsections (2)(e) through (g) do not require that the law enforcement agency communicate with the victim or the victim's designee regarding the status of DNA testing, absent a specific request received from the victim or the victim's designee.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(4): A law enforcement agency investigating a sexual offense may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(4)(a): release the information indicated in Subsections (2)(e) through (g) upon the request of the victim of the sexual offense, or the victim's designee and is the designated agency to provide that information to the victim or the victim's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(4)(b): require that the victim's request be in writing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(4)(c): respond to the victim's request with verbal communication, written communication, or by email if an email address is available.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(5): A law enforcement agency investigating a sexual offense shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(5)(a): notify the victim of the sexual offense, or the victim's designee, if the law enforcement agency determines that DNA evidence will not be analyzed in a case where the identity of the perpetrator has not be confirmed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(5)(b): provide the information described in this section in a timely manner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(5)(c): upon request of the victim or the victim's designee, advise the victim or the victim's designee of any significant changes in the information of which the law enforcement agency is aware.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(6): The law enforcement agency investigating the sexual offense is responsible for informing the victim of the sexual offense, or the victim's designee, of the rights established under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-3(7): Informational rights of the victim under this chapter are based upon the victim providing the current name, address, telephone number, and email address, if an email address is available, of the person to whom the information should be provided to the criminal justice agencies involved in the case.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4 Additional rights -- Children.
------------------------------------------------------------
In addition to all rights afforded to victims and witnesses under this chapter, child victims and witnesses shall be afforded these rights:Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(1): Children have the right to protection from physical and emotional abuse during their involvement with the criminal justice process.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(2): Children are not responsible for inappropriate behavior adults commit against them and have the right not to be questioned, in any manner, nor to have allegations made, implying this responsibility.  Those who interview children have the responsibility to consider the interests of the child in this regard.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(3): Child victims and witnesses have the right to have interviews relating to a criminal prosecution kept to a minimum.  All agencies shall coordinate interviews and ensure that they are conducted by persons sensitive to the needs of children.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(4): Child victims have the right to be informed of available community resources that might assist them and how to gain access to those resources.  Law enforcement and prosecutors have the duty to ensure that child victims are informed of community resources, including counseling prior to the court proceeding, and have those services available throughout the criminal justice process.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(5)(a): Child victims have the right, once an investigation has been initiated by law enforcement or the Division of Child and Family Services, to keep confidential their interviews that are conducted at a Children's Justice Center, including video and audio recordings, and transcripts of those recordings.  Except as provided in Subsection (6), recordings and transcripts of interviews may not be distributed, released, or displayed to anyone without a court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(5)(b): A court order described in Subsection (5)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(5)(b)(i): shall describe with particularity to whom the recording or transcript of the interview may be released and prohibit further distribution or viewing by anyone not named in the order; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(5)(b)(ii): may impose restrictions on access to the materials considered reasonable to protect the privacy of the child victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(5)(c): A parent or guardian of the child victim may petition a juvenile or district court for an order allowing the parent or guardian to view a recording or transcript upon a finding of good cause.  The order shall designate the agency that is required to display the recording or transcript to the parent or guardian and shall prohibit viewing by anyone not named in the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(5)(d): Following the conclusion of any legal proceedings in which the recordings or transcripts are used, the court shall order the recordings and transcripts in the court's file sealed and preserved.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6): 80-2-703; 67-5b-102; 53E-6-506; 53E-6-506; 53E-6-506; 53E-6-506; 63M-7-529
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(a): 80-2-703; 67-5b-102 The following offices and their designated employees may distribute and receive a recording or transcript to and from one another without a court order:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(a)(i): the Division of Child and Family Services;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(a)(ii): administrative law judges employed by the Department of Human Services;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(a)(iii): 80-2-703 Department of Human Services investigators investigating the Division of Child and Family Services or investigators authorized to investigate under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(a)(iv): an office of the city attorney, county attorney, district attorney, or attorney general;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(a)(v): a law enforcement agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(a)(vi): 67-5b-102 a Children's Justice Center established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(a)(vii): the attorney for the child who is the subject of the interview.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(b): In a criminal case or in a juvenile court in which the state is a party:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(b)(i): the parties may display and enter into evidence a recording or transcript in the course of a prosecution;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(b)(ii): the state's attorney may distribute a recording or transcript to the attorney for the defendant, pro se defendant, respondent, or pro se respondent pursuant to a valid request for discovery;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(b)(iii): the attorney for the defendant or respondent may do one or both of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(b)(iii)(A): release the recording or transcript to an expert retained by the attorney for the defendant or respondent if the expert agrees in writing that the expert will not distribute, release, or display the recording or transcript to anyone without prior authorization from the court; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(b)(iii)(B): permit the defendant or respondent to view the recording or transcript, but may not distribute or release the recording or transcript to the defendant or respondent; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(b)(iv): the court shall advise a pro se defendant or respondent that a recording or transcript received as part of discovery is confidential and may not be distributed, released, or displayed without prior authorization from the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(c): A court's failure to advise a pro se defendant or respondent that a recording or transcript received as part of discovery is confidential and may not be used as a defense to prosecution for a violation of the disclosure rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(d): In an administrative case, pursuant to a written request, the Division of Child and Family Services may display, but may not distribute or release, a recording or transcript to the respondent or to the respondent's designated representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(e)(i): Within two business days of a request from a parent or guardian of a child victim, an investigative agency shall allow the parent or guardian to view a recording after the conclusion of an interview, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(e)(i)(A): the suspect is a parent or guardian of the child victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(e)(i)(B): the suspect resides in the home with the child victim; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(e)(i)(C): the investigative agency determines that allowing the parent or guardian to view the recording would likely compromise or impede the investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(e)(ii): If the investigative agency determines that allowing the parent or guardian to view the recording would likely compromise or impede the investigation, the parent or guardian may petition a juvenile or district court for an expedited hearing on whether there is good cause for the court to enter an order allowing the parent or guardian to view the recording in accordance with Subsection (5)(c).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(e)(iii): A Children's Justice Center shall coordinate the viewing of the recording described in this Subsection (6)(e).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(f): A multidisciplinary team assembled by a Children's Justice Center or an interdisciplinary team assembled by the Division of Child and Family Services may view a recording or transcript, but may not receive a recording or transcript.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(g): A Children's Justice Center:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(g)(i): may distribute or display a recording or transcript to an authorized trainer or evaluator for purposes of training or evaluation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(g)(ii): may display, but may not distribute, a recording or transcript to an authorized trainee.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(h): An authorized trainer or instructor may display a recording or transcript according to the terms of the authorized trainer's or instructor's contract with the Children's Justice Center or according to the authorized trainer's or instructor's scope of employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-37-4(6)(i): 53E-6-506; 53E-6-506; 53E-6-506; 53E-6-506

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 38 - Crime Victims
***********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
For the purposes of this chapter and the Utah Constitution:Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(1): "Abuse" means treating the crime victim in a manner so as to injure, damage, or disparage.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(2): "Dignity" means treating the crime victim with worthiness, honor, and esteem.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(3): "Fairness" means treating the crime victim reasonably, even-handedly, and impartially.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(4): "Harassment" means treating the crime victim in a persistently annoying manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(5): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 8, Criminal Protective Orders "Important criminal justice hearings" or "important juvenile justice hearings" means the following proceedings in felony criminal cases or cases involving a minor's conduct which would be a felony if committed by an adult:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(5)(a): any preliminary hearing to determine probable cause;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(5)(b): any court arraignment where practical;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(5)(c): any court proceeding involving the disposition of charges against a defendant or minor or the delay of a previously scheduled trial date but not including any unanticipated proceeding to take an admission or a plea of guilty as charged to all charges previously filed or any plea taken at an initial appearance;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(5)(d): any court proceeding to determine whether to release a defendant or minor and, if so, under what conditions release may occur, excluding any such release determination made at an initial appearance;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(5)(e): any criminal or delinquency trial, excluding any actions at the trial that a court might take in camera, in chambers, or at a sidebar conference;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(5)(f): any court proceeding to determine the disposition of a minor or sentence, fine, or restitution of a defendant or to modify any disposition of a minor or sentence, fine, or restitution of a defendant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(5)(g): Title 78B, Chapter 7, Part 8, Criminal Protective Orders a hearing regarding any criminal protective order described in
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(5)(h): any public hearing concerning whether to grant a defendant or minor parole or other form of discretionary release from confinement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(6): "Reliable information" means information worthy of confidence, including any information whose use at sentencing is permitted by the United States Constitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(7): "Representative of a victim" means a person who is designated by the victim or designated by the court and who represents the victim in the best interests of the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(8): "Respect" means treating the crime victim with regard and value.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(9): 77-38-2(5)(h); 77-38-3(7)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(9)(a): "Victim of a crime" means any natural person against whom the charged crime or conduct is alleged to have been perpetrated or attempted by the defendant or minor personally or as a party to the offense or conduct or, in the discretion of the court, against whom a related crime or act is alleged to have been perpetrated or attempted, unless the natural person is the accused or appears to be accountable or otherwise criminally responsible for or criminally involved in the crime or conduct or a crime or act arising from the same conduct, criminal episode, or plan as the crime is defined under the laws of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(9)(b): For purposes of the right to be present, "victim of a crime" does not mean any person who is in custody as a pretrial detainee, as a prisoner following conviction for an offense, or as a juvenile who has committed an act that would be an offense if committed by an adult, or who is in custody for mental or psychological treatment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-2(9)(c): 77-38-2(5)(h); 77-38-3(7)(a) For purposes of the right to be present and heard at a public hearing as provided in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4 Right to be present, to be heard, and to file an amicus brief on appeal -- Control of disruptive acts or irrelevant statements -- Statements from persons in custody.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(1): 77-38-2(5); 77-38-2(5)(b); (c); (d); (f); (g); (h) The victim of a crime, the representative of the victim, or both shall have the right:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(1)(a): 77-38-2(5) to be present at the important criminal or juvenile justice hearings provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(1)(b): 77-38-2(5)(b); (c); (d); (f); (g); (h) to be heard at the important criminal or juvenile justice hearings provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(1)(c): to submit a written statement in any action on appeal related to that crime;  and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(1)(d): upon request to the judge hearing the matter, to be present and heard at the initial appearance of the person suspected of committing the conduct or criminal offense against the victim on issues relating to whether to release a defendant or minor and, if so, under what conditions release may occur.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(2): 76-3-207 This chapter shall not confer any right to the victim of a crime to be heard:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(2)(a): 76-3-207 at any criminal trial, including the sentencing phase of a capital trial under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(2)(b): at any delinquency trial or at any preliminary hearing in a minor's case, unless called as a witness.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(3): The right of a victim or representative of a victim to be present at trial is subject to Rule 615 of the Utah Rules of Evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(4): Nothing in this chapter shall deprive the court of the right to prevent or punish disruptive conduct nor give the victim of a crime the right to engage in disruptive conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(5): The court shall have the right to limit any victim's statement to matters that are relevant to the proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(6): In all cases where the number of victims exceeds five, the court may limit the in-court oral statements it receives from victims in its discretion to a few representative statements.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(7): Except as otherwise provided in this section, a victim's right to be heard may be exercised at the victim's discretion in any appropriate fashion, including an oral, written, audiotaped, or videotaped statement or direct or indirect information that has been provided to be included in any presentence report.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(8): If the victim of a crime is a person who is in custody as a pretrial detainee, as a prisoner following conviction for an offense, or as a juvenile who has committed an act that would be an offense if committed by an adult, or who is in custody for mental or psychological treatment, the right to be heard under this chapter shall be exercised by submitting a written statement to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(9): The court may exclude any oral statement from a victim on the grounds of the victim's incompetency as provided in Rule 601(a) of Utah Rules of Evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-4(10): Except in juvenile court cases, the Constitution may not be construed as limiting the existing rights of the prosecution to introduce evidence in support of a capital sentence.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to:Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-5(1): any felony filed in the courts of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-5(2): to any class A and class B misdemeanor filed in the courts of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-5(3): 80-6-604 to cases in the juvenile court as provided in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-6 Victim's right to privacy.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-6(1): The victim of a crime has the right, at any court proceeding, including any juvenile court proceeding, not to testify regarding the victim's address, telephone number, place of employment, or other locating information unless the victim specifically consents or the court orders disclosure on finding that a compelling need exists to disclose the information.  A court proceeding on whether to order disclosure shall be in camera.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-6(2): A defendant may not compel any witness to a crime, at any court proceeding, including any juvenile court proceeding, to testify regarding the witness's address, telephone number, place of employment, or other locating information unless the witness specifically consents or the court orders disclosure on finding that a compelling need for the information exists.  A court proceeding on whether to order disclosure shall be in camera.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-7 Victim's right to a speedy trial.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-7(1): In determining a date for any criminal trial or other important criminal or juvenile justice hearing, the court shall consider the interests of the victim of a crime to a speedy resolution of the charges under the same standards that govern a defendant's or minor's right to a speedy trial.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-7(2): The victim of a crime has the right to a speedy disposition of the charges free from unwarranted delay caused by or at the behest of the defendant or minor and to prompt and final conclusion of the case after the disposition or conviction and sentence, including prompt and final conclusion of all collateral attacks on dispositions or criminal judgments.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-7(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-7(3)(a): In ruling on any motion by a defendant or minor to continue a previously established trial or other important criminal or juvenile justice hearing, the court shall inquire into the circumstances requiring the delay and consider the interests of the victim of a crime to a speedy disposition of the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-7(3)(b): If a continuance is granted, the court shall enter in the record the specific reason for the continuance and the procedures that have been taken to avoid further delays.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-8 Age-appropriate language at judicial proceedings -- Advisor.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-8(1): In any criminal proceeding or juvenile court proceeding regarding or involving a child, examination and cross-examination of a victim or witness 13 years of age or younger shall be conducted in age-appropriate language.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-8(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-8(2)(a): The court may appoint an advisor to assist a witness 13 years of age or younger in understanding questions asked by counsel.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-8(2)(b): The advisor is not required to be an attorney.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9 Representative of victim -- Court designation -- Representation in cases involving minors -- Photographs in homicide cases.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(1)(a): A victim of a crime may designate, with the approval of the court, a representative who may exercise the same rights that the victim is entitled to exercise under this chapter, including pursuing restitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(1)(b): Except as otherwise provided in this section, the victim may revoke the designation at any time.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(1)(c): In cases where the designation is in question, the court may require that the designation of the representative be made in writing by the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(2): In cases in which the victim is deceased or incapacitated, upon request from the victim's spouse, parent, child, or close friend, the court shall designate a representative or representatives of the victim to exercise the rights of a victim under this chapter on behalf of the victim.  The responsible prosecuting agency may request a designation to the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(3)(a): If the victim is a minor, the court in its discretion may allow the minor to exercise the rights of a victim under this chapter or may allow the victim's parent or other immediate family member to act as a representative of the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(3)(b): The court may also, in its discretion, designate a person who is not a member of the immediate family to represent the interests of the minor.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(4): The representative of a victim of a crime shall not be:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(4)(a): the accused or a person who appears to be accountable or otherwise criminally responsible for or criminally involved in the crime or conduct, a related crime or conduct, or a crime or act arising from the same conduct, criminal episode, or plan as the crime or conduct is defined under the laws of this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(4)(b): a person in the custody of or under detention of federal, state, or local authorities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(4)(c): a person whom the court in its discretion considers to be otherwise inappropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(5): Any notices that are to be provided to a victim pursuant to this chapter shall be sent to the victim or the victim's lawful representative.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(6): On behalf of the victim, the prosecutor may assert any right to which the victim is entitled under this chapter, unless the victim requests otherwise or exercises his own rights.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-9(7): In any homicide prosecution, the prosecution may introduce a photograph of the victim taken before the homicide to establish that the victim was a human being, the identity of the victim, and for other relevant purposes.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-10 Victim's discretion.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-10(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-10(1)(a): The victim may exercise any rights under this chapter at his discretion to be present and to be heard at a court proceeding, including a juvenile delinquency proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-10(1)(b): The absence of the victim at the court proceeding does not preclude the court from conducting the proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-10(2): A victim shall not refuse to comply with an otherwise lawful subpoena under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-10(3): A victim shall not prevent the prosecution from complying with requests for information within a prosecutor's possession and control under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11 Enforcement -- Appellate review -- No right to money damages.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(1): 63M-7-1003 If a person acting under color of state law allegedly violates the rights of a victim described in this chapter, Chapter 37, Victims' Rights, or Utah Constitution, Article I, Section 28, the victim, or a representative of a victim, may file a complaint with a victim rights committee as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(2): If a person acting under color of state law willfully or wantonly fails to perform duties so that the rights in this chapter are not provided, an action for injunctive relief, including prospective injunctive relief, may be brought against the individual and the governmental entity that employs the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(3)(a): The victim of a crime or representative of a victim of a crime may:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(3)(a)(i): bring an action for declaratory relief or for a writ of mandamus defining or enforcing the rights of victims and the obligations of government entities under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(3)(a)(ii): petition to file an amicus brief in any court in any case affecting crime victims; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(3)(a)(iii): after giving notice to the prosecution and the defense, seek an appropriate remedy for a violation of a victim's right from the court assigned to the case involving the issue.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(3)(b): Adverse rulings on these actions or on a motion or request brought by a victim of a crime or a representative of a victim of a crime may be appealed under the rules governing appellate actions, provided that an appeal may not constitute grounds for delaying any criminal or juvenile proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(3)(c): An appellate court shall review all properly presented issues, including issues that are capable of repetition but would otherwise evade review.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(4)(a): Upon a showing that the victim has not unduly delayed in seeking to protect the victim's right, and after hearing from the prosecution and the defense, the court shall determine whether a right of the victim has been violated.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(4)(b): If the court determines that a victim's right has been violated, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(4)(b)(i): determine the appropriate remedy for the violation of the victim's right by hearing from the victim and the partiesand considering all factors relevant to the issue; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(4)(b)(ii): award an appropriate remedy to the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(5)(a): The court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(5)(a)(i): reconsider any judicial decision or judgment affected by a violation of the victim's right; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(5)(a)(ii): upon affording the victim the right and further hearing from the prosecution and the defense, determine whether the decision or judgment would have been different.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(5)(b): If the court's decision or judgment would have been different, the court shall enter the new different decision or judgment as the appropriate remedy.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(5)(c): If necessary to protect the victim's right, the court shall enter the new decision or judgment nunc pro tunc to the time the first decision or judgment was reached.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(5)(d): In no event shall the appropriate remedy be a new trial, damages, attorney fees, or costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(6)(a): The appropriate remedy under Subsection (4) or (5) shall include only actions necessary to provide the victim the right to which the victim was entitled.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(6)(b): The appropriate remedy under Subsection (4) or (5) may include reopening previously held proceedings.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(7)(a): Subject to Subsection (7)(c), the court may reopen a sentence or a previously entered guilty or no contest plea only if reopening the sentence or plea:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(7)(a)(i): would not preclude continued prosecution or sentencing the defendant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(7)(a)(ii): would not otherwise permit the defendant to escape justice.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(7)(b): The court shall tailor a remedy to provide the victim with an appropriate remedy without violating any constitutional right of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(7)(c): If the court sets aside a previously entered plea of guilty or no contest, and the continued prosecution of the charge is held to be prevented by the defendant's having been previously put in jeopardy, the order setting aside the plea is void and the plea is reinstated as of the date of the plea's original entry.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(7)(d): The court may not award as a remedy the dismissal of any criminal charge.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(7)(e): The court may not award any remedy if the proceeding that the victim is challenging occurred more than 90 days before the day on which the victim filed an action alleging the violation of the right.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(8): The failure to provide the rights in this chapter or Chapter 37, Victims' Rights, shall not constitute cause for a judgment against the state or any government entity, or any individual employed by the state or any government entity, for monetary damages, attorney fees, or the costs of exercising any rights under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-11(9): A defendant convicted of an offense may not bring an action or complaint concerning a violation of this chapter or Chapter 37, Victims' Rights.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-12 Construction of this chapter -- No right to set aside conviction, adjudication, admission, or plea -- Severability clause.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-12(1): All of the provisions contained in this chapter shall be construed to assist the victims of crime.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-12(2): This chapter may not be construed as creating a basis for dismissing any criminal charge or delinquency petition, vacating any adjudication or conviction, admission or  plea of guilty or no contest, or for a defendant to obtain appellate, habeas corpus, or other relief from a judgment in any criminal or delinquency case.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-12(3): This chapter may not be construed as creating any right of a victim to appointed counsel at state expense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-12(4): All of the rights contained in this chapter shall be construed to conform to the Constitution of the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-12(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-12(5)(a): In the event that any portion of this chapter is found to violate the Constitution of the United States, the remaining provisions of this chapter shall continue to operate in full force and effect.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-12(5)(b): In the event that a particular application of any portion of this chapter is found to violate the Constitution of the United States, all other applications shall continue to operate in full force and effect.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-12(6): The enumeration of certain rights for crime victims in this chapter shall not be construed to deny or disparage other rights granted by the Utah Constitution or the Legislature or retained by victims of crimes.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-13 Declaration of legislative authority.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
It is the view of the Legislature that the provisions of this chapter, and other provisions enacted simultaneously with it, are substantive provisions within inherent legislative authority.  In the event that any of the provisions of this chapter, and other provisions enacted simultaneously with it, are interpreted to be procedural in nature, the Legislature also intends to invoke its powers to modify procedural rules under the Utah Constitution.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-14 Notice of expungement petition -- Victim's right to object.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-14(1): 77-40a-305; 80-6-1004.1
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-14(1)(a): 77-40a-305; 80-6-1004.1 The Department of Corrections or the Juvenile Probation Department shall prepare a document explaining the right of a victim or a victim's representative to object to a petition for expungement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-14(1)(b): The department or division shall provide each trial court a copy of the document that has jurisdiction over delinquencies or criminal offenses subject to expungement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-14(2): 77-40a-305; 80-6-1004.1 The prosecuting attorney in any case leading to a conviction, a charge dismissed in accordance with a plea in abeyance agreement, or an adjudication subject to expungement, shall provide a copy of the document to each person who would be entitled to notice of a petition for expungement under Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-201 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known and cited as the "Confidential Communications for Sexual Assault Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-202 Purpose.
----------------------------------------
It is the purpose of this act to enhance and promote the mental, physical and emotional recovery of victims of sexual assault and to protect the information given by victims to sexual assault counselors from being disclosed.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-203 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-203(1): "Confidential communication" means information given to a sexual assault counselor by a victim and includes reports or working papers made in the course of the counseling relationship.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-203(2): 53B-28-201
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-203(2)(a): "Rape crisis and services center" means a nonprofit entity that assists victims of sexual assault and victims' families by offering sexual assault crisis intervention and counseling through a sexual assault counselor.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-203(2)(b): 53B-28-201 "Rape crisis and services center" does not include a qualified institutional victim services provider as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-203(3): "Sexual assault counselor" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-203(3)(a): is employed by or volunteers at a rape crisis and services center;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-203(3)(b): has a minimum of 40 hours of training in counseling and assisting victims of sexual assault; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-203(3)(c): is under the supervision of the director or designee of a rape crisis and services center.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-203(4): "Victim" means an individual who has experienced a sexual assault of whatever nature including incest and rape and requests counseling or assistance regarding the mental, physical, and emotional consequences of the sexual assault.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-204 Disclosure of confidential communications.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
The confidential communication between a victim and a sexual assault counselor is available to a third person only when:Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-204(1): the victim is a minor and the counselor believes it is in the best interest of the victim to disclose the confidential communication to the victim's parents;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-204(2): the victim is a minor and the minor's parents or guardian have consented to disclosure of the confidential communication to a third party based upon representations made by the counselor that it is in the best interest of the minor victim to make such disclosure;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-204(3): the victim is not a minor, has given consent, and the counselor believes the disclosure is necessary to accomplish the desired result of counseling; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-204(4): Title 80, Chapter 2, Child Welfare Services; Title 80, Chapter 2a, Removal and Protective Custody of a Child the counselor has an obligation under


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-301 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Profits from Notorious Criminal Activity Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(1): "Convicted person" means a person who has been convicted of a crime.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(2): "Conviction" means an adjudication by a federal or state court resulting from a trial or plea, including a plea of no contest, nolo contendere, a finding of not guilty due to insanity, or not guilty but having a mental condition regardless of whether the sentence was imposed or suspended.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(3): 63M-7-526 "Fund" means the Crime Victim Reparations Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(4): "Memorabilia" means any tangible property of a convicted person or a representative or assignee of a convicted person, the value of which is enhanced by the notoriety gained from the criminal activity for which the person was convicted.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(5): "Notoriety of crimes contract" means a contract or other agreement with a convicted person, or a representative or assignee of a convicted person, with respect to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(5)(a): the reenactment of a crime in any manner including a movie, book, magazine article, Internet website, recording, phonograph record, radio or television presentation, or live entertainment of any kind;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(5)(b): the expression of the convicted person's thoughts, feelings, opinions, or emotions regarding a crime involving or causing personal injury, death, or property loss as a direct result of the crime; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(5)(c): the payment or exchange of any money or other consideration or the proceeds or profits that directly or indirectly result from the notoriety of the crime.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(6): "Office" means the Utah Office for Victims of Crime.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(7): "Profit" means any income or benefit:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(7)(a): over and above the fair market value of tangible property that is received upon the sale or transfer of memorabilia; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-302(7)(b): any money, negotiable instruments, securities, or other consideration received or contracted for gain which is traceable to a notoriety of crimes contract.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303 Profit from sale of memorabilia or notoriety of crimes contract -- Deposit in Crime Victim Reparations Fund -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(1): Any convicted person or a representative or assignee of a convicted person who receives a profit from the sale or transfer of memorabilia shall remit to the fund:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(1)(a): a complete, itemized accounting of the transaction, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(1)(a)(i): a description of each item sold;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(1)(a)(ii): the amount received for each item;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(1)(a)(iii): the estimated fair market value of each item; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(1)(a)(iv): the name and address of the purchaser of each item; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(1)(b): a check or money order for the amount of the profit, which shall be the difference between the amount received for the item and the estimated fair market value of the item.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(2): (1) Any person who willfully violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(3)(a): Any person or entity who enters into a notoriety of crime contract with a convicted person or with a representative or assignee of a convicted person shall pay to the fund any profit which by the terms of the contract would otherwise be owing to the convicted person or representative or assignee of the convicted person.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(3)(b): (3)(a) A convicted person or a representative or assignee of a convicted person who has received any profit from a notoriety of crime contract shall remit the profit to the fund.  Any future profit which, by the terms of the contract, would otherwise be owing to the convicted person or a representative or assignee of a convicted person shall be paid to the fund as required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(4): (3) Upon receipt of money under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(5): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(5)(a): (3) Any person or entity who willfully violates Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(5)(b): Any civil penalty ordered under this Subsection shall be paid to the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(6): The prosecuting agency or the attorney general may bring an action to enforce the provisions of this chapter in the court of conviction.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-303(7): (1); (3) A court shall enter an order to remit funds as provided in this chapter if it finds by a preponderance of the evidence any violation of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-401 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Privileged Communications with Victim Advocates Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-402 Purpose.
----------------------------------------
It is the purpose of this part to enhance and promote the mental, physical, and emotional recovery of victims by restricting the circumstances under which a confidential communication with the victim may be disclosed.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(1): "Advocacy services" means assistance provided that supports, supplements, intervenes, or links a victim or a victim's family with appropriate resources and services to address the wide range of potential impacts of being victimized.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(2): "Advocacy services provider" means an entity that has the primary focus of providing advocacy services in general or with specialization to a specific crime type or specific type of victimization.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(3): "Confidential communication" means a communication that is intended to be confidential between a victim and a victim advocate for the purpose of obtaining advocacy services.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(4): "Criminal justice system victim advocate" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(4)(a): is employed or authorized to volunteer by a government agency that possesses a role or responsibility within the criminal justice system;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(4)(b): has as a primary responsibility addressing the mental, physical, or emotional recovery of victims;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(4)(c): completes a minimum 40 hours of trauma-informed training:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(4)(c)(i): in crisis response, the effects of crime and trauma on victims, victim advocacy services and ethics, informed consent, and this part regarding privileged confidential communication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(4)(c)(ii): that have been approved or provided by the Utah Office for Victims of Crime; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(4)(d): is under the supervision of the director or director's designee of the government agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(5): 78B-3-403 "Health care provider" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(6): 58-60-102 "Mental health therapist" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(7): "Nongovernment organization victim advocate" means an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(7)(a): is employed or authorized to volunteer by an nongovernment organization advocacy services provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(7)(b): has as a primary responsibility addressing the mental, physical, or emotional recovery of victims;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(7)(c): has a minimum 40 hours of trauma-informed training:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(7)(c)(i): in assisting victims specific to the specialization or focus of the nongovernment organization advocacy services provider and includes this part regarding privileged confidential communication; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(7)(c)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(7)(c)(ii)(A): that have been approved or provided by the Utah Office for Victims of Crime; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(7)(c)(ii)(B): that meets other minimally equivalent standards set forth by the nongovernment organization advocacy services provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(7)(d): is under the supervision of the director or the director's designee of the nongovernment organization advocacy services provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(8): "Record" means a book, letter, document, paper, map, plan, photograph, file, card, tape, recording, electronic data, or other documentary material regardless of physical form or characteristics.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(9): 77-38-2; 77-36-1; 78B-7-102 "Victim" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(9)(a): 77-38-2 a victim of a crime as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(9)(b): 77-36-1 an individual who is a victim of domestic violence as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(9)(c): 78B-7-102 an individual who is a victim of dating violence as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(10)(a): "Victim advocate" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(10)(a)(i): a criminal justice system victim advocate;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(10)(a)(ii): a nongovernment organization victim advocate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(10)(a)(iii): an individual who is employed or authorized to volunteer by a public or private entity and is designated by the Utah Office for Victims of Crime as having the specific purpose of providing advocacy services to or for the clients of the public or private entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-403(10)(b): "Victim advocate" does not include an employee of the Utah Office for Victims of Crime.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-404 Scope of part.
----------------------------------------------
This part governs the disclosure of a confidential communication to a victim advocate, except that:Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-404(1): Title 53B, Chapter 28, Part 2, Confidential Communications for Institutional Advocacy Services Act if
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-404(2): Part 2, Confidential Communications for Sexual Assault Act if


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-405 Disclosure of a communication given to a victim advocate.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-405(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-405(1)(a): A victim advocate may not disclose a confidential communication with a victim, including a confidential communication in a group therapy session, except:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-405(1)(a)(i): that a criminal justice system victim advocate shall provide the confidential communication to a prosecutor who is responsible for determining whether the confidential communication is exculpatory or goes to the credibility of a witness;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-405(1)(a)(ii): that a criminal justice system victim advocate may provide the confidential communication to a parent or guardian of a victim if the victim is a minor and the parent or guardian is not the accused, or a law enforcement officer, health care provider, mental health therapist, domestic violence shelter employee, an employee of the Utah Office for Victims of Crime, or member of a multidisciplinary team assembled by a Children's Justice Center or a law enforcement agency for the purpose of providing advocacy services; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-405(1)(a)(iii): to the extent allowed by the Utah Rules of Evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-405(1)(b): If a prosecutor determines that the confidential communication is exculpatory or goes to the credibility of a witness, after the court notifies the victim and the defense attorney of the opportunity to be heard at an in camera review, the prosecutor will present the confidential communication to the victim, defense attorney, and the court for in camera review in accordance with the Utah Rules of Evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-405(2): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act A record that contains information from a confidential communication between a victim advocate and a victim may not be disclosed under
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-405(3): A criminal justice system victim advocate, as soon as reasonably possible, shall notify a victim, or a parent or guardian of the victim if the victim is a minor and the parent or guardian is not the accused:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-405(3)(a): whether a confidential communication with the criminal justice system victim advocate will be disclosed to a prosecutor and whether a statement relating to the incident that forms the basis for criminal charges or goes to the credibility of a witness will also be disclosed to the defense attorney; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-405(3)(b): of the name, location, and contact information of one or more nongovernment organization advocacy services providers specializing in the victim's service needs, when a nongovernment organization advocacy services provider exists and is known to the criminal justice system victim advocate.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503 Guidelines for prosecutors.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(1): Upon the request of the victim or victim's family member, a certifying official from a certifying entity shall certify victim helpfulness on the Form I-918 Supplement B certification, if the certifying entity determines the victim was a victim of a qualifying criminal activity and has been helpful, is being helpful, or is likely to be helpful to the detection, investigation, or prosecution of that qualifying criminal activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(2): (1) A certifying entity shall determine helpfulness as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(3): A certifying entity shall process a Form I-918 Supplement B certification within 90 days of request, unless the noncitizen is in removal proceedings, in which case the certification shall be processed within 14 days of request.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(4): A current investigation, the filing of charges, a prosecution, or a conviction are not required for the victim to request the Form I-918 Supplement B certification from a certifying official.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(5): A certifying official may withdraw a Form I-918 Supplement B certification if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(5)(a): the victim refuses to provide information and assistance when reasonably requested; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(5)(b): the certifying entity determines that the individual is not a victim of a qualifying criminal activity.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(6): A certifying entity is prohibited from disclosing the immigration status of a victim or person requesting the Form I-918 Supplement B certification, except to comply with federal law, or if authorized by the victim or person requesting the Form I-918 Supplement B certification.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(7): (7)(a); (7)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(7)(a): Each certifying entity shall maintain records of the following information related to each request for a Form I-918 Supplement B certification:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(7)(a)(i): the number of victims that requested Form I-918 Supplement B certifications from the entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(7)(a)(ii): the number of those Form I-918 Supplement B certifications that were signed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(7)(a)(iii): the number of Form I-918 Supplement B certifications that were denied.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(7)(b): (7)(a) Each certifying entity shall report the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(7)(c): (7)(b) The commission shall report the information received pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(8): (8)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(8)(a): A certifying entity may not disclose personal identifying information, or information regarding the citizenship or immigration status of any victim of criminal activity or trafficking who is requesting a certification unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(8)(a)(i): required to do so by applicable state or federal law or court order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(8)(a)(ii): the certifying agency has written authorization from:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(8)(a)(ii)(A): the victim; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(8)(a)(ii)(B): if the victim is a minor or is otherwise not legally competent, from the victim's parent or guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-503(8)(b): (8)(a) Subsection
