Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-602 Creation -- Commission responsibilities.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-602(1): There is created the Safe at Home Program within the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-602(2): Under the program, the commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-602(2)(a): designate, train, and manage program assistants;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-602(2)(b): develop, distribute, and process application forms and related materials for the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-602(2)(c): designate an assigned address for a program participant to be used by the program participant and a state or local government entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-602(2)(d): receive mail sent to a program participant's assigned address, forward the mail to the program participant's actual address at the commission's expense, and track and maintain records for all mail received.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603 Eligibility.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1): An applicant is eligible to participate in the program if the applicant attests that the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(a): is a resident of this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(b)(i): is a victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(b)(ii): is a parent or a guardian of an individual who:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(b)(ii)(A): is a victim; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(b)(ii)(B): resides at the same address as the parent or guardian;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(b)(iii): resides at the same address where a victim resides; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(b)(iv): fears for the applicant's physical safety, or for the physical safety of a minor or incapacitated individual residing at the same address as the applicant, from a threat of abuse, domestic violence, human trafficking, stalking, or sexual assault;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(c)(i): resided at a residential address that was known by an assailant and relocated within the past 90 days to a different residential address that is not known by the assailant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(c)(ii): resides at a residential address known by the assailant and intends to relocate within 90 days to a different residential address in the state that is not known by the assailant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(c)(iii): resides at a residential address that is not known by the assailant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(d): will not disclose the different residential address to the assailant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(1)(e): will benefit from participation in the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(2): An applicant may participate in the program regardless of whether:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(2)(a): a criminal charge is filed against an assailant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(2)(b): the applicant has a restraining order or injunction against an assailant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(2)(c): the applicant reported an act or threat by an assailant to a law enforcement agency or officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(3): An applicant may participate in the program only upon the recommendation of a program assistant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(4): To participate in the program:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(4)(a): an applicant shall sign, date, and verify the information on an application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(4)(b): the commission shall verify the applicant's current residential address as provided on the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-603(5): A parent or guardian may act on behalf of a minor or an incapacitated individual in determining whether the minor or the incapacitated individual is eligible for the program.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604 Designation of program assistants.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604(1): The commission may designate as a program assistant, an individual that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604(1)(a)(i): is an employee of the commission or a state or local government entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604(1)(a)(ii): is a volunteer for an organization that provides counseling, assistance, or support services at no charge to victims; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604(1)(b)(i): provides counseling, referrals, or other services to victims; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604(1)(b)(ii): completes any training or registration process required by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604(2): A program assistant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604(2)(a): assist an applicant in preparing an application for the program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604(2)(b): sign, date, and verify an application for the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-604(3): 77-38-603 A signature of a program assistant is a recommendation by the program assistant that the applicant is eligible to participate in the program under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605 Administration -- Application.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(1): The commission shall provide an application form to an applicant who seeks to participate in the program under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(2): The commission may not charge an applicant or program participant for an application or participation fee to apply for, or participate in, the program.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3): 77-38-617 The application shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(a): the applicant's name;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(b): a mailing address, a phone number, and an email address where the applicant may be contacted by the commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(c): an indication regarding whether the assailant is employed by a state or local government entity, and if applicable, the name of the state or local government entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(d): 77-38-617 a statement that the applicant understands and consents to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(d)(i): 77-38-617 remain enrolled in the program for four years, unless the applicant's participation in the program is cancelled under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(d)(vi): register to vote in person at the office of the clerk in the county where the applicant's actual address is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(d)(vii): certify that the commission is the applicant's designated agent for service of process for personal service;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(e): evidence that the applicant, or a minor or an incapacitated individual residing with the applicant, is a victim, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(e)(i): a law enforcement, court, or other state, local, or federal government agency record; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(e)(ii): a document from:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(e)(ii)(A): a domestic violence program, facility, or shelter;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(e)(ii)(B): a sexual assault program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(e)(ii)(C): a religious, medical, or other professional from whom the applicant, or the minor or the incapacitated individual residing with the applicant, sought assistance in dealing with alleged abuse, domestic violence, stalking, or a sexual offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(f): a statement from the applicant that a disclosure of the applicant's actual address would endanger the applicant, or a minor or an incapacitated individual residing with the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(g): a statement by the applicant that the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(g)(i): resides at a residential address that is not known by the assailant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(g)(ii): has relocated to a different residential address in the past 90 days that is not known by the assailant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(g)(iii): will relocate to a different residential address in the state within 90 days that is not known by the assailant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(h): the actual address that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(h)(i): the applicant requests that the commission not disclose; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(h)(ii): is at risk of discovery by the assailant or potential assailant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(i): a statement by the applicant disclosing:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(i)(i): the existence of a court order or action involving the applicant, or a minor or an incapacitated individual residing with the applicant, related to a divorce proceeding, a child support order or judgment, or the allocation of custody or parent-time; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(i)(ii): the court that issued the order or has jurisdiction over the action;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(j): the name of any other individual who resides with the applicant who needs to be a program participant to ensure the safety of the applicant, or a minor or an incapacitated individual residing with the applicant;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(k): a statement by the applicant that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(k)(i): the applicant, or a minor or an incapacitated individual residing at the same address as the applicant, will benefit from participation in the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(k)(ii): if the applicant intends to vote, the applicant will register to vote at the office of the clerk in the county in which the applicant actually resides; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(k)(iii): the applicant does not have a current obligation to register as a sex offender, kidnap offender, or child abuse offender under Title 77, Chapter 41, Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(l): a statement by the applicant, under penalty of perjury, that the information contained in the application is true;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(m): a statement that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(m)(i): if the applicant intends to use the assigned address for any correspondence with the State Tax Commission, the applicant must provide the State Tax Commission with the applicant's social security number, federal employee identification number, and any other identification number related to a tax, fee, charge, or license administered by the State Tax Commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(m)(ii): if the applicant intends to use the assigned address for correspondence to a state or local government entity for the purpose of titling or registering a motor vehicle or a watercraft that is owned or leased by the applicant, the applicant shall provide to the state or local government entity for each motor vehicle or watercraft:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(m)(ii)(A): the motor vehicle or hull identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(m)(ii)(B): the license plate or registration number for the motor vehicle or the watercraft; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(m)(ii)(C): the physical address where each motor vehicle or watercraft is stored; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-605(3)(n): a statement that any assistance or counseling provided by a program assistant as part of the program does not constitute legal advice or legal services to the applicant.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-606(4)(c): 77-38-605(3) The renewal application shall contain:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-606(4)(c)(iii): a statement by the applicant, under penalty of perjury, that the information contained in the renewal application is true.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609 Disclosure of actual address prohibited.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609(1): 77-38-612; (1)(a)(i); (ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609(1)(a): 77-38-612 The commission may not disclose a program participant's actual address, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609(1)(a)(i): required by a court order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609(1)(a)(ii): 77-38-612 the commission grants a request from a state or local government entity under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609(1)(b): (1)(a)(i); (ii) The commission shall provide a program participant immediate notification of a disclosure of the program participant's actual address if the disclosure is made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609(2): If, at the time of application, an applicant, or a parent or guardian of an applicant, is subject to a court order relating to a divorce proceeding, a child support order or judgment, or an allocation of custody or parent-time, the commission shall provide notice of whether the applicant is enrolled under the program and the assigned address of the applicant to the court that issued the order or has jurisdiction over the action.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609(3): A person may not knowingly or intentionally obtain a program participant's actual address from the commission or any state or local government entity if the person is not authorized to obtain the program participant's actual address.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609(4): Unless the disclosure is permitted under this part or is otherwise permitted by law, an employee of the commission or a state or local government entity may not knowingly or intentionally disclose a program participant's actual address if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609(4)(a): the employee obtains a program participant's actual address during the course of the employee's official duties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609(4)(b): at the time of disclosure, the employee has specific knowledge that the address is the actual address of the program participant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-609(5): A person who intentionally or knowingly obtains or discloses information in violation of this part is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-610 Change of name, address, or telephone number.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-610(1): A program participant shall notify the commission no later than 30 days after the day on which the program participant obtains a legal name change, by providing the commission with a certified copy of a judgment or order establishing the name change, or any other documentation that is sufficient evidence of the name change.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-610(2): A program participant shall notify the commission no later than 10 business days after the day on which the program participant's actual address or telephone number changes from the actual address or telephone number listed for the program participant.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612 Request for disclosure.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(1): A state or local government entity requesting disclosure of a program participant's actual address in accordance with this section shall make the request:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(1)(a): in writing;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(1)(b): on the state or local government entity's letterhead; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(1)(c): with the signature of the head or an executive-level official of the state or local government entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(2): (1) In accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(2)(a): explaining why the state or local government entity is requesting the program participant's actual address;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(2)(b): explaining why the state or local government entity cannot meet the state or local government entity's statutory or administrative obligations without the disclosure of the program participant's actual address;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(2)(c): of facts showing that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(2)(c)(i): other methods to locate the program participant's actual address have failed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(2)(c)(ii): other methods will be unlikely to succeed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(2)(c)(iii): other means of contacting the program participant have failed or are unavailable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(2)(d): that the state or local government entity has adopted a procedure to protect the confidentiality of the program participant's actual address.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(3): (2) In response to a request for disclosure under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(4): (4)(b); (1); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(4)(a): (4)(b); (1) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(4)(a)(i): informing the participant of the request, and to the extent possible, of an opportunity to be heard regarding the request; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(4)(a)(ii): after a decision is made by the commission, whether the request has been granted or denied.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(4)(b): (4)(a) The commission is not required to provide notice of a request for disclosure to a program participant under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(4)(b)(i): the request is made by a state or local law enforcement agency conducting a criminal investigation involving alleged criminal conduct by the program participant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(4)(b)(ii): providing notice to the program participant would jeopardize an ongoing criminal investigation or the safety of law enforcement personnel.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(5): The commission shall grant a state or local government entity's request for disclosure and disclose the program participant's actual address if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(5)(a): the state or local government entity has demonstrated a good faith statutory or administrative need for the actual address;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(5)(b): the actual address will be used only for the purpose stated in the request;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(5)(c): other methods to locate the program participant or the program participant's actual address have failed or are unlikely to succeed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(5)(d): other means of contacting the program participant have failed or are unavailable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(5)(e): the state or local government entity has adopted a procedure to protect the confidentiality of the program participant's actual address.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(6): If the commission grants a request for disclosure under this section, the commission shall provide the state or local government entity with a disclosure that contains:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(6)(a): the program participant's actual address;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(6)(b): a statement of the permitted use of the program participant's actual address;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(6)(c): the names or classes of persons permitted to have access to or use of the program participant's actual address;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(6)(d): a statement that the state or local government entity is required to limit access to and use of the program participant's actual address to the permitted use and to the listed persons or classes of persons; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(6)(e): if expiration of the disclosure is appropriate, the date on which the permitted use of the program participant's actual address expires.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(7): If a request for disclosure is granted by the commission, a state or local government entity shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(7)(a): limit use of the program participant's actual address to the purpose stated in the disclosure;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(7)(b): limit access to the program participant's actual address to the persons or classes of persons stated in the disclosure;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(7)(c): cease use of the program participant's actual address upon the expiration of the permitted use;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(7)(d): dispose of the program participant's actual address upon the expiration of the permitted use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(7)(e): except as permitted in the request for disclosure, maintain the confidentiality of the program participant's actual address.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(8): Upon denial of a state or local government entity's request for disclosure, the commission shall promptly provide a written notification to the state or local government entity explaining the specific reasons for denying the request for disclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(9): (8); (9)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(9)(a): (8) A state or local government entity may file a written appeal with the commission no later than 15 days after the day on which the state or local government entity receives the written notification under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(9)(b): (9)(a) A state or local government entity filing a written appeal under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(9)(b)(i): restate the information contained in the request for disclosure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(9)(b)(ii): respond to the commission's reason for denying the request for disclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(9)(c): The commission shall make a final determination on the appeal within 30 days after the day on which the appeal is received by the commission, unless the state or local government entity and the commission agree to a different deadline.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-612(9)(d): Before the commission makes a final determination, the commission may conduct a hearing or request additional information from the state or local government entity or the program participant.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-613 Request for disclosure by law enforcement.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-613(1): The commission shall establish a process to expedite a request submitted by a law enforcement officer or agency for the disclosure of information regarding a program participant who is involved in a criminal proceeding or investigation within 24 hours of the law enforcement officer or agency submitting the request.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-613(2): (1) If a law enforcement officer or agency seeks the disclosure of a program participant's actual address from the commission under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-613(2)(a): the public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-613(2)(b): law enforcement personnel who are not involved in the criminal proceeding or investigation for which the disclosure is requested.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-613(3): Upon expiration of the use for the program participant's actual address in a criminal proceeding or investigation, a law enforcement officer or agency shall remove the program participant's actual address from any record system maintained by the law enforcement officer or agency.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-614 Service of process at the assigned address.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-614(1): In accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 4, the commission is the agent authorized to receive process for a program participant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-614(2): In accordance with the Utah Rules of Civil Procedure, Rule 5, the last known address for a program participant is the program participant's assigned address, not the program participant's actual address.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-615 Participation in the program -- Orders in relation to allocation of custody or parent-time.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-615(1): A court may not consider a parent's participation in the program for the purpose of making an order allocating custody or parent-time under Title 81, Chapter 9, Custody, Parent-time, and Visitation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-615(2): A court shall take practical measures to keep a program participant's actual address confidential when making an order allocating custody or parent-time.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-615(3): Nothing in this part affects an order relating to the allocation of custody or parent-time in effect prior to or during a program participant's participation in the program.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-616 Disclosure of address or identifiable information in a judicial or administrative proceeding.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-616(1): A program participant may submit the program participant's actual address to the court as a safeguarded record in accordance with the Utah Code of Judicial Administration, Rule 4-202.02.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-616(2): A person may not compel disclosure of a program participant's actual address or identifying information related to the program participant's residence during a proceeding in a court or administrative proceeding, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-616(2)(a): the court orders the disclosure of the program participant's address; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-616(2)(b): an administrative tribunal finds, based on a preponderance of the evidence, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-616(2)(b)(i): the disclosure is required in the interest of justice;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-616(2)(b)(ii): public interest in the disclosure substantially outweighs the potential harm to the program participant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-616(2)(b)(iii): no other alternative would satisfy the necessity of the disclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-616(3): If disclosure of a program participant's actual address is required in a proceeding before a court or administrative tribunal, the court or administrative tribunal may safeguard the portion of a record that contains the program participant's actual address.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-616(4): Nothing in this section prevents a state or local government entity from using a program participant's actual address in filing a document or record with a court or administrative tribunal if, at the time of the filing, the document or record is filed under safeguard or not a public record.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-617 Cancellation of enrollment -- Records.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-617(1): 77-38-606 The commission shall cancel a program participant's enrollment in the program if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-617(1)(a): 77-38-606 the program participant submits to the commission a written request to withdraw from enrollment in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-617(1)(b): the program participant fails to notify the commission of a change in the program participant's name, actual address, or telephone number that is listed on the application;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-617(1)(c): the program participant, or a parent or guardian of the program participant, knowingly submits false information in the program application; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-617(1)(d): mail forwarded to the program participant by the commission is returned as undeliverable.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-617(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-617(2)(a): (1) If the commission determines that there are grounds for cancelling a program participant's enrollment in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-617(2)(b): A program participant has 30 days to appeal the cancellation decision in accordance with procedures developed by the commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-617(3): A program participant who receives a notice of cancellation is responsible for notifying a person who uses the program participant's assigned address to communicate with the program participant that the assigned address is no longer valid.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-617(4): If the commission cancels a program participant's enrollment in the program, the program participant is not eligible to participate in the program for six months after the day on which the commission cancels the program participant's enrollment in the program.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-618 Retention and destruction of records.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
The commission shall establish policies and procedures regarding the maintenance and destruction of applications, records, and other documents received or generated under this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-619 Immunity from suit.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-619(1): A program assistant, or a program assistant's employer, is immune from liability in a civil action or proceeding involving the performance or nonperformance of a duty under this part, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-619(1)(a): the performance or nonperformance of a program assistant was manifestly outside the scope of the program assistant's duties in the program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-619(1)(b): the program assistant acted with malicious purpose, bad faith, or in a wanton or reckless manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-619(2): Title 63G, Chapter 7, Governmental Immunity Act of Utah In addition to the governmental immunity granted in


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620 Safe at Home Program Restricted Account -- Report.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(1): There is created a restricted account in the General Fund known as the "Safe at Home Program Restricted Account."
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(2): The account shall be funded by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(2)(a): private contributions;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(2)(b): gifts, donations, or grants from public or private entities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(2)(c): interest and earnings on account money.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(3): Upon appropriation by the Legislature, the commission may expend funds from the account to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(3)(a): designate, train, and manage program assistants;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(3)(b): develop, distribute, and process application forms and related materials for the program;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(3)(c): assist applicants and program participants in enrolling in the program; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(3)(d): ensure program participants receive mail forwarded from the program to the program participant's actual address.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(4): (2); (3) No later than December 31 of each year, the commission shall provide to the Executive Offices and Criminal Justice Appropriations Subcommittee a written report of the program's activities, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(4)(a): (2) the contributions received under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(4)(b): (3) an accounting of the money expended or committed to be expended by the commission under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38-620(4)(c): the balance of the account.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 38b - Crime Victims Restitution Act
****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Crime Victims Restitution Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(1): 77-32b-102 "Civil accounts receivable" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(2): 77-32b-102 "Civil judgment of restitution" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3): 80-6-701
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(a): "Conviction" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(a)(i): a plea of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(a)(i)(A): guilty;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(a)(i)(B): guilty with a mental condition; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(a)(i)(C): no contest; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(a)(ii): a judgment of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(a)(ii)(A): guilty; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(a)(ii)(B): guilty with a mental condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(b): 80-6-701 "Conviction" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(b)(i): a plea in abeyance until a conviction is entered for the plea in abeyance;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(b)(ii): a diversion agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(3)(b)(iii): 80-6-701 an adjudication of a minor for an offense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(4): 77-32b-102 "Criminal accounts receivable" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(5): "Criminal conduct" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(5)(a): any misdemeanor or felony offense of which the defendant is convicted; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(5)(b): any other criminal behavior for which the defendant admits responsibility to the court with or without an admission of committing the criminal behavior.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(6): "Deceased victim" means an individual whose death is proximately caused by the criminal conduct of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(7): 80-1-102
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(7)(a): "Defendant" means an individual who has been convicted of, or entered into a plea disposition for, criminal conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(7)(b): 80-1-102 "Defendant" does not include a minor, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(8): "Department" means the Department of Corrections.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(9)(a): "Dependent" means an individual for whom a deceased victim, or a permanently impaired victim, had a legal obligation to provide dependent support at the time of the criminal conduct by the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(9)(b): "Dependent" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(9)(b)(i): a child:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(9)(b)(i)(A): who is younger than 18 years old; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(9)(b)(i)(B): for whom a deceased victim, or a permanently impaired victim, is the adoptive or biological parent or legal guardian;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(9)(b)(ii): an unborn child who has a parent-child relationship with a deceased victim, or a permanently impaired victim, in accordance with Title 78B, Chapter 15, Utah Uniform Parentage Act; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(9)(b)(iii): an incapacitated individual for whom a deceased victim, or a permanently impaired victim, is the adoptive or biological parent or the legal guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(10): "Dependent support" means the financial obligation of an individual to provide for the routine needs of a dependent, including food, clothing, health care, safety, or shelter.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(11): "Diversion agreement" means an agreement entered into by the prosecuting attorney and the defendant that suspends criminal proceedings before conviction on the condition that a defendant agree to participate in a rehabilitation program, pay restitution to the victim, or fulfill some other condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(12): "Incapacitated" or "incapacitation" means the individual is:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(12)(a): mentally or physically impaired to the extent that the individual is permanently unable to gain employment and provide basic necessities, including food, clothing, health care, safety, or shelter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(12)(b): reliant on a parent, legal guardian, or other relative or person to provide basic necessities for the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(13): "Incapacitated individual" means an individual who is incapacitated.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(14): "Legal guardian" means an individual appointed by a court to make decisions regarding a child or an incapacitated individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(15): "Life expectancy" means the number of months an individual is or was expected to live considering medical records and experiential data for the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(16): 63A-3-502 "Office" means the Office of State Debt Collection created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(17): 77-32b-102 "Payment schedule" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(18): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(18)(a): "Pecuniary damages" means all demonstrable economic injury, losses, and expenses regardless of whether the economic injury, losses, and expenses have yet been incurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(18)(b): "Pecuniary damages" does not include punitive damages or pain and suffering damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(19): "Permanently impaired victim" means an incapacitated individual whose incapacitation is proximately caused by the criminal conduct of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(20): "Plea agreement" means an agreement entered between the prosecuting attorney and the defendant setting forth the special terms and conditions and criminal charges upon which the defendant will enter a plea of guilty or no contest.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(21): "Plea disposition" means an agreement entered into between the prosecuting attorney and the defendant including a diversion agreement, a plea agreement, a plea in abeyance agreement, or any agreement by which the defendant may enter a plea in any other jurisdiction or where charges are dismissed without a plea.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(22): "Plea in abeyance" means an order by a court, upon motion of the prosecuting attorney and the defendant, accepting a plea of guilty or of no contest from the defendant but not, at that time, entering judgment of conviction against the defendant nor imposing sentence upon the defendant on condition that the defendant comply with specific conditions as set forth in a plea in abeyance agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(23): "Plea in abeyance agreement" means an agreement entered into between the prosecuting attorney and the defendant setting forth the specific terms and conditions upon which, following acceptance of the agreement by the court, a plea may be held in abeyance.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(24): "Restitution" means the payment of pecuniary damages to a victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(25): "Unborn child" means a human fetus or embryo in any stage of gestation from fertilization until birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(26): 63M-7-519
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(26)(a): "Victim" means any person who has suffered pecuniary damages that are proximately caused by the criminal conduct of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(26)(b): 63M-7-519 "Victim" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(26)(b)(i): 63M-7-519 the Utah Office for Victims of Crime if the Utah Office for Victims of Crime makes a payment to, or on behalf of, a victim under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(26)(b)(ii): the estate of a deceased victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(26)(b)(iii): a dependent; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(26)(b)(iv): a parent, spouse, intimate partner as defined in 18 U.S.C. Sec. 921, child, or sibling of a victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-102(26)(c): "Victim" does not include a codefendant or accomplice.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-201 Law enforcement responsibility for collecting restitution information.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-201(1): A law enforcement agency investigating criminal conduct that would constitute a felony or a misdemeanor shall include information about restitution for any potential victim in the investigative report or the citation, including information about whether a claim for restitution may exist.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-201(2): A law enforcement agency shall also include in the investigative report:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-201(2)(a): the basis for the claim for restitution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-201(2)(b): the estimated or actual amount of the claim for restitution.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202 Prosecuting attorney responsibility for collecting restitution information -- Depositing restitution on behalf of victim.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(1): If a prosecuting attorney files a criminal charge against a defendant, the prosecuting attorney shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(1)(a): contact any known victim of the offense for which the criminal charge is filed, or person asserting a claim for restitution on behalf of the victim; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(1)(b): gather the following information from the victim or person:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(1)(b)(i): the name of the victim or person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(1)(b)(ii): the actual or estimated amount of restitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(2): 77-38b-205; 77-38b-205
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(2)(a): When a conviction, a diversion agreement, or a plea in abeyance is entered by the court, the prosecuting attorney shall provide the court with the information gathered by the prosecuting attorney under Subsection (1)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(2)(b): If, at the time of the plea disposition or conviction, the prosecuting attorney does not have all the information under Subsection (1)(b), the prosecuting attorney shall provide the defendant with:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(2)(b)(i): at the time of plea disposition or conviction, all information under Subsection (1)(b) that is reasonably available to the prosecuting attorney; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(2)(b)(ii): any information under Subsection (1)(b) as the information becomes available to the prosecuting attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(2)(c): 77-38b-205; 77-38b-205 Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent a prosecuting attorney, a victim, or a person asserting a claim for restitution on behalf of a victim from:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(2)(c)(i): 77-38b-205 submitting information on, or a request for, restitution to the court within the time periods described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(2)(c)(ii): 77-38b-205 submitting information on, or a request for, restitution for additional or substituted victims within the time periods described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(3): 63A-3-101
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(3)(a): The prosecuting attorney may be authorized by the appropriate public treasurer to deposit restitution collected on behalf of a victim into an interest-bearing account in accordance with Title 51, Chapter 7, State Money Management Act, pending the distribution of the funds to the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(3)(b): 63A-3-101 If restitution is deposited into an interest-bearing account under Subsection (3)(a), the prosecuting attorney shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(3)(b)(i): distribute any interest that accrues in the account to each victim on a pro rata basis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(3)(b)(ii): 63A-3-101 if all victims have been made whole and funds remain in the account, distribute any remaining funds to the Division of Finance, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-202(3)(c): Nothing in this section prevents an independent judicial authority from collecting, holding, and distributing restitution.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203 Department of Corrections responsibility for collecting restitution information -- Presentence investigation report -- In camera review of victim information.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(1): 77-18-103 In preparing a presentence investigation report described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(1)(a): the law enforcement agency and the prosecuting attorney; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(1)(b): any victim of the offense or person asserting a claim for restitution on behalf of the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(2): A victim seeking restitution, a prosecuting attorney, or a person asserting a claim for restitution on behalf of a victim, shall provide the department with:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(2)(a): all invoices, bills, receipts, and any other evidence of pecuniary damages;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(2)(b): all documentation of any compensation or reimbursement from an insurance company or a local, state, or federal agency that is related to the pecuniary damages for the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(2)(c): the victim's proof of identification, including the victim's date of birth, social security number, driver license number; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(2)(d): the victim's or the person's contact information, including next of kin if available, current home and work address, and telephone number.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(3): In the presentence investigation report, the department shall make every effort to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(3)(a): itemize any pecuniary damages suffered by the victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(3)(b): include a specific statement on the amount of restitution that the department recommends for each victim; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(3)(c): include a victim impact statement that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(3)(c)(i): provides the name of each victim and any person asserting a claim on behalf of a victim;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(3)(c)(ii): describes the effect of the offense on the victim and the victim's family;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(3)(c)(iii): describes any physical, mental, or emotional injury suffered by a victim as a result of the offense and the seriousness and permanence of the injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(3)(c)(iv): describes any change in a victim's personal welfare or familial relationships as a result of the offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(3)(c)(v): provides any request for mental health services by a victim or a victim's family member as a result of the offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(3)(c)(vi): provides any other relevant information regarding the impact of the offense upon a victim or the victim's family.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(4): (4)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(4)(a): A prosecuting attorney and the department may take steps that are reasonably necessary to protect the identity of a victim and the victim's family in information that is submitted to the court under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(4)(b): If a defendant seeks to view protected, safeguarded, or confidential information about a victim or a victim's family, the court shall review the information in camera.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(4)(c): (4)(b) The court may allow the defendant to view the information under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(4)(c)(i): the defendant's interest in viewing the information outweighs the victim's or the victim's family safety and privacy interests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-203(4)(c)(ii): there are protections in place to safeguard the victim's and the victim's family safety and privacy interests.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205 Order for restitution.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(1): 76-3-201; 76-3-201; 77-2a-3
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(1)(a): 76-3-201; 76-3-201 If a defendant is convicted, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(1)(a)(i): in accordance with the terms of any plea agreement in the case; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(1)(a)(ii): for the entire amount of pecuniary damages that are proximately caused to each victim by the criminal conduct of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(1)(b): 77-2a-3 If a court enters a plea in abeyance or a diversion agreement for a defendant that includes an agreement to pay restitution, the court shall order the defendant to pay restitution to all victims:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(1)(b)(i): in accordance with the terms of the plea in abeyance or the diversion agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(1)(b)(ii): 77-2a-3 if the terms of the plea in abeyance include an agreement between the parties that restitution will be determined by the court as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(2): 77-38b-206
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(2)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (2)(b), in determining the amount of pecuniary damages under Subsection (1)(a)(ii) or (b)(ii), the court shall consider all relevant facts to establish an amount that fully compensates a victim for all pecuniary damages proximately caused by the criminal conduct of the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(2)(b): 77-38b-206 If the court determines that the defendant owes pecuniary damages to a dependent for dependent support, the court shall establish the amount of dependent support owed to the dependent as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(2)(c): Subsection (2)(b) does not prohibit the court from also ordering restitution for a victim under Subsection (2)(a) that is not dependent support.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(3): The court shall enter the determination of the amount of restitution under Subsection (1)(a)(ii) or (b)(ii) as a finding on the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(4): 77-32b-103; 77-32b-103 Upon an order for a defendant to pay restitution under Subsection (1), the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(4)(a): 77-32b-103 enter an order to establish a criminal accounts receivable as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(4)(b): 77-32b-103 establish a payment schedule for the criminal accounts receivable as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(5): If the defendant objects to a request for restitution, the court shall allow the defendant to have a hearing on the issue, unless the issue is addressed at the sentencing hearing for the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(6): If a court does not enter an order for restitution at sentencing, the court shall schedule a hearing to enter an order for restitution, unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(6)(a): the court finds as a matter of law that there is no victim in the case; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(6)(b): the prosecuting attorney certifies to the court, on the record, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(6)(b)(i): the prosecuting attorney has consulted with all victims, including the Utah Office for Victims of Crime; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(6)(b)(ii): all victims, including the Utah Office for Victims of Crime, are not seeking restitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(7)(a): A court shall enter an order for restitution in a defendant's case no later than the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(7)(a)(i): the termination of the defendant's sentence, including early termination of the defendant's sentence; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(7)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(7)(a)(ii)(A): if the defendant is convicted and imprisoned for a first degree felony, within seven years after the day on which the court sentences the defendant for the first degree felony conviction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(7)(a)(ii)(B): except as provided in Subsection (7)(a)(ii)(A), and if the defendant is convicted of a felony, within three years after the day on which the court sentences the defendant for the felony conviction.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(7)(b): A request for restitution that is made within the time period described in Subsection (7)(a) tolls the time for which the court must enter an order for restitution under Subsection (7)(a) but does not extend the term of the defendant's probation or period of incarceration.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(8)(a): If a court does not order restitution at sentencing or at a hearing described in Subsection (6), the prosecuting attorney or the victim may file a motion for restitution within the time periods described in Subsection (7).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(8)(b): If the defendant receives notice and does not object to a motion for restitution, the court may order restitution without a hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(8)(c): If the defendant receives notice and objects to a motion for restitution, the court may schedule a hearing to determine whether restitution should be ordered if the prosecuting attorney or victim shows good cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-205(9): Upon a motion from the prosecuting attorney or the victim within the time periods described in Subsection (7), the court may modify an existing order of restitution, including the amount of pecuniary damages owed by the defendant in the order for restitution, if the prosecuting attorney or the victim shows good cause for modifying the order.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206 Calculating the amount of restitution owed for dependent support.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(1): 78B-12-303; 78B-12-203 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(1)(a): 78B-12-303 "Base combined child support obligation table" means the child support table located in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(1)(b): 78B-12-203 "Gross income" means the amount of income that would be calculated for a parent for child support purposes as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(1)(c): "Monthly income" means the amount of monthly income established for a deceased victim, or a permanently impaired victim, under Subsection (3).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(2): 77-38b-205 If a defendant owes pecuniary damages to a dependent under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(3)(a): For purposes of determining a defendant's monthly obligation under Subsection (4), the court shall establish the monthly income of the deceased victim, or the permanently impaired victim, by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(3)(a)(i): calculating the deceased or permanently impaired victim's monthly gross income before the victim's death or incapacitation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(3)(a)(ii): dividing the deceased or permanently impaired victim's monthly gross income in half.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(3)(b): If the amount calculated under Subsection (3)(a)(ii) is $3,000 or less, the court shall impute a monthly income of $3,001 to the deceased or permanently impaired victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(3)(c): If the amount calculated under Subsection (3)(a)(ii) is greater than $3,000, the deceased or permanently impaired victim's monthly income is the amount calculated under Subsection (3)(a)(ii).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(4): To calculate the amount of pecuniary damages that a defendant owes a dependent of a deceased victim for dependent support, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(4)(a): locate the monthly dependent support obligation in the base income child support table using:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(4)(a)(i): the deceased victim's monthly income established under Subsection (3)(b) or (c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(4)(a)(ii): the total number of dependents for which the defendant owes dependent support; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(4)(b): multiply the monthly amount established under Subsection (4)(a) for the dependent by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(4)(b)(i): the number of months until the dependent is 18 years old and is graduated from high school if the dependent is a child; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(4)(b)(ii): the life expectancy of the dependent if the dependent is an incapacitated individual who is 18 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(5): To calculate the amount of pecuniary damages that a defendant owes a dependent of a permanently impaired victim for dependent support, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(5)(a): locate the monthly dependent support obligation in the base income child support table using:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(5)(a)(i): the permanently impaired victim's monthly income established under Subsection (3)(b) or (c); and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(5)(a)(ii): the total number of dependents for which the defendant owes dependent support;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(5)(b): multiply the monthly amount established under Subsection (5)(a) by the permanently impaired victim's whole person impairment rating as determined by the most recent edition of the American Medical Association's Guides to the Evaluation of Permanent Impairment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(5)(c): multiply the amount established under Subsection (5)(b) for the dependent by:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(5)(c)(i): the number of months until the dependent is 18 years old and is graduated from high school if the dependent is a child who is younger than 18 years old; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(5)(c)(ii): the life expectancy of the dependent if the dependent is an incapacitated individual who is 18 years old or older.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-206(6): The deceased or permanently impaired victim's monthly income calculated under Subsection (3) is the only income that may be used when locating the monthly dependent support obligation in the base combined child support obligation table.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-301(6)(d): the civil enforcement of a civil judgment does not divest a defendant of an obligation imposed as part of the defendant's punishment in a criminal action.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-302 Nondischargability in bankruptcy.
------------------------------------------------------------------
A civil judgment of restitution and a civil accounts receivable are considered a debt from a criminal case that may not be discharged in bankruptcy.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303 Effect of civil action or settlement for criminal conduct -- Issue preclusion -- Crediting payments.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(1)(a): "Civil settlement" or "settlement" means an agreement entered into between a victim and a defendant that settles all the claims that a victim may bring in a civil action against the defendant for the defendant's criminal conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(1)(b): "Civil settlement" or "settlement" does not include an agreement that settles a civil judgment of restitution or a civil accounts receivable for a defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(2): Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to limit or impair the right of a victim to sue and recover damages from the defendant in a civil action.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(3): 77-38b-205
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(3)(a): 77-38b-205 A court's finding on the amount of restitution owed by a defendant under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(3)(b): If a conviction in a criminal trial decides the issue of a defendant's liability for pecuniary damages suffered by a victim, the issue of the defendant's liability for pecuniary damages is conclusively determined as to the defendant if the issue is involved in a subsequent civil action.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(3)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(3)(c)(i): Except as provided in Subsection (3)(c)(ii), if a defendant is convicted of a misdemeanor or felony offense, the defendant is precluded from subsequently denying the essential allegations of the offense in a subsequent civil action brought against the defendant for the criminal conduct underlying the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(3)(c)(ii): Subsection (3)(c)(i) does not apply if the offense is a class C misdemeanor under Title 41, Chapter 6a, Traffic Code, or the defendant entered a plea of no contest for the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(4): If a civil action brought by a victim against a defendant results in a civil judgment for the defendant's criminal conduct or there is a civil settlement entered into between a victim and defendant for the defendant's criminal conduct, the civil judgment or settlement does not limit or preclude:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(4)(a): the sentencing court from entering an order of restitution against the defendant in accordance with this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(4)(b): the civil enforcement of a civil judgment of restitution by the office or the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(5)(a): The sentencing court shall credit any payment made to a victim in a civil action for the defendant's criminal conduct toward the amount of restitution owed by the defendant to the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(5)(b): In a civil action, a court shall credit any restitution paid by the defendant to a victim for the defendant's criminal conduct towards the victim against any judgment that is in favor of the victim for the civil action.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(5)(c): If a victim receives payment from the defendant for the civil action, the victim shall provide notice to the sentencing court and the court in the civil action of the payment within 30 days after the day on which the victim receives the payment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(6)(a): If a victim prevails in a civil action against a defendant, the court shall award reasonable attorney fees and costs to the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(6)(b): If the defendant prevails in the civil action, the court shall award reasonable costs to the defendant if the court finds that the victim brought the civil action for an improper purpose, including to harass the defendant or to cause unnecessary delay or needless increase in the cost of litigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(7)(a): The sentencing court shall credit any payment made to a victim as part of a civil settlement toward the amount of restitution owed by the defendant to the victim if the sentencing court determines that the payment compensates the victim for pecuniary damages proximately caused by the defendant's criminal conduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(7)(b): If a victim receives a payment from the defendant as part of a civil settlement, the victim shall provide notice to the sentencing court within 30 days after the day on which the victim receives the payment.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(8): Nothing in this section shall prevent a defendant from providing proof of payment to the court or the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(9): Notwithstanding Subsections (5) and (6), if a defendant owes dependent support to a victim in an order for restitution:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(9)(a): the defendant may not use any payment from a motor vehicle insurance policy to satisfy any amount of dependent support owed by the defendant until all persons entitled to recover in a civil action for the defendant's criminal conduct are made whole; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-303(9)(b): a court may not credit any payment from the defendant towards the amount of dependent support owed by the defendant against any judgment that is in favor of the victim for a civil action until all persons entitled to recover in a civil action for the defendant's criminal conduct are made whole.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402 Preservation of assets.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(1): (1)(a)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(1)(a): Before, or at the time, a criminal information, indictment charging a violation, or a petition alleging delinquency is filed, or at any time during the prosecution of the case, a prosecuting attorney may, if in the prosecuting attorney's best judgment there is a substantial likelihood that a conviction will be obtained and restitution will be ordered in the case, petition the court to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(1)(a)(i): enter a temporary restraining order, an injunction, or both;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(1)(a)(ii): require the execution of a satisfactory performance bond; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(1)(a)(iii): take any other action to preserve the availability of property that may be necessary to satisfy an anticipated order for restitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(1)(b): (1)(a)(iii) A prosecuting attorney may subpoena a document, witness, or other evidence that, in the prosecuting attorney's best judgment, may provide evidence relevant to the property described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(2)(a): (1) Upon receiving a request from a prosecuting attorney under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(2)(a)(i): there is probable cause to believe that an offense has been committed and that the defendant committed the offense, and that failure to enter the order will likely result in the property being sold, distributed, exhibited, destroyed, or removed from the jurisdiction of the court, or otherwise be made unavailable for restitution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(2)(a)(ii): the need to preserve the availability of the property or prevent the property's sale, distribution, exhibition, destruction, or removal through the entry of the requested order outweighs the hardship on any party against whom the order is to be entered.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(2)(b): In a hearing conducted in accordance with this section, a court may consider reliable hearsay as defined in Utah Rules of Evidence, Rule 1102.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(2)(c): An order for an injunction entered under this section is effective for the period of time given in the order.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(3): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(3)(a): Upon receiving a request for a temporary restraining order from a prosecuting attorney under this section, a court may enter a temporary restraining order against an owner with respect to specific property without notice or opportunity for a hearing if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(3)(a)(i): the prosecuting attorney demonstrates that there is a substantial likelihood that the property with respect to which the order is sought appears to be necessary to satisfy an anticipated restitution order under this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(3)(a)(ii): provision of notice would jeopardize the availability of the property to satisfy any judgment or order for restitution.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(3)(b): (3) The temporary order in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-38b-402(4): A hearing concerning an order entered under this section shall be held as soon as possible, and before the expiration of the temporary order.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 39 - Sale of Tobacco or Alcohol to Under Age Persons

Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101 Investigation of sales of alcohol, tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, and nicotine products to underage individuals.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(1): 76-10-101; 76-10-101; 53-13-109; 76-10-101 As used in this section:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(1)(d): 76-10-101 "Tobacco product" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(2): 32B-4-403; 76-10-114
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(2)(a): 32B-4-403; 76-10-114 A peace officer may investigate the possible violation of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(2)(a)(i): 32B-4-403 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(2)(a)(ii): 76-10-114 Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(2)(a)(ii)(A): a tobacco product;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(2)(a)(ii)(B): an electronic cigarette product; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(2)(a)(ii)(C): a nicotine product.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(2)(b): A peace officer who is present at the site of a proposed purchase shall direct, supervise, and monitor the individual requested to make the purchase.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(2)(c): Immediately following a purchase or attempted purchase or as soon as practical the supervising peace officer shall inform the cashier and the proprietor or manager of the retail establishment that the attempted purchaser was under the legal age to purchase:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(3):

Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(4): 53-1-103 The individual requested by the peace officer to attempt a purchase and anyone accompanying the individual attempting a purchase may use false identification in attempting the purchase if:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(4)(b): the false identification:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(4)(b)(ii): displays a current photo of the individual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(4)(c): the peace officer maintains possession of the false identification at all times outside the attempt to purchase.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(5): An individual requested to attempt to purchase or make a purchase pursuant to this section is immune from prosecution, suit, or civil liability for the purchase of, attempted purchase of, or possession of alcohol, a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product if a peace officer directs, supervises, and monitors the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(6): (6)(b); 32B-4-403; 76-10-114
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(6)(a): (6)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(6)(a)(i): on a random basis at any one retail establishment location, not more often than four times for the attempted purchase of alcohol; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-39-101(6)(a)(ii): a minimum of two times at a retail establishment that sells tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products for the attempted purchase of a tobacco product, an electronic cigarette product, or a nicotine product.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-101(21)(b): is prepared, owned, received, or retained by an agency, including a court.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-101(23): 73-18-13; 73-18-13.6

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-101(23)(a)(i): an infraction, a class B misdemeanor offense, or a class C misdemeanor offense under Title 41, Chapter 6a, Traffic Code;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-101(23)(a)(ii): an infraction, a class B misdemeanor offense, or a class C misdemeanor offense under Title 53, Chapter 3, Part 2, Driver Licensing Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-101(23)(a)(iii): an infraction, a class B misdemeanor offense, or a class C misdemeanor offense under Title 73, Chapter 18, State Boating Act; and

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-102 Applicability to juvenile court records.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not apply to an expungement of a record for an adjudication under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-103 Retroactive application.
---------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this chapter apply retroactively to all arrests and convictions regardless of the date on which the arrests were made or convictions were entered.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105 Eligibility for removing the link between personal identifying information and court case dismissed.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(1): 77-36-1 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(1)(a): 77-36-1 "Domestic violence offense" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(1)(b): "Personal identifying information" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(1)(b)(i): a current name, former name, nickname, or alias; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(1)(b)(ii): date of birth.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(2)(a): An individual whose criminal case is dismissed may move the court for an order to remove the link between the individual's personal identifying information from the dismissed case in any publicly searchable database of the Utah state courts.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(2)(b): If a motion is filed under Subsection (2)(a), the court shall grant the motion if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(2)(b)(i): 30 days have passed from the day on which the case is dismissed ;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(2)(b)(ii): no appeal is filed for the dismissed case within the 30-day period described in Subsection (2)(b)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(2)(b)(iii): no charge in the case was a domestic violence offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(3): Removing the link to personal identifying information of a court record under Subsection (2) does not affect a prosecuting, arresting, or other agency's records.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-105(4): A case history, unless expunged under this chapter, remains public and accessible through a search by case number.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-107 Expungement data requirements -- Report.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-107(1): No later than November 1 of each year, the Administrative Office of the Courts shall submit a written report to the Executive Offices and Criminal Justice Appropriations Subcommittee and the Judiciary Interim Committee regarding expungement data for the preceding fiscal year, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-107(1)(a): the number of petitions filed for expungement in the district, justice, and juvenile courts;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-107(1)(b): the number of petitions granted for expungement in the district, justice, and juvenile courts;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-107(1)(c): the number of orders issued for an automatic expungement by the district, justice, and juvenile courts;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-107(1)(d): the total number of individuals for whom at least one automatic expungement order was issued by the district, justice, or juvenile court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-107(1)(e): the total number of individuals for whom at least one petition-based expungement order was issued by the district, justice, or juvenile court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-107(2): No later than November 1 of each year, the bureau shall submit a written report to the Executive Offices and Criminal Justice Appropriations Subcommittee and the Judiciary Interim Committee regarding expungement data for the preceding fiscal year, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-107(2)(a): the number of applications for expungement received by the bureau;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-107(2)(b): the number of certificates of eligibility issued by the bureau; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-107(2)(c): the number of orders for expungement received by the bureau.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-201 General provisions for automatic expungement and deletion.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-201(1): Nothing in this section precludes an individual from filing a petition for expungement of records that are eligible for automatic expungement or deletion under this section if an automatic expungement or deletion has not occurred pursuant to this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-201(2): 77-40a-403; 77-40a-404 An automatic expungement performed under this part does not preclude a person from requesting access to expunged records in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-201(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-201(3)(a): The Judicial Council and the Supreme Court shall make rules to govern the process for automatic expungement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-201(3)(b): The rules under Subsection (3)(a) may authorize:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-201(3)(b)(i): a presiding judge of a district court to issue an expungement order for any case when the requirements for automatic expungement are met; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-201(3)(b)(ii): a presiding judge of a justice court to issue an expungement order for any justice court case within the presiding judge's judicial district when the requirements for automatic expungement are met.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-201(4): An individual does not have a cause of action for damages as a result of the failure to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-201(4)(a): identify an individual's case as eligible for automatic expungement or deletion under this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-201(4)(b): automatically expunge or delete the records of a case that is eligible under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-202 Automatic deletion for traffic offense by a court.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-202(1): 77-2a-3 A court shall delete all records for the following traffic offenses without a court order or notice to the prosecuting agency:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-202(1)(a): a traffic offense case that resulted in an acquittal on all charges;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-202(1)(b): 77-2a-3 a traffic offense case that is dismissed with prejudice, except for a case that is dismissed with prejudice as a result of successful completion of a plea in abeyance agreement governed by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-202(1)(c): a traffic offense case for which the following time periods have elapsed from the day on which the case is adjudicated:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-202(1)(c)(i): at least five years for a class C misdemeanor or an infraction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-202(1)(c)(ii): at least six years for a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-202(2): For a traffic offense case that results in an acquittal, is dismissed, or is adjudicated on or after May 1, 2020, the court shall delete all records for the traffic offense upon identification.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-202(3): For a traffic offense case that results in an acquittal, is dismissed, or is adjudicated before May 1, 2020, the court shall delete all records for the traffic offense within one year of the day on which the case is identified as eligible for deletion.
