Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-205(4): A prosecuting agency that has complied with Rule 42 of the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure shall receive notice on a monthly basis for any case prosecuted by that agency that appears to be eligible for automatic expungement under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-205(5): Within 35 days after the day on which the notice described in Subsection (4) is sent, the prosecuting agency shall provide written notice in accordance with Rule 42 of the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure if the prosecuting agency objects to an automatic expungement for any of the following reasons:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-205(5)(a): the prosecuting agency believes that the case is not eligible for expungement under this section after reviewing the agency record;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-205(5)(b): the individual has not paid restitution to the victim as ordered by the court; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-205(5)(c): the prosecuting agency has a reasonable belief, grounded in supporting facts, that an individual involved in the case is continuing to engage in criminal activity within or outside of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-205(6): If a prosecuting agency provides written notice of an objection for a reason described in Subsection (5) within 35 days after the day on which the notice under Subsection (4) is sent, the court may not proceed with automatic expungement of the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-205(7): If 35 days pass after the day on which the notice described in Subsection (4) is sent without the prosecuting agency providing written notice of an objection under Subsection (5), the court shall proceed with automatic expungement of the case.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-205(8)(b): notify the bureau and the prosecuting agency identified in the case, based on information available to the court, of the order of expungement.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-302(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-302(1)(a): at least 30 days have passed after the day on which the individual is arrested or charged for the offense;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-302(1)(c)(ii): there is a conviction in the case for a traffic offense that is a class B misdemeanor, at least four years have passed after the day on which the petitioner was convicted of the traffic offense.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-302(2)(c): the petitioner is currently incarcerated, on parole, or on probation, unless the petitioner is on probation or parole for an infraction, a traffic offense, or a minor regulatory offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-302(2)(d): there is a criminal protective order or a criminal stalking injunction in effect for the case.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(4): Subject to Subsections (6), (7), and (8), a petitioner is not eligible to receive a certificate of eligibility if, at the time the petitioner seeks the certificate of eligibility, the bureau determines that the petitioner's criminal history, including previously expunged convictions, contains any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(4)(a): two or more felony convictions other than for drug possession offenses, each of which is contained in a separate criminal episode;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(4)(b): any combination of three or more convictions other than for drug possession offenses that include two class A misdemeanor convictions, each of which is contained in a separate criminal episode;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(4)(c): any combination of four or more convictions other than for drug possession offenses that include three class B misdemeanor convictions, each of which is contained in a separate criminal episode; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(4)(d): five or more convictions other than for drug possession offenses of any degree whether misdemeanor or felony, each of which is contained in a separate criminal episode.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(5): Subject to Subsections (7) and (8), a petitioner is not eligible to receive a certificate of eligibility if, at the time the petitioner seeks the certificate of eligibility, the bureau determines that the petitioner's criminal history, including previously expunged convictions, contains any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(5)(a): three or more felony convictions for drug possession offenses, each of which is contained in a separate criminal episode; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(5)(b): any combination of five or more convictions for drug possession offenses, each of which is contained in a separate criminal episode.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(6): If the petitioner's criminal history contains convictions for both a drug possession offense and a non-drug possession offense arising from the same criminal episode, the bureau shall count that criminal episode as a conviction under Subsection (4) if any non-drug possession offense in that episode:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(6)(a): is a felony or class A misdemeanor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(6)(b): has the same or a longer waiting period under Subsection (1)(c) than any drug possession offense in that episode.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(7): Except as provided in Subsection (8), if at least 10 years have passed after the day on which the petitioner was convicted or released from incarceration, parole, or probation, whichever occurred last, for all convictions:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(7)(a): each numerical eligibility limit under Subsections (4)(a) and (b) shall be increased by one; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(7)(b): each numerical eligibility limit under Subsections (4)(c) and (d) is not applicable if the highest level of convicted offense in the criminal episode is:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(7)(b)(i): a class B misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(7)(b)(ii): a class C misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(7)(b)(iii): a drug possession offense if none of the non-drug possession offenses in the criminal episode are a felony or a class A misdemeanor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(7)(b)(iv): an infraction.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(8): When determining whether a petitioner is eligible for a certificate of eligibility under Subsection (4), (5), or (7), the bureau may not consider a petitioner's pending case or prior conviction for:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(8)(a): an infraction;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(8)(b): a traffic offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(8)(c): a minor regulatory offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(8)(d): a clean slate eligible case that was automatically expunged.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-303(9): 77-27-5.1 If the petitioner received a pardon before May 14, 2013, from the Utah Board of Pardons and Parole, the petitioner is entitled to an expungement order for all pardoned crimes in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304 Certificate of eligibility process -- Issuance of certificate -- Fees.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1): 77-40a-301
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(a): 77-40a-301 When a petitioner applies for a certificate of eligibility as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(a)(i): the petitioner shall pay an application fee at the time the petitioner submits an application for a certificate of eligibility to the bureau; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(a)(ii): the bureau shall perform a check of records of governmental agencies, including national criminal data bases, to determine whether the petitioner is eligible to receive a certificate of eligibility under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(b): For purposes of determining eligibility under this chapter, the bureau may review records of arrest, investigation, detention, and conviction that have been previously expunged, regardless of the jurisdiction in which the expungement occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(c): If a disposition for an arrest on the criminal history file is unobtainable after reasonable research, the bureau may issue a special certificate giving determination of eligibility to the court, except that the bureau may not issue the special certificate if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(c)(i): there is a criminal proceeding for a misdemeanor or felony offense pending against the petitioner, unless the criminal proceeding is for a traffic offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(c)(ii): there is a plea in abeyance for a misdemeanor or felony offense pending against the petitioner, unless the plea in abeyance is for a traffic offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(c)(iii): the petitioner is currently incarcerated, on parole, or on probation, unless the petitioner is on probation or parole for an infraction, a traffic offense, or a minor regulatory offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(2): 77-40a-302; 77-40a-303
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(2)(a): Once the eligibility process is complete, the bureau shall notify the petitioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(2)(b): 77-40a-302; 77-40a-303 If the petitioner meets all of the criteria under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(2)(b)(i): the bureau shall issue a certificate of eligibility or special certificate that is valid for a period of 180 days from the day on which the certificate is issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(2)(b)(ii): the bureau shall provide a petitioner with an identification number for the certificate of eligibility or special certificate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(2)(b)(iii): except as provided in Subsection (3), the petitioner shall pay an additional fee for the issuance of a certificate of eligibility or special certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(3): 77-40a-302 The bureau shall issue a certificate of eligibility or special certificate without requiring the payment of the issuance fee if the petitioner qualifies for a certificate of eligibility under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(4): The bureau shall include on a certificate of eligibility all information that is needed for the court to issue a valid expungement order.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(5): The bureau shall provide clear written instructions to the petitioner that explain:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(5)(a): the process for a petition for expungement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(5)(b): what is required of the petitioner to complete the process for a petition for expungement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(6): 63J-1-504 The bureau shall charge application and issuance fees for a certificate of eligibility or special certificate in accordance with the process in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(7): The department shall deposit funds generated by application and issuance fees under this section into the General Fund as a dedicated credit by the department to cover the costs incurred in determining eligibility for expungement.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1): 77-40a-301
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(a): 77-40a-301 When a petitioner applies for a certificate of eligibility as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(a)(i): the petitioner shall pay an application fee at the time the petitioner submits an application for a certificate of eligibility to the bureau; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(a)(ii): the bureau shall perform a check of records of governmental agencies, including national criminal data bases, to determine whether the petitioner is eligible to receive a certificate of eligibility under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(b): For purposes of determining eligibility under this chapter, the bureau may review records of arrest, investigation, detention, and conviction that have been previously expunged, regardless of the jurisdiction in which the expungement occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(c): If a disposition for an arrest on the criminal history file is unobtainable after reasonable research, the bureau may issue a special certificate giving determination of eligibility to the court, except that the bureau may not issue the special certificate if:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(c)(ii): there is a plea in abeyance for a misdemeanor or felony offense pending against the petitioner, unless the plea in abeyance is for a traffic offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(1)(c)(iii): the petitioner is currently incarcerated, on parole, or on probation, unless the petitioner is on probation or parole for an infraction, a traffic offense, or a minor regulatory offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(2): 77-40a-302; 77-40a-303

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(2)(b): 77-40a-302; 77-40a-303 If the petitioner meets all of the criteria under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(2)(b)(i): the bureau shall issue a certificate of eligibility or special certificate that is valid for a period of 180 days from the day on which the certificate is issued;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(2)(b)(iii): except as provided in Subsection (3), the petitioner shall pay an additional fee for the issuance of a certificate of eligibility or special certificate.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(6): If a petitioner indicates on the application for a certificate of eligibility that a court is likely to waive the fee for a petition for expungement as described in Subsection (3)(b), the bureau shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(6)(a): inform the petitioner that the petitioner will be required to pay an issuance fee before an agency will expunge the offense if a court does not waive the fee for a petition for expungement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(6)(b): provide the petitioner with the form for waiving a court fee for a petition for expungement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(7): If the bureau issues a certificate of eligibility or a special certificate without requiring payment of the issuance fee as described in Subsection (3)(b), the bureau shall charge the petitioner the issuance fee upon the bureau's receipt of an order deciding a petition for expungement unless the court communicates to the bureau that the fee to file the petition for expungement was waived because the petitioner is indigent.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(8): 77-40a-401; 77-40a-401; 77-40a-307
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(8)(a): 77-40a-401 If the petitioner qualifies for a waiver of the issuance fee under Subsection (7) and the expungement order grants the petition for expungement, the bureau shall process the expungement order in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-304(8)(b): 77-40a-401; 77-40a-307 If the petitioner does not qualify for a waiver of the issuance fee under Subsection (7) and the expungement order grants the petition for expungement, the bureau may not process the expungement order as described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305 Petition for expungement -- Venue -- Prosecutorial responsibility -- Hearing.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(1): 77-40a-304
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(1)(a): The petitioner shall file a petition for expungement in accordance with Rule 42 of the Utah Rules of Criminal Procedure.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(1)(b): 77-40a-304 A petitioner shall include the identification number for the certificate of eligibility or special certificate described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(1)(c): Information on a certificate of eligibility is incorporated into a petition by reference to the identification number for the certificate of eligibility.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(1)(d): A petitioner shall bring a petition for expungement:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(1)(d)(i): in the court where the criminal case was filed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(1)(d)(ii): if charges were never filed, in the district court in the county in which the arrest occurred or the citation was issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(2): 77-40a-304
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(2)(a): If a petition for expungement is filed under Subsection (1)(a), the court shall obtain a certificate of eligibility or special certificate from the bureau.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(2)(b): 77-40a-304 A court may not accept a petition for expungement if the certificate of eligibility or special certificate is no longer valid as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(3): Notwithstanding Subsection (2), the petitioner may file a petition for expungement of a traffic offense case without obtaining a certificate of eligibility if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(3)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(3)(a)(i): for a traffic offense case with a class C misdemeanor or infraction, at least three years have passed after the day on which the case was adjudicated or dismissed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(3)(a)(ii): for a traffic offense case with a class B misdemeanor, at least four years have passed after the day on which the case was adjudicated or dismissed;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(3)(b): there is no traffic offense case pending against the petitioner;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(3)(c): there is no plea in abeyance for a traffic offense case pending against the petitioner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(3)(d): the petitioner is not currently on probation for a traffic offense case.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(4): 26B-4-201 Notwithstanding Subsection (2), a petitioner may file a petition for expungement of a record for a conviction related to cannabis possession without a certificate of eligibility if the petition demonstrates that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(4)(a): 26B-4-201 the petitioner had, at the time of the relevant arrest or citation leading to the conviction, a qualifying condition, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(4)(b): the possession of cannabis in question was in a form and an amount to medicinally treat the qualifying condition described in Subsection (4)(a).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(5)(a): The court shall provide notice of a filing of a petition and certificate of eligibility or special certificate to the prosecutorial office that handled the court proceedings within three days after the day on which the petitioner's filing fee is paid or waived.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(5)(b): If there were no court proceedings, the court shall provide notice of a filing of a petition and certificate of eligibility or special certificate to the county attorney's office in the jurisdiction where the arrest occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(5)(c): If the prosecuting agency with jurisdiction over the arrest, investigation, detention, or conviction, was a city attorney's office, the county attorney's office in the jurisdiction where the arrest occurred shall immediately notify the city attorney's office that the county attorney's office has received a notice of a filing of a petition for expungement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(6)(a): Upon receipt of a notice of a filing of a petition for expungement of a conviction or a charge dismissed in accordance with a plea in abeyance, the prosecuting attorney shall make a reasonable effort to provide notice to any victim of the conviction or charge.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(6)(b): The notice under Subsection (6)(a) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(6)(b)(i): include a copy of the petition, certificate of eligibility or special certificate, statutes, and rules applicable to the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(6)(b)(ii): state that the victim has a right to object to the expungement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(6)(b)(iii): provide instructions for registering an objection with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(7)(a): The prosecuting attorney may respond to the petition by filing a recommendation or objection with the court within 35 days after the day on which the notice of the filing of the petition is sent by the court to the prosecuting attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(7)(b): If there is a victim of the offense for which expungement is sought, the victim may respond to the petition by filing a recommendation or objection with the court within 60 days after the day on which the petition for expungement was filed with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(8)(a): The court may request a written response to the petition from the Division of Adult Probation and Parole within the Department of Corrections.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(8)(b): If requested, the response prepared by the Division of Adult Probation and Parole shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(8)(b)(i): the reasons probation was terminated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(8)(b)(ii): certification that the petitioner has completed all requirements of sentencing and probation or parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(8)(c): The Division of Adult Probation and Parole shall provide a copy of the response to the petitioner and the prosecuting attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(9): The petitioner may respond in writing to any objections filed by the prosecuting attorney or the victim and the response prepared by the Division of Adult Probation and Parole within 14 days after the day on which the objection or response is received.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(10)(a): If the court receives an objection concerning the petition from any party, the court shall set a date for a hearing and notify the petitioner and the prosecuting attorney of the date set for the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(10)(b): The prosecuting attorney shall notify the victim of the date set for the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(10)(c): The petitioner, the prosecuting attorney, the victim, and any other person who has relevant information about the petitioner may testify at the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(10)(d): The court shall review the petition, the certificate of eligibility or special certificate, and any written responses submitted regarding the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-305(11): If no objection is received within 60 days from the day on which the petition for expungement is filed with the court, the expungement may be granted without a hearing.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1): 77-40a-305; 77-40a-305; 77-40a-305; 26B-4-201 If a petition for expungement is filed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(a): 77-40a-305 except as provided in Subsection (1)(b) and Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(a)(i): the certificate of eligibility is valid and contains the information needed for the court to issue an order for expungement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(a)(ii): the statutory requirements for expungement have been met;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(b): if the petitioner obtained a special certificate from the bureau:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(b)(i): the special certificate is valid; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(b)(ii): there is sufficient information in the petition for the court to determine that the statutory requirements for expungement have been met;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(c): if the petitioner seeks expungement after a case is dismissed without prejudice or without condition, the prosecuting attorney provided written consent and has not filed and does not intend to refile related charges;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(d): 77-40a-305; 26B-4-201 if the petitioner seeks expungement without a certificate of eligibility for expungement under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(d)(i): 26B-4-201 the petitioner had, at the time of the relevant arrest or citation leading to the conviction, a qualifying condition, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(d)(ii): the possession of cannabis in question was in a form and an amount to medicinally treat the qualifying condition described in Subsection (1)(d)(i);
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(e): if an objection is received, the petition for expungement is for a charge dismissed in accordance with a plea in abeyance agreement, and the charge is an offense eligible to be used for enhancement, there is good cause for the court to grant the expungement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(1)(f): the interests of the public would not be harmed by granting the expungement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(2)(a): If the court denies a petition described in Subsection (1)(c) because the prosecuting attorney intends to refile charges, the petitioner may apply again for a certificate of eligibility if charges are not refiled within 180 days after the day on which the court denies the petition.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(2)(b): A prosecuting attorney who opposes an expungement of a case dismissed without prejudice, or without condition, shall have a good faith basis for the intention to refile the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(2)(c): A court shall consider the number of times that good faith basis of intention to refile by the prosecuting attorney is presented to the court in making the court's determination to grant the petition for expungement described in Subsection (1)(c).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(3): If the court grants a petition described in Subsection (1)(e), the court shall make the court's findings in a written order.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(4): 77-40a-302; 77-40a-303 A court may not expunge a conviction of an offense for which a certificate of eligibility may not be, or should not have been, issued under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(5): 77-40a-401 If the court issues an order of expungement under this section, the court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(5)(a): 77-40a-401 expunge all records of the case as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(5)(b): notify the bureau of the order of expungement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(5)(c): provide the bureau with the order of expungement and all relevant information available to the court that the bureau will need to identify an expunged record.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(6)(a): The petitioner may request certified copies of an order of expungement within 28 days after the day on which the court issues an order of expungement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-306(6)(b): If a petitioner makes a request under Subsection (6)(a), the court shall provide the petitioner with certified copies of the order of expungement.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403 Retention and release of expunged records -- Agencies.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(1): (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(1)(a): After receiving an order of expungement, the bureau shall keep, index, and maintain all expunged records of arrests and convictions.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(1)(b): An agency, other than the bureau, receiving an order of expungement shall develop and implement a process to identify and maintain an expunged record.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(1)(c): (1)(b) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(1)(d): An agency is not required to redact an expunged record, or a record referencing an expunged record, that pertains to more than one individual until the agency is required to release the record.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2): 63J-1-504
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(a): An agency shall provide an individual who receives an expungement with written confirmation that the agency has expunged all records of the offense for which the individual received the expungement if the individual requests confirmation from the agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(b): 63J-1-504 The bureau may charge a fee for providing a written confirmation under Subsection (2)(a) in accordance with the process in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(3): 77-40a-404
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(3)(a): 77-40a-404 An employee of the bureau, or any agency with an expunged record, may not divulge any information contained in the expunged record to any person or agency without a court order unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(3)(a)(i): 77-40a-404 specifically authorized by Subsection (4) or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(3)(a)(ii): subject to Subsection (3)(b), the information in an expunged record is being shared with another agency through a records management system that both agencies use for the purpose of record management.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(3)(b): An agency with a records management system may not disclose any information in an expunged record to another agency or person, or allow another agency or person access to an expunged record, if that agency or person does not use the records management system for the purpose of record management.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4): The following entities or agencies may receive information contained in expunged records upon specific request:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(a): the Board of Pardons and Parole;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(b): Peace Officer Standards and Training;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(c): federal authorities if required by federal law;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(d): the State Board of Education;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(e): the Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice, for purposes of investigating applicants for judicial office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(f): a research institution or an agency engaged in research regarding the criminal justice system if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(f)(i): the research institution or agency provides a legitimate research purpose for gathering information from the expunged records;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(f)(ii): the research institution or agency enters into a data sharing agreement with the court or agency with custody of the expunged records that protects the confidentiality of any identifying information in the expunged records;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(f)(iii): any research using expunged records does not include any individual's name or identifying information in any product of that research; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(f)(iv): any product resulting from research using expunged records includes a disclosure that expunged records were used for research purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(5): Except as otherwise provided by this section or by court order, a person, an agency, or an entity authorized by this section to view expunged records may not reveal or release any information obtained from the expunged records to anyone outside the specific request, including distribution on a public website.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(6): 76-5-106.5; 77-36-1; 77-41-102 A prosecuting attorney may communicate with another prosecuting attorney, or another prosecutorial agency, regarding information in an expunged record that includes a conviction, or a charge dismissed as a result of a successful completion of a plea in abeyance agreement, for:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(6)(b): 77-36-1 a domestic violence offense as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(6)(c): 77-41-102 an offense that would require the individual to register as a sex offender, kidnap offender, or child abuse offender as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(6)(d): a weapons offense under Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 5, Weapons.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(7): Except as provided in Subsection (9), a prosecuting attorney may not use an expunged record for the purpose of a sentencing enhancement or as a basis for charging an individual with an offense that requires a prior conviction.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(8): 53-5-704 The bureau may also use the information in the bureau's index as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(9): If an individual is charged with a felony, or an offense eligible for enhancement based on a prior conviction, after obtaining an order of expungement, the prosecuting attorney may petition the court in which the individual is charged to open the expunged records upon a showing of good cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(10): 77-27-5.1

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(1): 77-40a-404
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(1)(a): 77-40a-404 An agency with an expunged record, or any employee of an agency with an expunged record, may not knowingly or intentionally divulge any information contained in the expunged record to any person, or another agency, without a court order unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(1)(a)(i): 77-40a-404 specifically authorized by Subsection (4) or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(1)(a)(ii): subject to Subsection (1)(b), the information in an expunged record is being shared with another agency through a records management system that both agencies use for the purpose of record management.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(1)(b): An agency with a records management system may not disclose any information in an expunged record to another agency or person, or allow another agency or person access to an expunged record, if that agency or person does not use the records management system for the purpose of record management.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2): The following entities or agencies may receive information contained in expunged records upon specific request:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(a): the Board of Pardons and Parole;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(b): Peace Officer Standards and Training;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(c): federal authorities if required by federal law;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(d): the State Board of Education;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(e): the Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice, for purposes of investigating applicants for judicial office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(f): a research institution or an agency engaged in research regarding the criminal justice system if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(f)(i): the research institution or agency provides a legitimate research purpose for gathering information from the expunged records;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(f)(ii): the research institution or agency enters into a data sharing agreement with the court or agency with custody of the expunged records that protects the confidentiality of any identifying information in the expunged records;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(f)(iii): any research using expunged records does not include any individual's name or identifying information in any product of that research; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(2)(f)(iv): any product resulting from research using expunged records includes a disclosure that expunged records were used for research purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(3): Except as otherwise provided by this section or by court order, a person, an agency, or an entity authorized by this section to view expunged records may not reveal or release any information obtained from the expunged records to anyone outside the specific request, including distribution on a public website.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4): 76-5-106.5; 77-36-1; 77-41-102 A prosecuting attorney may communicate with another prosecuting attorney, or another prosecutorial agency, regarding information in an expunged record that includes a conviction, or a charge dismissed as a result of a successful completion of a plea in abeyance agreement, for:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(a): 76-5-106.5 stalking as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(b): 77-36-1 a domestic violence offense as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(c): 77-41-102 an offense that would require the individual to register as a sex offender, kidnap offender, or child abuse offender as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(4)(d): a weapons offense under Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 5, Weapons.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(5): Except as provided in Subsection (7), a prosecuting attorney may not use an expunged record for the purpose of a sentencing enhancement or as a basis for charging an individual with an offense that requires a prior conviction.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(6): 53-5-704 The bureau may also use the information in the bureau's index as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(7): If an individual is charged with a felony, or an offense eligible for enhancement based on a prior conviction, after obtaining an order of expungement, the prosecuting attorney may petition the court in which the individual is charged to open the expunged records upon a showing of good cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(8): 77-27-5.1
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(8)(a): 77-27-5.1 For judicial sentencing, a court may order any records expunged under this chapter or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(8)(b): The records are confidential and are available for inspection only by the court, parties, counsel for the parties, and any other person who is authorized by the court to inspect them.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(8)(c): At the end of the action or proceeding, the court shall order the records expunged again.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-403(8)(d): Any person authorized by this Subsection (8) to view expunged records may not reveal or release any information obtained from the expunged records to anyone outside the court.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-404 Confirmation of expungement -- Access to expunged records by individuals.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-404(1): 77-40a-401 An individual who receives an expungement may request a written confirmation from an agency under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-404(2): 77-27-5.1 The following individuals may view or obtain an expunged record under this chapter or Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-404(2)(a): the petitioner or an individual who receives an automatic expungement under Part 2, Automatic Expungement and Deletion;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-404(2)(b): a law enforcement officer, who was involved in the case, for use solely in the officer's defense of a civil action arising out of the officer's involvement with the petitioner in that particular case; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-40a-404(2)(c): a party to a civil action arising out of the expunged incident if the information is kept confidential and utilized only in the action.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104 Registration of offenders -- Department and agency requirements.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(1): The Department of Corrections shall register an offender in the custody of the Department of Corrections as required under this chapter upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(1)(a): placement on probation;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(1)(b): commitment to a secure correctional facility operated by or under contract to the Department of Corrections;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(1)(c): release from confinement to parole status, termination or expiration of sentence, or escape;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(1)(d): entrance to and release from any community-based residential program operated by or under contract to the Department of Corrections; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(1)(e): termination of probation or parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(2): The sheriff of the county in which an offender is confined shall register an offender with the department, as required under this chapter, if the offender is not in the custody of the Department of Corrections and is confined in a correctional facility not operated by or under contract to the Department of Corrections upon:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(2)(a): commitment to the correctional facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(2)(b): release from confinement.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(3): The division shall register an offender in the custody of the division with the department, as required under this chapter, before the offender's release from custody of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(4): A state mental hospital shall register an offender committed to the state mental hospital with the department, as required under this chapter, upon the offender's admission and upon the offender's discharge.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(5): (5)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(5)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(5)(a)(i): A municipal or county law enforcement agency shall register an offender who resides within the agency's jurisdiction and is not under the supervision of the Division of Adult Probation and Parole within the Department of Corrections.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(5)(a)(ii): In order to conduct offender registration under this chapter, the agency shall ensure the agency staff responsible for registration:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(5)(a)(ii)(A): has received initial training by the department and has been certified by the department as qualified and authorized to conduct registrations and enter offender registration information into the registry database; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(5)(a)(ii)(B): certify annually with the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(5)(b): (5)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(5)(b)(i): When the department receives offender registration information regarding a change of an offender's primary residence location, the department shall within five days after the day on which the department receives the information electronically notify the law enforcement agencies that have jurisdiction over the area where:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(5)(b)(i)(A): the residence that the offender is leaving is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(5)(b)(i)(B): the residence to which the offender is moving is located.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(5)(c): The department shall make available to offenders required to register under this chapter the name of the agency, whether the agency is a local law enforcement agency or the department, that the offender should contact to register, the location for registering, and the requirements of registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(6): 77-41-105(3) An agency in the state that registers an offender on probation, an offender who has been released from confinement to parole status or termination, or an offender whose sentence has expired shall inform the offender of the duty to comply with the continuing registration requirements of this chapter during the period of registration required in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(6)(a): notification to the state agencies in the states where the registrant presently resides and plans to reside when moving across state lines;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(6)(b): verification of address at least every 60 days pursuant to a parole agreement for lifetime parolees; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(6)(c): notification to the out-of-state agency where the offender is living, regardless of whether the offender is a resident of that state.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-104(7): The department may make administrative rules necessary to implement this chapter, including:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-107 Penalties.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-107(1): 77-41-102; 77-41-105; 77-41-102 An offender who knowingly fails to register under this chapter or provides false or incomplete information is guilty of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-107(1)(a): 77-41-102; 77-41-105 a third degree felony and shall be sentenced to serve a term of incarceration for not less than 30 days and also at least one year of probation if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-107(1)(a)(i): 77-41-102 the offender is required to register for a felony conviction or adjudicated delinquent for what would be a felony if the juvenile were an adult of an offense listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-107(1)(a)(ii): 77-41-105 the offender is required to register for the offender's lifetime under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-107(1)(b): 77-41-102 a class A misdemeanor and shall be sentenced to serve a term of incarceration for not fewer than 30 days and also at least one year of probation if the offender is required to register for a misdemeanor conviction or is adjudicated delinquent for what would be a misdemeanor if the juvenile were an adult of an offense listed in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-107(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-107(2)(a): Neither the court nor the Board of Pardons and Parole may release an individual who violates this chapter from serving the term required under Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-107(2)(b): This Subsection (2) supersedes any other provision of the law contrary to this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-107(3): The offender shall register for an additional year for every year in which the offender does not comply with the registration requirements of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110 Sex offender, kidnap offender, and child abuse offender registry -- Department to maintain.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(1): The department shall maintain a Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Notification and Registration website on the Internet, which shall contain a disclaimer informing the public:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(1)(a): the information contained on the site is obtained from offenders and the department does not guarantee its accuracy or completeness;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(1)(b): members of the public are not allowed to use the information to harass or threaten offenders or members of their families; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(1)(c): harassment, stalking, or threats against offenders or their families are prohibited and doing so may violate Utah criminal laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(2): The Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Notification and Registration website shall be indexed by both the surname of the offender and by postal codes.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(3): The department shall construct the Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Notification and Registration website so that users, before accessing registry information, must indicate that they have read the disclaimer, understand it, and agree to comply with its terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(4): 77-41-102 Except as provided in Subsection (7), the Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Notification and Registration website shall include the following registry information:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(4)(a): all names and aliases by which the offender is or has been known, but not including any online or Internet identifiers;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(4)(b): the addresses of the offender's primary, secondary, and temporary residences;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(4)(c): a physical description, including the offender's date of birth, height, weight, and eye and hair color;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(4)(d): the make, model, color, year, and plate number of any vehicle or vehicles the offender owns or regularly drives;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(4)(e): a current photograph of the offender;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(4)(f): a list of all professional licenses that authorize the offender to engage in an occupation or carry out a trade or business;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(4)(g): each educational institution in Utah at which the offender is employed, carries on a vocation, or is a student;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(4)(h): a list of places where the offender works as a volunteer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(4)(i): 77-41-102 the crimes listed in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(5): 77-41-105(7)(h); 77-41-105(7)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(5)(a): 77-41-105(7)(h); 77-41-105(7)(i) The department shall enable the public to search the Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Notification and Registration website to determine if the following search criteria are linked to an offender:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(5)(a)(i): 77-41-105(7)(h) telephone numbers or other designations for an offender provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(5)(a)(ii): 77-41-105(7)(i) Internet identifiers or other addresses for an offender provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(5)(a)(iii): names and Internet addresses of websites on which an offender is registered using an online identifier, including the online identifier used to access the website.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(5)(b): The department shall ensure that a search performed using the criteria in Subsection (5)(a):
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(5)(b)(i): provides the individual requesting the search with only information regarding whether the criteria are linked to an offender; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(5)(b)(ii): does not return the name or any other identifying information about an offender.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(5)(c): The department is not required to:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(5)(c)(i): report the results of the search under Subsection (5)(a) to a law enforcement agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(5)(c)(ii): based on the results of a search under Subsection (5)(a), open an investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(6): The department, the department's personnel, and any individual or entity acting at the request or upon the direction of the department are immune from civil liability for damages for good faith compliance with this chapter and will be presumed to have acted in good faith by reporting information.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-110(7): The department shall redact information that, if disclosed, could reasonably identify a victim.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-111 Fees.
-------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-111(1): 77-41-105 Each offender required to register under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-111(1)(a): pay to the department an annual fee of $100 each year the offender is subject to the registration requirements of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-111(1)(b): pay to the registering agency, if it is an agency other than the department, an annual fee of not more than $25, which may be assessed by that agency for providing registration.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-111(2): (1) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-111(3): The department shall deposit fees collected in accordance with this chapter in the General Fund as a dedicated credit, to be used by the department for maintaining the offender registry under this chapter and monitoring offender registration compliance, including the costs of:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-111(3)(a): data entry;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-111(3)(b): processing registration packets;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-111(3)(c): updating registry information; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-111(3)(d): reporting an offender not in compliance with registration requirements to a law enforcement agency.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112 Removal from registry -- Requirements -- Procedure.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(1): 77-41-105; 80-1-102; 77-41-105; 80-1-102 An offender who is required to register with the Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry may petition the court for an order removing the offender from the Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(1)(a)(i): the offender was convicted of an offense described in Subsection (2);

Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(1)(a)(iv): the offender has not been convicted of another offense, excluding a traffic offense, since the day on which the offender was convicted of the offense for which the offender is required to register, as evidenced by a certificate of eligibility issued by the bureau;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(1)(a)(v): the offender successfully completed all treatment ordered by the court or the Board of Pardons and Parole relating to the offense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(1)(a)(vi): the offender has paid all restitution ordered by the court or the Board of Pardons and Parole relating to the offense;

Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(1)(b)(i): 77-41-105 the offender is required to register in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(1)(b)(ii): 80-1-102 at least 10 years have passed after the later of:

Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(1)(b)(iv): the offender successfully completed all treatment ordered by the court or the Board of Pardons and Parole relating to the offense; and

Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(5)(a): The offender shall file the petition, including original information, the court docket, the certificate of eligibility from the bureau, and the document from the department described in Subsection (3)(b)(iv) with the court, and deliver a copy of the petition to the office of the prosecutor.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(5)(b): Upon receipt of a petition for removal from the Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry, the office of the prosecutor shall provide notice of the petition by first-class mail to the victim at the most recent address of record on file or, if the victim is still a minor under 18 years old, to the parent or guardian of the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(5)(c): The notice described in Subsection (5)(b) shall include a copy of the petition, state that the victim has a right to object to the removal of the offender from the registry, and provide instructions for registering an objection with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(5)(d): The office of the prosecutor shall provide the following, if available, to the court within 30 days after the day on which the office receives the petition:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(5)(d)(i): presentencing report;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(5)(d)(ii): an evaluation done as part of sentencing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(5)(d)(iii): other information the office of the prosecutor determines the court should consider.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(5)(e): The victim, or the victim's parent or guardian if the victim is a minor under 18 years old, may respond to the petition by filing a recommendation or objection with the court within 45 days after the day on which the petition is mailed to the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(a): The court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(a)(i): review the petition and all documents submitted with the petition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(a)(ii): hold a hearing if requested by the prosecutor or the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(i): Except as provided in Subsections (6)(b)(ii) and (iii), the court may grant the petition and order removal of the offender from the registry if the court determines that the offender has met the requirements described in Subsection (1)(a) or (b) and removal is not contrary to the interests of the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(ii): When considering a petition filed under Subsection (1)(c), the court shall determine whether the offender has demonstrated, by clear and convincing evidence, that the offender is rehabilitated and does not pose a threat to the safety of the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(iii): In making the determination described in Subsection (6)(b)(ii), the court may consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(iii)(A): the nature and degree of violence involved in the offense that requires registration;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(iii)(B): the age and number of victims of the offense that requires registration;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(iii)(C): the age of the offender at the time of the offense that requires registration;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(iii)(D): the offender's performance while on supervision for the offense that requires registration;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(iii)(E): the offender's stability in employment and housing;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(iii)(F): the offender's community and personal support system;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(iii)(G): other criminal and relevant noncriminal behavior of the offender both before and after the offense that requires registration;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(iii)(H): the level of risk posed by the offender as evidenced by the evidence-based risk assessment described in Subsection (1)(c)(vi); and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(b)(iii)(I): any other relevant factors.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(c): In determining whether removal is contrary to the interests of the public, the court may not consider removal unless the offender has substantially complied with all registration requirements under this chapter at all times.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(d): If the court grants the petition, the court shall forward a copy of the order directing removal of the offender from the registry to the department and the office of the prosecutor.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(e)(i): Except as provided in Subsection (6)(e)(ii), if the court denies the petition, the offender may not submit another petition for three years.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(6)(e)(ii): If the offender files a petition under Subsection (1)(c) and the court denies the petition, the offender may not submit another petition for eight years.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(7): The court shall notify the victim and the Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry office in the department of the court's decision within three days after the day on which the court issues the court's decision in the same manner described in Subsection (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(8): 77-41-105 Except as provided in Subsection (9), an offender required to register under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(8)(a): meets the requirements of Subsections (1)(b)(ii) through (v);
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(8)(b): has resided in this state for at least 183 days in a year for two consecutive years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(8)(c): intends to primarily reside in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(9): 77-41-105; 77-41-106 An offender required to register under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(9)(a): 77-41-106 the offense requiring the offender to register is substantially equivalent to an offense listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(9)(b): the offender meets the requirements of Subsections (1)(c)(ii) through (vi);
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(9)(c): the offender has resided in this state for at least 183 days in a year for two consecutive years; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-112(9)(d): the offender intends to primarily reside in this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113 Removal for offenses or convictions for which registration is no longer required.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(1): The department shall automatically remove an individual who is currently on the Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry because of a conviction if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(1)(a): the only offense or offenses for which the individual is on the registry are listed in Subsection (2); or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(1)(b): the department receives a formal notification or order from the court or the Board of Pardons and Parole that the conviction for the offense or offenses for which the individual is on the registry have been reversed, vacated, or pardoned.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(2): 76-4-401; 76-5-301; 76-5-301.1; 76-5-304; 76-5-401; 76-5-403 The offenses described in Subsection (1)(a) are:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(2)(a): 76-4-401 a class B or class C misdemeanor for enticing a minor under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(2)(b): 76-5-301 kidnapping under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(2)(c): 76-5-301.1 child kidnapping under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(2)(d): 76-5-304 unlawful detention under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(2)(e): 76-5-401 a third degree felony for unlawful sexual intercourse before 1986, or a class B misdemeanor for unlawful sexual intercourse, under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(2)(f): 76-5-403 sodomy, but not forcible sodomy, under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(3)(a): The department shall notify an individual who has been removed from the registry in accordance with Subsection (1).
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(3)(b): The notice described in Subsection (3)(a) shall include a statement that the individual is no longer required to register as a sex offender or kidnap offender.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(4): An individual who is currently on the Sex, Kidnap, and Child Abuse Offender Registry may submit a request to the department to be removed from the registry if the individual believes that the individual qualifies for removal under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(5): The department, upon receipt of a request for removal from the registry shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(5)(a): check the registry for the individual's current status;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(5)(b): determine whether the individual qualifies for removal based upon this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(5)(c): notify the individual in writing of the department's determination and whether the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(5)(c)(i): qualifies for removal from the registry; or
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(5)(c)(ii): does not qualify for removal.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(6): If the department determines that the individual qualifies for removal from the registry, the department shall remove the offender from the registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(7): If the department determines that the individual does not qualify for removal from the registry, the department shall provide an explanation in writing for the department's determination. The department's determination is final and not subject to administrative review.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(8): Neither the department nor an employee of the department may be civilly liable for a determination made in good faith in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(9)(a): The department shall provide a response to a request for removal within 30 days of receipt of the request.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-41-113(9)(b): If the response under Subsection (9)(a) cannot be provided within 30 days, the department shall notify the individual that the response may be delayed up to 30 additional days.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 77 - Chapter 42 - Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry
***************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry."

Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-102(1): "Attorney general" means the Utah attorney general or a deputy attorney general.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-102(2): 53-10-201 "Bureau" means the Bureau of Criminal Identification of the Department of Public Safety established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-102(3): "Business day" means a day on which state offices are open for regular business.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-102(4): 77-42-108 "Certificate of eligibility" means a document issued by the Bureau of Criminal Identification stating that the offender has met the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-102(5): 76-3-201 "Conviction" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-102(6): 77-42-105 "Offender" means an individual required to register as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-102(7): "Register" means to comply with the requirements of this chapter and rules of the Office of the Attorney General made under this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103 Duties.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(1): 77-42-104 The attorney general shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(1)(a): develop and operate a system to collect, analyze, maintain, and disseminate information on offenders; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(1)(b): 77-42-104 make information listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(2): 77-42-105 Any prosecuting attorney who obtains a conviction for an offense listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(2)(a): inform the attorney general within 45 business days of sentencing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(2)(b): in a manner prescribed by the attorney general, cooperate with a request for information by the attorney general.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(3): The attorney general shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(3)(a): provide the following additional information when available:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(3)(a)(i): the crimes for which the offender has been convicted;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(3)(a)(ii): a description of the offender's targets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(3)(a)(iii): any other relevant identifying information as determined by the attorney general;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(3)(b): maintain the Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry website; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-103(3)(c): ensure that information is entered into the offender registry in a timely manner.


Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104 Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry -- Attorney general to maintain.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(1): The attorney general shall maintain the Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry website on the Internet, which shall contain a disclaimer informing the public that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(1)(a): the information contained on the website is obtained from government records where feasible, however, the attorney general does not guarantee the website's accuracy or completeness;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(1)(b): members of the public are not allowed to use the information to harass or threaten offenders or members of their families; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(1)(c): harassment, stalking, or making threats against offenders or their families is prohibited and may violate Utah criminal laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(2): The Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry website shall be indexed by the surname of the offender.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(3): The attorney general shall construct the Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry website so that before accessing registry information, users must indicate that they have read and understand the disclaimer and agree to comply with the disclaimer's terms.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(4): (6); 77-42-105 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(4)(a): all names and aliases by which the offender is or has been known, but not including any online or Internet identifiers;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(4)(b): a physical description, including the offender's date of birth, height, weight, and eye and hair color;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(4)(c): a recent photograph of the offender; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(4)(d): 77-42-105 the crimes listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(5): The Office of the Attorney General and any individual or entity acting at the request or upon the direction of the attorney general are immune from civil liability for damages and will be presumed to have acted in good faith by reporting information.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(6): The attorney general shall redact the names, addresses, phone numbers, Social Security numbers, and other information that, if disclosed, specifically identifies individual victims.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(7): (4); 77-42-106(2); 77-42-105 An offender is considered to have consented to the public posting of the images or records specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(7)(a): 77-42-106(2); 77-42-105 fails to register as required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-104(7)(b): fails to appear at the request of the Office of the Attorney General to have a current photograph taken.

Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106 Registration of offenders -- Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry -- Penalty for failure to register.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(1): 77-42-105 An offender who has been convicted of any offense listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(1)(a): a period of 10 years for a first offense;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(1)(b): a second period of 10 years for a second conviction under this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(1)(c): a lifetime period if convicted a third time under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(2): (3); 77-42-105 Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(2)(a): with the attorney general to be included in the Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(2)(b)(i): no later than 45 days after the offender is sentenced; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(2)(b)(ii): in a manner prescribed by the attorney general.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(3): (2) An offender is not required to register as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(3)(a): has complied with all court orders at the time of sentencing;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(3)(b): has paid in full all court-ordered amounts of restitution to victims; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(3)(c): has not been convicted of any other offense for which registration would be required.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(4): If an offender is in the custody of the Department of Corrections:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-106(4)(a): the department shall register the offender within 45 days of sentencing; or

Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108 Removal from the Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(1): Title 41, Chapter 6a, Part 5, Driving Under the Influence and Reckless Driving An offender may petition the court where the offender was convicted of the offense for which registration with the Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry is required, for an order to remove the offender from the Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry, if:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(1)(a): five years have passed since the completion of the offender's sentence;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(1)(b): the offender has successfully completed all treatment ordered by the court or the Board of Pardons and Parole relating to the conviction;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(1)(c): Title 41, Chapter 6a, Part 5, Driving Under the Influence and Reckless Driving
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(1)(c)(i): the offender has not been convicted of any other crime, excluding traffic offenses, as evidenced by a certificate of eligibility issued by the bureau; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(1)(c)(ii): Title 41, Chapter 6a, Part 5, Driving Under the Influence and Reckless Driving as used in this section, "traffic offense" does not include a violation of
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(1)(d): the offender has paid all restitution ordered by the court;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(1)(e): notice has been delivered to the victims and the office that prosecuted the offender; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(1)(f): the offender has not been found to be civilly liable in any case in which fraud, misrepresentation, deceit, breach of fiduciary duty, or the misuse or misappropriation of funds is an element.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2): 76-8-504.6; (2); (1)(a); (d); 63J-1-504; (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(a): 76-8-504.6; (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(a)(i): An offender seeking removal from the White Collar Crime Offender Registry shall apply for a certificate of eligibility from the bureau.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(a)(ii): 76-8-504.6 An offender who intentionally or knowingly provides any false or misleading information to the bureau when applying for a certificate of eligibility is guilty of a class B misdemeanor and subject to prosecution under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(a)(iii): (2) Regardless of whether the offender is prosecuted, the bureau may deny a certificate of eligibility to anyone providing false information on an application under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(b): (1)(a); (d)
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(b)(i): The bureau shall check the records of governmental agencies, including national criminal databases, to determine whether an offender is eligible to receive a certificate of eligibility under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(b)(ii): (1)(a); (d) If the offender meets all of the criteria under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(c): 63J-1-504
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(c)(i): 63J-1-504 The bureau shall charge an application fee for the certificate of eligibility in accordance with the process in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(c)(ii): The fee shall be paid at the time the offender submits an application for a certificate of eligibility to the bureau.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(c)(iii): If the bureau determines that the issuance of a certificate of eligibility is appropriate, the bureau shall issue to the offender a certificate of eligibility at no additional charge.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(2)(d): (2) Funds generated under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(3): (1) The offender shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(3)(a): (1) file with the court the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(3)(a)(i): the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(3)(a)(ii): the original information;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(3)(a)(iii): the court docket; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(3)(a)(iv): (1) an affidavit certifying that the offender is in compliance with the provisions of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(3)(b): deliver a copy of the petition to the office of the prosecutor.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(4)(a): Upon receipt of a petition for removal from the Utah White Collar Crime Offender Registry, the office of the prosecutor shall provide notice of the petition by first-class mail to the victims at the most recent addresses of record on file.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(4)(b): The notice shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(4)(b)(i): include a copy of the petition for removal from the registry;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(4)(b)(ii): state that the victim has a right to object to the removal of the offender from the registry; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(4)(b)(iii): provide instructions for filing an objection with the court.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(5): The office of the prosecutor shall provide the following, if available, to the court within 30 days after receiving the petition:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(5)(a): a presentence report;
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(5)(b): any evaluation done as part of sentencing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(5)(c): any other information the office of the prosecutor feels the court should consider.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(6): The victim may respond to the petition by filing a recommendation or objection with the court within 45 days after the mailing of the petition to the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(7): The court shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(7)(a): review the petition and all documents submitted with the petition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(7)(b): hold a hearing if requested by the office of the prosecutor or the victim.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(8): When considering a petition for removal from the registry, the court shall consider whether the offender has paid all restitution ordered by the court or the Board of Pardons and Parole.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(9): If the court determines that it is not contrary to the interests of the public to do so, the court may grant the petition and order removal of the offender from the registry.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(10): If the court grants the petition, the court shall forward a copy of the order directing removal of the offender from the registry to the attorney general and the office of the prosecutor.
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(11): (3)(a) The office of the prosecutor shall notify the victims of the court's decision in the same manner as the notification required in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(12): 77-42-105 The attorney general shall remove an offender from the registry upon the offender providing satisfactory evidence to the attorney general that:
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(12)(a): 77-42-105 each conviction listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 77-42-108(12)(b): the offender has paid all court-ordered restitution to victims.
